"Oh," Jenna added casually, "he also ordered two bottles of Romanée-Conti."

Patrick's walkie-talkie clattered to the floor. Twenty-six thousand dollar wines, just like that? What kind of magic had this girl worked on Tony?
###Chapter 33

Patrick Klein stared at the bill on his computer screen, fingers tapping lightly on the desk.

"How unusual. Tony Lombardi actually acknowledged you as his little sister."

He looked up at Jenna Roland, surprise flickering in his eyes.

Jenna stood before his desk, hands clasped in front of her.

"I didn’t expect it either."

Patrick suddenly laughed, the wrinkles on his face smoothing out.

"Well, this works out perfectly. From now on, you’ll handle him whenever he comes. Saves the others from hiding."

Jenna pressed her lips together.

"He’s not that scary, really."

Patrick stood and patted her shoulder.

"Congratulations. Your commission this time is over fifty grand."

Jenna gave a slight bow.

"Thank you, Mr. Klein."

"Go take a break."

Jenna turned and left the office, taking the elevator down to the staff lounge.

She had just settled onto the couch when the door swung open.

Tristan Ashcroft strode in, a sheen of sweat on his forehead.

"Did Tony Lombardi do anything to you?"

His voice was tight with tension.

Jenna stood, a flicker of confusion in her eyes.

"How did you know I was the one handling him?"

Tristan pulled out his phone and waved it.

"Stella Laurent texted me."

He dropped heavily onto the couch and fished a cigarette from his pocket.

The flame from his lighter danced at his fingertips.

"What was Patrick thinking, sending you of all people?"

Smoke curled around his furrowed brows.

Jenna spoke softly.

"Everyone else was busy. I’d just finished with another client."

Tristan took a deep drag, his gaze sharp.

"Did he touch you?"

Jenna shook her head.

"No. He called me his little sister and ordered two bottles of Romanée-Conti."

Tristan’s fingers twitched, ash scattering on his pants.

"What?"

His head snapped up, disbelief flooding his expression.

Jenna nodded earnestly.

"It’s true."

Tristan stubbed out the cigarette, his voice low.

"Why would he..."

His fingers drummed absently on his knee.

"I don’t know why he ordered such expensive wine," Jenna murmured. "As for the sister thing, I just said some kind words."

Tristan studied her for a long moment.

"As long as you’re unharmed."

He stood, straightening his suit jacket.

"Next time, give me a heads-up."

Jenna nodded.

"Understood, sir."

At the door, Tristan turned back with a final warning.

"Remember—avoid him if you can."

When the door closed, Jenna exhaled deeply and sank back into the couch.
###Chapter 34

After Tristan Ashcroft left, Jenna Roland collapsed onto the couch, her body finally relaxing.

The $6,000 commission made her heart race.

The money had come too fast. At this rate, she'd soon have enough for Milo's surgery.

Too bad she couldn't tell her brother she worked at a club.

News traveled fast.

Within an hour, word of Jenna selling $26,000 worth of wine spread through Studio 54.

Her commission broke the club's record.

Envious glances mixed with jealousy.

A newcomer earning so much in just three days? Who wouldn't be bitter?

At closing time, coworkers clamored for her to treat them.

Jenna hesitated.

She'd risked everything for that money.

But to keep the peace, she reluctantly agreed to take them to a street food stall.

At 2 a.m., thirty people descended on the food street.

They picked a popular spot and took up four tables.

Four crates of beer and a feast of dishes were ordered.

Stella Laurent sidled up. "With this crowd, you're bleeding cash tonight."

Jenna kept her expression blank. "It's fine."

She couldn't back out now.

Or they'd call her stingy, making future work harder.

Sophia Merouin sat beside Tristan, eyeing Jenna meaningfully. "Never thought you'd charm Tony."

Chloe Blanchet cut in. "And he called her 'little sister.' How bizarre."

Patrick Klein feigned concern. "I was worried you couldn't handle it."

Jenna forced a smile. "Thanks for your concern."

"That's how this industry works. Gain more experience," Patrick said.

When the food arrived, toasts began.

Jenna held her liquor well, accepting every drink.

Tristan intervened. "Let her eat something."

With the boss speaking up, no one dared push further.

As Jenna picked up her chopsticks, her phone lit up.

Tony Lombardi's message appeared: Off work? We're having late-night snacks. Join us?
###Chapter 35

Jenna Roland's phone screen lit up. She quickly unlocked it to reply.

"Tony, don't trouble yourself. We're having dinner out with colleagues."

He responded instantly. "Where?"

"At a street food stall on Fifth Avenue."

The moment she sent the message, her phone vibrated.

Tony Lombardi had transferred $20,000.

Jenna stared at the number on the screen, her fingers trembling slightly.

"Tony, what’s this for?"

A new message popped up immediately. "Be generous when treating colleagues. Use this for dinner. If you ever need money, just ask. I’ve got plenty to spare!"

Warmth spread through her chest.

Just yesterday, she’d considered him dangerous.

Who would’ve thought this man she’d met by chance—who’d spent a fortune on drinks and genuinely treated her like a sister—would now send her such an enormous sum without hesitation?

Apart from Sean and Milo, no one had ever shown her this kind of care.

"Tony, money doesn’t grow on trees. Really, you don’t have to."

She quickly tapped "Refund."

Another notification chimed, accompanied by an angry emoji.

"You’re not treating me like family, huh? Older brothers are supposed to spoil their sisters! If you don’t take it, I’ll be pissed!"

Jenna sighed in resignation.

This man was determined to shower her with money.

"Then… thank you, Tony."

"No need for thanks! Enjoy your meal. We’ll talk later."

Putting her phone away, she rejoined her colleagues, clinking glasses and laughing.

The late-night feast lasted until 4 a.m.

When the bill came—over $2,000—Jenna swiped her card without flinching.

It was the most extravagant meal she’d ever paid for.

But since she’d offered to treat everyone, she wouldn’t complain.

Tristan Ashcroft lit a cigarette. "Where do you live? I’ll drive you."

Out of the corner of her eye, Jenna caught Sophia Merouin’s dark expression.

"No need." She refused firmly.

Tristan didn’t press further, driving off with Sophia.

Nathaniel Vance approached her. "Let me take you. It’s hard to get a cab this late."

Jenna nodded. "Thanks."

She slid into the passenger seat.
###Chapter 36

Neon lights flickered outside the club as night deepened.

Stella Laurent stood by the roadside in her high heels, waving at several taxis that ignored her. She turned toward a black sedan that had just started its engine. "Nathaniel, can I hitch a ride? You're heading my way, right?"

Nathaniel Vance rolled down the window and confirmed the address. Stella slid into the backseat, settling beside Jenna Roland.

As the car merged onto the main road, Nathaniel glanced at Jenna through the rearview mirror. "The boss offered to drive you home. Why didn't you take him up on it?"

Jenna kept her eyes on the blur of city lights outside. "Sophia looked ready to skin me alive."

"Damn right!" Stella crossed her legs. "That woman's possessive as hell. If you'd gotten in his car, she'd have made your life miserable tomorrow."

Jenna scoffed. "No point stirring up trouble."

Nathaniel turned the steering wheel. "You know about their... arrangement?"

"Heard rumors." Jenna tapped her fingers against the window frame.

Nathaniel lowered his voice. "Plenty of girls at the club have crushes on the boss, but none dare act on it. Last month, a new girl didn't get the memo. Sophia cornered her in the alley the next day—"

"Seven stitches in her skull." Stella mimed smashing a bottle.

Jenna arched an eyebrow. "That vicious?"

"Girl vanished after that." Stella shrugged. "So yeah, steer clear of those two."

Jenna narrowed her eyes. She wasn't one to back down from conflict, but she hadn't come to the club to get entangled in drama. Money was her only objective.

The car pulled up at Beverly Hills.

Jenna thanked them and stepped out, watching the taillights disappear. She eased the front door open, careful not to wake Milo if he was waiting up.

The living room lay in darkness. She fumbled for the wall switch. The sofa stood empty.

When she pushed her bedroom door open, her breath caught—

Ethan Roscente lay asleep in her bed.

A black suitcase leaned against the nightstand, its zipper half-open to reveal men's dress shirts. Jenna froze, her nails digging into her palms.

Was he actually moving in?

Moonlight at 5:30 AM filtered through the sheer curtains as she mechanically towel-dried her hair, catching her pale reflection in the bathroom mirror.

Clutching a thin blanket, she moved toward the living room couch like a sleepwalker.
###Chapter 37

At 6:30 in the morning, Milo Roland rubbed his sleepy eyes as he entered the living room.

Seeing Jenna Roland curled up asleep on the sofa, he walked past her toward the bathroom without a second thought.

The sound of running water filled the air as Milo finished washing up. He changed into his school uniform and headed to the kitchen.

Ethan Roscente appeared in the living room, adjusting his cufflinks. His gaze briefly swept over Jenna on the sofa before he strode toward the bathroom.

By the time a steaming bowl of plain noodle soup was placed on the table, Ethan had just finished drying his hair.

"Mr. Roscente, I made noodles," Milo said, handing him chopsticks with slightly nervous hands.

Ethan accepted them, his eyes dropping to the bowl in front of him.

Slender white noodles swam in amber broth, topped with vibrant green scallions and a fried egg with crisp golden edges.

The savory aroma lingered in the air.

He took a bite. The noodles had the perfect chew, and the broth was rich with umami.

Milo kept his head down, quietly slurping his noodles.

"Aren't you going to wake her?" Ethan's voice was icy.

Milo glanced at his sleeping sister. "She got home late from her night shift. Let her rest."

"Where does she work?" Ethan paused mid-bite.

"A 24-hour convenience store," Milo answered without hesitation.

A flicker of mockery crossed Ethan's eyes.

This woman didn't even blink when lying.

"High school sophomore?" Ethan abruptly changed the subject.

Milo's hand jerked, nearly dropping his noodles. "Y-yes."

Ethan set down his chopsticks and stood to leave.

Only after the front door closed did Milo finally exhale in relief.

His sister had said Ethan was a company executive, but his presence was more intimidating than their school principal.

As Milo cleared the table, he couldn't help stealing another glance at Jenna on the sofa.

How was his sister going to survive living with this man?

......

A shrill ringtone yanked Jenna from her dreams.

"Hello?" she mumbled, fumbling for her phone.

"Hey sis, I'm eating at a friend's place. Don't wait for me at lunch," Milo's voice came through the receiver.
###Chapter 38

"Got it."

Jenna hung up the phone and rubbed her sleepy eyes. She picked up her phone again and dialed Ethan's number.

The call connected almost immediately.

"Mr. Roscente, will you be back for lunch? Alright."

Next, she called Grandma Blanche, who was busy playing mahjong at the senior center and wouldn't be home for lunch.

After washing up, Jenna changed into loungewear and headed to the kitchen. If Ethan weren't coming back, she would've just made instant noodles. But now she had to prepare three dishes and a soup.

Ethan returned at half past noon.

"Lunch is ready. Please wash your hands first."

He responded with a cold hum, his gaze icy.

Every time she met those emotionless eyes, Jenna felt a chill run down her spine.

She served the rice and handed him the chopsticks only after he sat down. The dining table was eerily quiet, the clinking of utensils the only sound.

"You didn't tell your brother you work at a club?" Ethan suddenly spoke.

Jenna's head snapped up, her pulse quickening. "You told him?"

"No."

She exhaled in relief. If Milo found out she worked at such a place, he'd raise hell.

"I don't have that kind of free time." His tone dripped with disdain.

Jenna lowered her head and silently finished her rice.

"Mr. Roscente," she mustered the courage to speak, "can we sleep separately for now? I'm not ready."

"You want to sleep on the floor?" He blew out a smoke ring, looking down at her.

Jenna froze. So he'd already planned to make her sleep on the floor.

"Yes. I'll take the floor." Her reply was firm.

After a pause, she added cautiously, "I have work at night, so I might not be able to make dinner..."

Ethan stubbed out his cigarette. "Do whatever you want."

He walked away, his back cold and distant.
###Chapter 39

At 6:40 p.m., Jenna Roland hurried into Studio 54, her heels clicking against the pavement. The glass doors reflected her slightly weary figure.

The lounge was already packed. Stella Laurent shot her a pointed look, signaling she was late.

"Sorry, I took a nap this afternoon," Jenna murmured, shoving her bag into a locker.

Patrick Klein clapped his hands, calling everyone for the daily briefing. After the meeting, Jenna was scheduled as the last performer.

Sophia Merouin lounged beside her, crossing her legs. Her red nail polish gleamed garishly under the lights.

"Word is, you're quite popular with the clients lately," Sophia said, her voice dripping with envy.

Jenna kept her eyes on her phone. "Just trying to make a living."

Sophia's phone rang. When she hung up, her gaze turned sharp.

"Jenna," she hissed, leaning closer. "The boss keeps mentioning you."

Jenna finally looked up, a faint smirk playing on her lips. "And?"

"Stay away from him." Sophia gritted her teeth. "Don't think I don't know what you're up to."

Jenna scoffed and returned to her phone. She'd heard these empty warnings too many times.

Patrick pushed the door open. "Jenna, a client in Room 204 requested you."

"Who is it?"

"Said he's your brother," Patrick added. "Same guy as last time."

Jenna frowned. What was Sean Roland doing here again? And with friends?

The door to Room 204 was slightly ajar. Jenna took a deep breath and stepped inside.

The room was hazy with smoke. Sean sat in the center, flanked by two unfamiliar men puffing on cigarettes.

"You're here." Sean waved her over. "These are my colleagues, Cheng Feng and Zheng Haocheng."

Zheng Haocheng immediately stood and extended his hand. "I've heard so much about you."

Jenna gave a reluctant handshake, recoiling at the clammy sweat on his palm.

"Your sister's even prettier than in the photos," Cheng Feng whistled. "Sean, you've been hiding her well."

Sean smacked the back of his head. "Keep your thoughts clean."

"What would you like to drink?" Jenna cut in, ending their banter.

"Three cases of Budweiser," Sean said. "Don't go overboard."

Jenna nodded and slipped out. The hallway lights flickered as she rubbed her temples.

When she returned with the drinks, Sean was gone. Cheng Feng held her brother's phone, grinning oddly.

"Where's Sean?" Jenna set the tray down.

Cheng Feng waved the phone. "Taking a call." His eyes raked over her. "Hey, can I get your number?"

Jenna took a step back, her spine pressing against the cold wall.
###Chapter 40

Sean Roland slumped onto the couch with careless ease. As he took the phone, he asked casually, "Who is it?"

Kevin Heilbronn grinned. "Your brother. Asked where you were. I said we're drinking at Studio 54. Also mentioned Jenna works here."

Sean's expression darkened instantly.

Kevin's smile froze. "What? Was I not supposed to say that?"

Sean's eyes turned icy. "They're sworn enemies. What do you think will happen now?"

"Shit!" Kevin leapt to his feet. "Why didn't you tell me sooner?"

A vein throbbed at Sean's temple.

How was he supposed to know it was Jason calling?

Byron Valdemar looked worried. "What do we do now?"

Sean massaged his forehead. "What can we do?"

Kevin hesitated. "Should I... make up an excuse?"

"Is he coming?"

"Yeah."

Sean scoffed. "Too late."

The private room door swung open.

Jenna walked in carrying a tray of drinks, followed by a server.

The moment the drinks were set down, Sean pulled her aside.

When she heard what happened, her hands trembled.

A beer bottle crashed to the floor, shards scattering everywhere.

If Jason found out she worked at a place like this, he'd make sure the entire Roland family knew.

Sean's voice was low. "Don't work tonight."

Jenna smirked. "Avoiding tonight won't solve tomorrow."

Sean pulled out his phone. "I'll tell him not to come."

The call connected.

"Jason, Kevin was joking. Don't take it seriously."

"Bro, I'm bringing Heidi over. We'll be there soon."

The line went dead.

Jenna had already grabbed a broom to sweep up the glass.

"Don't worry," she said, lips curving. "If he causes trouble, I'll have security throw him out."
###Chapter 41

Jenna Roland had only discovered last night that Tristan Ashcroft secretly maintained a team of bodyguards.

These bodyguards specialized in maintaining order at Studio 54, preventing any disturbances.

If Jason Roland dared to cause trouble, Tristan would deal with him before Jenna even had to speak.

Sean Roland nodded, gesturing for Jenna to sit and join the drinks.

She shook her head. "A guest has arrived. I need to attend to them."

"Go ahead." Sean didn’t press further.

Jenna hurried toward VIP Room 888.

She knocked lightly before entering.

Five impeccably dressed men sat inside, each exuding an air of sophistication.

Standing in the center, Jenna gave a slight bow. "Good evening. I'm Jenna Roland. It's my pleasure to serve you."

Oliver Macmillan, clad in a gray suit, looked her over. "Where's your boss?"

"He's occupied at the moment. Shall I notify him for you?"

Oliver crossed his legs. "Tell Ashcroft an old friend is here."

"Of course. One moment, please." Jenna excused herself.

Downstairs, she found Supervisor Patrick Klein and inquired about Tristan’s whereabouts.

"Who's asking?" Patrick questioned.

"The guest in Room 888. He claims to be the boss's friend."

"Just call him directly," Patrick suggested.

Jenna dialed Tristan’s number and briefly explained the situation.

"I'll be right there," came Tristan’s reply.

She returned to wait outside Room 888.

Soon, Tristan arrived in haste.

They entered the room together.

Oliver smirked. "Busy man. Hard to get an audience with you."

Tristan took a seat beside him. "Apologies. I was entertaining some associates."

Julian Richter interjected, "Macmillan insisted on seeing you. We couldn’t stop him."

"Had I known you were coming, I wouldn’t have wasted time with Wang Hai," Tristan said regretfully.

Oliver waved it off. "What’s good here?"

Tristan glanced at Jenna. "Show us what you've got."

She stepped forward and began fluently presenting the club’s beverage menu.
###Chapter 42

Oliver Macmillan tapped his fingers lightly on the table, scanning the wine list. "Four bottles of Royal Salute."

"Right away, sir." Jenna Roland gave a slight bow, the hem of her dress swaying gracefully as she turned.

Oliver slung an arm around Tristan Ashcroft's shoulder, a playful glint in his eyes. "Your hiring standards have improved."

Tristan swirled the amber liquid in his glass. "Meaning?"

Brian Durrant whistled. "He's saying you finally hired someone decent. Unlike those last few disasters who couldn't even sell water in a desert."

"Then why not order Romanée-Conti?" Tristan raised an eyebrow.

Oliver sighed. "The old man's been auditing my accounts. Allowance cut in half." He leaned in, lowering his voice. "Heard Tony Lombardi dropped fifty grand here last night?"

Julian Richter snapped his lighter shut. "That gangster?"

Tristan smirked. "Jenna sweet-talked him into calling her 'little sister' and made him open two bottles of Romanée-Conti." He tapped his temple. "That girl's got skills."

Oliver let out an appreciative whistle. "With that face and that body in that uniform..."

"Don't even think about it." Tristan's tone turned serious. "She's under Ethan Roscente's protection."

The room went dead silent.

Brian nearly dropped his glass. "Ethan Roscente? The 'Grim Reaper' of HM Group?"

Oliver swallowed hard. "The same guy who bankrupted a rival during the financial summit?"

Tristan tilted his phone, displaying a stark black-and-white message from this morning: Jenna is mine.

Julian suddenly chuckled. "Interesting. Since when does the second son of the Roscente family go for this type?"

Outside, neon lights flickered as Jenna carried a tray of drinks down the hallway. The crystal chandelier cast shimmering reflections on her collarbone, like a gilded bird in an ornate cage.
###Chapter 43

Oliver narrowed his eyes, fingers tapping rhythmically on the table. "Tristan, you're not joking with us, are you? Someone of Ethan Roscente's status getting involved with Jenna Roland?"

Julian and Zane exchanged skeptical glances.

Tristan exhaled a smoke ring, his smile cryptic through the haze. "Why would I lie? Brian, don't you know Gavin? Just call and verify."

Brian remained motionless, absently tracing the rim of his wine glass.

"If Jenna truly knows Ethan," Brian said suddenly, "haven't you considered leveraging that connection?"

Tristan sighed. "The Hudson Yards tender is coming up. My father's company is bidding, but the competition is brutal. I wanted Jenna to put in a good word..."

"Hudson Yards?" Brian's eyebrow arched. "That's prime real estate. Dozens of firms are fighting for it."

"Exactly." Tristan stubbed out his cigarette. "Without insider connections, it's impossible."

The private room door swung open.

Jenna entered carrying a tray of drinks, followed by two servers.

She expertly uncorked bottles and poured with practiced efficiency.

"So you know Ethan Roscente?" Brian's abrupt question made her hands falter.

Jenna's gaze flickered to Tristan before quickly lowering. "We're acquainted. Nothing more."

Her detached tone when mentioning Ethan drew knowing looks from the men.

"Leave after serving." Tristan dismissed her with a wave.

Jenna nodded and exited—only to freeze in the hallway.

Jason and Heidi stood nearby, sneering at her.

"I knew big brother was lying!" Heidi crowed. "This little bitch really works at a place like this!"

Jason eyed Jenna's uniform with contempt. "Dressed like this? How are you any different from those escort girls? If your parents knew—"

"I'm just a server!" Jenna's grip whitened around the tray.

"A server?" Jason laughed mockingly. "In that outfit?"

Stella emerged from the adjacent room, her face darkening at the insult.

She glanced down at her identical uniform, fury flashing in her eyes.
###Chapter 44

Stella Laurent clicked across the floor in her stilettos and positioned herself protectively in front of Jenna Roland.

Her red-lacquered nails pointed inches from Jason Roland's face. "Who the hell do you think you are? This is my turf."

Jason's face darkened, veins bulging at his temples. "You bitch looking for trouble?"

Stella smirked, crimson lips curling in contempt. "Go ahead. Take your best shot."

Jenna's eyes glistened with unshed tears, voice trembling. "Jason, get out!"

"Like hell I will!" Jason kicked over a decorative vase near the hallway.

Ethan Roscente emerged from the restroom just as the commotion started. He immediately doubled back to fetch Sean Roland.

When Sean arrived, Jason was screaming obscenities at Jenna.

Sean stepped between them, voice dangerously calm. "Enough. You're embarrassing yourself."

Jason gaped. "You're defending this slut? After what she did to our family?"

"Shut your mouth." Sean's voice cracked like a whip. "One more word and I'll handle you myself."

The club's pounding bass nearly drowned out the altercation until a neighboring VIP suite door swung open.

Tristan Ashcroft stepped out, phone in hand, scanning the scene with icy precision.

Stella seized the opportunity. "Boss, these two are causing problems."

Jason spat on the floor. "Big man with his little threats."

Tristan's expression hardened. He tapped his phone once.

Within sixty seconds, four hulking bodyguards blocked the corridor.

Heidi Roland cowered behind Jason.

"Throw them out." Tristan's voice could freeze lava. "Next time, break their legs."

Jason glared at Jenna. "This isn't over."

The bodyguards hauled them away like ragdolls.

Sean approached Tristan. "Mr. Ashcroft, my apologies—"

"Try that again," Tristan interrupted, "and you'll join them."

Sean pressed his lips together and gave a curt nod.
###Chapter 45

Tristan Ashcroft's gaze turned icy as he stared at Jenna Roland. His slender fingers tapped rhythmically against the desk, producing a dull thud.

"Why didn't you inform me immediately when trouble arose?"

If not for Stella Laurent's message, he wouldn't have known someone dared to cause a scene in his territory.

Jenna bit her lower lip, her fingers unconsciously twisting the hem of her blouse.

"Boss, I thought I could handle it myself. I didn't expect them to be so persistent... I'm sorry for the inconvenience."

Tristan stood, looking down at her with an unreadable expression.

"Inconvenience? My primary concern is the safety of our guests—and yours."

A cold sweat formed on his back. This was Ethan Roscente's wife. If anything happened to her here, the consequences would be disastrous.

Jenna bowed deeply. "I sincerely apologize."

"Go." Tristan waved dismissively. "Take your brother back to the private room. Don't disturb the other guests."

Nodding, Jenna quickly pulled Sean Roland away.

The moment the door closed behind them, Jenna's face paled. She leaned against the door, her chest heaving.

"Big brother... he knows. He'll spread rumors everywhere."

Her voice trembled as her fingers clenched the fabric of her clothes.

Sean frowned. "Maybe you should quit? Once gossip like this starts circulating—"

"No!" Jenna's head snapped up. "Milo's surgery still needs over a million. There are follow-up treatments too. If I quit now..."

Her voice cracked, eyes glistening with unshed tears.

Sean raked a hand through his hair in frustration. The money in his account wasn't even enough to cover a fraction.

"Quit first. We'll figure out the money somehow."

Jenna shook her head, tears threatening to spill.

"We can't wait... The doctor said Milo's condition can't be delayed any longer."

Didn't she know this job would invite malicious gossip? But for her brother's sake, she had no other choice.

Sean exhaled heavily. 1.3 million—an astronomical sum for people like them.

"Maybe we could—"

Before he could finish, a sharp knock sounded at the door.
###Chapter 46

"You should go stop Jason first." Jenna paused, then shook her head. "Never mind. Let him be. I'll keep working here until Milo finds out."

She cared about nothing except her younger brother Milo.

As long as Milo remained unaware, everything was manageable.

Sean frowned. "You really don't care about their gossip?"

Jenna gave a bitter smile. "Big brother, when Milo and I were desperate, which one of them lifted a finger? Their opinions mean nothing to me now."

"If that's how you feel..." Sean picked up his coat. "I'll go check on things. I'll explain if needed."

"Don't bother." Her eyes turned icy. "Let them talk."

"You're my sister. I protect my family." Sean turned to Tristan and the others. "Continue without me. We'll meet another time."

Without waiting for a response, he strode out of the private room.

Tristan looked guilty. "Jenna, I'm sorry. I didn't know you—"

"What's done is done." She cut him off. "No point hiding it now. Enjoy yourselves. I have work to do."

Sophia nodded silently, watching Jenna leave before raising her glass again.

......

In the Roland family living room, Jason was dramatically recounting Jenna's "escort work" at the club.

Sean entered with a dark expression. "She sells drinks. That's not the same as being an escort."

Jason sneered and turned to Victor. "Dad, look! Big brother's still defending that bitch!"

"Shut your mouth!" Sean's eyes flashed dangerously. "After all these years of her slaving for you, this is how you repay her?"

Victor slammed the table. "You insolent brat! Who's your real brother? Taking an outsider's side—have you no shame?"

"Outsider?" Sean laughed coldly. "Dad, whose orchard is it? Whose pockets have been lined with its profits? Jenna cooks, cleans, pays rent and living expenses here. Where's your conscience?"

Victor's face turned purple with rage. Fiona looked ashen.

"Her father was your own brother!" Sean's words struck like daggers. "She shares our blood and name. Call her an outsider again—see if you can face our ancestors in the afterlife."

"You ungrateful wretch!" Victor hurled a teacup at him. "Keep defending that slut, and you can get out too!"
###Chapter 47

Sean clenched his fists until his knuckles turned white.

He never imagined his own family could be so despicable.

Fiona shrieked, "Sean, we're your blood relatives! How dare you take their side over ours?"

Jason sneered, "Having a brother like you is downright embarrassing."

Sean's chest heaved with barely contained rage.

His icy gaze swept over them as he growled, "What you did to Jenna will come back to haunt you."

Without another word, he turned on his heel and left.

Victor chased him to the doorway, bellowing, "Ungrateful wretch! Don't you dare come back!"

The elevator doors closed just as Sean's eyes finally reddened.

Back in the living room, Victor slammed the door violently.

"That traitor! Defending that little slut!"

Heidi chimed in with false concern, "If word gets out about Jenna working as an escort at Studio 54, we'll be the laughingstock of Los Angeles."

Fiona's eyes gleamed with greed. "Those places must pay well, right?"

Jason scoffed. "High-end clubs like that? Thousands per night, easy."

"Disgusting!" Victor spat. "I wouldn't touch that dirty money!"

Fiona lowered her voice. "That sickly Milo won't last much longer. Maybe we could..."

Heidi caught on immediately. "If we control Milo, Jenna will have to pay up."

Jason suddenly pounded the table. "I've got it!"

He whipped out his phone. "We'll demand $40,000 hush money, or we'll expose her escort gig!"

The moment he hit send, a red exclamation mark appeared.

"Damn it!" Jason exploded. "That bitch blocked me!"

Heidi's face darkened. "What just happened?"
###Chapter 48

Fiona Roland gnashed her teeth while scrolling through her phone. "She must have deleted me the day she moved out."

Jason Roland's face darkened. "Mom, Heidi, check if she's blocked you too."

They frantically pulled out their phones.

The results were shocking—not only were Fiona and Heidi deleted, but Victor Roland's WeChat had also been blocked by Jenna!

"That ungrateful wretch!" Victor slammed the table. "After all these years raising her, she treats us like this? Even a dog would show more loyalty!"

Heidi looked grim. "Since WeChat's gone, we'll have to call."

Jason immediately dialed Jenna's number.

A cold automated voice responded: "The number you have dialed is currently unavailable..."

Four attempts yielded the same result.

"Bitch!" Jason snarled, hanging up. "She blocked my number!"

Fiona and Heidi tried calling too—same automated message.

Clearly, Jenna had blacklisted the entire family.

"That little snake has nerve!" Fiona stomped her foot in fury.

Heidi suddenly remembered something. "Wait, I have a new number."

She quickly dialed Jenna using the fresh line.

This time, it connected.

"Hello, this is Jenna Roland," came the familiar voice.

Heidi shoved the phone at Jason.

"It's me," Jason said icily.

Jenna, working at Studio 54, instantly tensed at his voice.

"What do you want?" Her tone was frigid.

"We know you're working as an escort at that club," Jason threatened. "Transfer $4,000 immediately unless you want Milo to find out. Or should I expose your dirty little secret to everyone?"

Jenna took a sharp breath. "It's too loud here. I'll call you back."

She hung up and hurried to find Stella Laurent.

"Let me borrow your phone," she said urgently.

Stella frowned but handed it over. "What's wrong?"

"Open WeChat, quick." Jenna pressed.

Though confused, Stella unlocked her device.
###Chapter 49

Jenna Roland scrolled through Stella Laurent's WeChat moments before dialing Jason Roland's number.

He answered instantly.

"It was too noisy earlier. If you're feeling generous, repeat what you said."

"I said everyone knows you work as an escort at Studio 54! Transfer me $4,000 right now, or I'll make sure Milo finds out and the whole world points fingers at you!"

Jason's voice dripped with malice.

Jenna tightened her grip on the phone, suppressing her fury.

"So you're threatening to spread lies about me working at a club unless I pay you?"

She enunciated every word.

"Lies? You are an escort! Stop pretending to be innocent!"

"I'm a licensed beverage promoter. What you're doing is extortion and defamation. Know the law?"

"Bullshit! Who's extorting you?"

"Your entire demand just now constitutes both crimes. I recorded it. Want to hear?"

Jason choked on his water.

"You bitch, say that again!"

"Listen carefully."

The playback of his exact words echoed through the line.

He hurled his phone across the room.

"Mom! That bitch recorded me! She's accusing me of extortion!"

Fiona Roland frantically searched the legal penalties on her phone.

The results drained the color from her face.

Extortion over $3,000 carried a 3-10 year sentence plus fines.

Heidi Roland shrieked, "That sly little witch set us up!"

Jason paced like a caged animal. "What do we do now?"

Victor Roland's expression darkened. "Leak her escort rumors anyway."

"But she called it defamation..."

Heidi scoffed. "What's the worst that could happen?"

Fiona checked defamation laws.

Malicious false accusations meant detention and fines.

"We get no money and no revenge!"

She smashed her phone against the wall.

......

Studio 54 lounge.
###Chapter 50

Stella Laurent's eyes widened as she listened to Jenna Roland's plan. "This is brilliant! You've got them completely trapped!"

Jenna backed up the voice recording and handed the phone back to Stella. "Don't celebrate yet. Those people would do anything for money."

She knew her relatives too well—they'd sell their dignity for a quick buck.

The most important thing now was keeping Milo in the dark.

Patrick Klein pushed the door open. "Jenna, the guest in VIP 309 requested you specifically."

"Regular?" Jenna asked casually.

"New face." Patrick wiped his brow. "Everyone else is busy, so you're our only option."

"Got it." Jenna adjusted her collar and headed straight for the private room.

Patrick turned to Stella. "Heard someone came looking for trouble with Jenna?"

Stella nodded. "Her cousin and his wife. Security kicked them out."

Patrick hummed thoughtfully before walking away.

——

At 3:30 AM, Jenna dragged her exhausted body home.

The living room was empty—Milo must already be asleep in his room.

She pushed open her bedroom door to find Ethan Roscente sprawled across her bed again.

Great. Another night on the floor.

After washing up, Jenna pulled spare bedding from the closet and collapsed onto the makeshift bed.

——

The next morning, Ethan opened his eyes to see Jenna curled up on the floor.

At least she knew her place.

He freshened up, changed clothes, and headed for the door.

Milo intercepted him in the living room with a bowl of plain noodle soup. "Mr. Roscente, I made breakfast—"

"No." Ethan brushed past without a backward glance.

The slam of the front door made Milo's stomach twist.

Had Jenna upset him again? Yesterday he'd eaten the noodles she cooked—why the sudden cold shoulder?

Whatever. More for him.

Milo polished off two bowls until his stomach protested.

After cleaning the kitchen, he started a pot of soup for Jenna.

As he grabbed his backpack for school, his phone buzzed with an unknown number.

The text froze him in place:

"Your sister works as an escort at Studio 54. See for yourself."

His trembling fingers dialed the number—disconnected.

Legs wobbling, he stared at the master bedroom door.

But Jenna said she worked night shifts at the convenience store...
###Chapter 51

Milo Roland had always believed his sister worked night shifts at a convenience store.

Until today.

He stood before the gilded entrance of "Studio 54," watching Jenna walk through the revolving doors in a revealing uniform. Neon lights flickered behind her, illuminating her exhausted face forced into a practiced smile.

His heart twisted violently.

Clutching his chest, he staggered back. The congenital heart disease made it hard to breathe, his vision darkening at the edges.

She was doing this for him.

For his expensive medications. For his monthly checkups. She had sacrificed her dignity, stepping into this world of decadence.

"It's all my fault..."

The teenage boy collapsed onto a nearby bench, tears blurring his sight. His uncle's venomous words echoed in his mind: "You're nothing but a burden!"

His phone buzzed.

A message from Jenna: "Milo, coming home for dinner?"

With trembling fingers, he replied: "No, sis. Eating at a friend's place."

After sending it, he wiped his tears and headed toward the distant bus stop.

Jenna Roland woke to sunlight streaming through the windows.

The rice cooker in the kitchen glowed with its "keep warm" light, the aroma of steamed rice filling the air. She massaged her aching lower back—last night's escort shift had ended at 3 AM, leaving her body feeling shattered.

Her phone screen lit up.

"Mr. Roscente, will you be home for lunch?" She hesitated before sending the text.

No immediate reply.

Jenna began preparing lunch. The crisp sound of chopping greens filled the kitchen, but her mind drifted back to last night's greasy client.

Ding—

Ethan's delayed response arrived: "Yes."

A single word, just like their marriage.

At exactly noon, the front door unlocked. Jenna was stir-frying the final dish when she glanced over her shoulder.

Ethan stood in the foyer, impeccably dressed in his tailored suit, his sharp features unreadable.

"Almost done," she said softly.

They ate in silence across from each other. Jenna pushed the rice bowl toward him. Ethan accepted it with refined movements, beginning his meal without a word.

The unnatural calm lasted ten minutes.

"Does the house need anything else?" Ethan suddenly asked.

Her chopsticks stilled. "Everything's taken care of."

"Your clothes?" His dark eyes lifted, fathomless.

Her grip tightened on the chopsticks, nails digging into her palms.

This marriage was transactional. He needed a wife to appease his family. She needed money for Milo's treatment. Nothing more.

"I have enough," Jenna murmured, avoiding his gaze.

Ethan's attention lingered on her frayed collar for a fleeting second before he resumed eating.

Silence reclaimed the dining room.

Only the occasional clink of chopsticks against porcelain reminded them of this hollow union.
###Chapter 52

Jenna declined Ethan's offer.

"Mr. Roscente, I have enough clothes. Please don't waste your money."

Ethan's gaze swept over the sparse contents of her closet. The faded fabrics looked worse than rags in his eyes.

On the shoe rack, a pair of worn cloth shoes had frayed edges. The only pair of leather shoes had peeling patches of lacquer.

He couldn't comprehend how anyone could live so frugally in this day and age.

"Though this is a marriage of convenience, I won't neglect my obligations."

Jenna lowered her lashes, fingers unconsciously twisting the hem of her shirt.

"Mr. Roscente, I truly want nothing from this marriage. I didn't deceive Grandma Blanche."

A flicker of mockery passed through Ethan's eyes. If she hadn't schemed somehow, why would the old woman force him to marry a complete stranger?

"Hmph."

That cold scoff made Jenna's heart clench. She suddenly realized explanations would only deepen the misunderstanding.

Silently, she gathered the dishes and retreated to the kitchen.

When she emerged, the living room stood empty.

After a two-hour nap, Jenna left with a shopping bag.

She chose the cheaper farmers' market. Every penny saved meant another reference book for Milo.

Her phone rang abruptly.

"Grandma?"

"Dear, your grandfather and I are coming for lunch tomorrow."

Jenna's lips curved unconsciously. "Of course. What does Grandpa like?"

"The old man loves cola chicken wings and braised pork knuckles. Just make sure they're tender—his teeth aren't what they used to be."

Hanging up, Jenna felt surprised. She hadn't expected Grandpa Harrison's tastes to match Milo's so closely.

At the fresh produce stall, she meticulously selected the plumpest chicken wings.

After a hurried dinner, Jenna rushed to Studio 54.

The moment she entered, her phone rang again.

Caller ID: Lily Evans.

"Hello, Lily?"
###Chapter 53

"Jenna, why isn't Milo in class today?" Lily Evans' voice carried clear confusion through the phone.

Jenna Roland halted mid-step, her brows knitting together. "That's impossible. He never skips school."

"The homeroom teacher asked me to check with you. He's definitely absent." Lily's tone left no room for doubt.

Jenna ended the call abruptly and dialed her brother's number.

"The number you have dialed is currently switched off—" The robotic female voice made her pulse spike.

Her fingers turned icy as she called several of Milo's classmates in rapid succession.

"Haven't seen Milo."
"He didn't come to school today."
"Nobody's seen him since morning."

Each response landed like a hammer blow. Standing outside Studio 54, Jenna's grip on the phone trembled slightly.

When she dialed the last number, she barely dared to breathe.

"Hello?" The call connected instantly.

"Ryan, this is Milo's sister. Have you seen him today?"

"Oh, Jenna!" Ryan Watson's voice sounded weak. "Sorry, I'm running a fever. Milo's been taking care of me..."

Jenna exhaled sharply, the tension draining from her shoulders.

"Put him on."

A familiar voice came through moments later: "Sis."

"Do you have any idea how worried I was?" Jenna's voice shook. "Everyone said you'd vanished. I thought—"

"Ryan's family wasn't home, and his charger broke," Milo explained. "I'm sorry for scaring you."

"Next time, you call me first!" Jenna scolded sternly. "Come home early."

Only after hanging up did she notice her damp blouse clinging to her back.

"Trouble?" Stella Laurent approached, taking in Jenna's pale complexion.

Jenna gave a brief explanation.

"Honestly," Stella shook her head, "Milo's the most responsible kid I know. Stop imagining worst-case scenarios."

"But he never turns off his phone..." Jenna muttered defensively.

"Enough. Go change." Stella tugged her toward the staff area. "We've got that tedious staff meeting tonight."

In the locker room, Jenna mechanically changed into her uniform. By seven, when the meeting ended and guests began arriving, her heartbeat had finally steadied.
###Chapter 54

The night deepened as the clock struck eight.

Jenna Roland had just bid farewell to her last customer. She descended the stairs in her high heels to fetch more wine.

When she spotted the figure by the bar, her entire body froze as if struck by lightning.

Her phone slipped from her fingers, clattering loudly against the marble floor.

Stella Laurent rushed over at the noise. Following Jenna's gaze, she gasped. "Holy shit!"

"Milo?" Her eyes widened. "What are you doing here?"

The teenager's fists clenched, veins bulging. Shock and anguish swirled in his eyes.

That morning, he'd left with nothing but guilt weighing on him—the belief that he'd burdened his sister.

A classmate's call had interrupted his suicidal thoughts.

He'd spent the entire day at his friend's house, desperately convincing himself that text message was fake.

Yet an unshakable unease had driven him to the club for answers.

The sight before him shattered all his illusions.

Milo turned and bolted into the night.

"Milo!" Jenna abandoned her phone, hiking up her dress as she chased after him.

Patrick Klein approached with a frown. "What's going on?"

"That's her brother." Stella stomped her foot in frustration. "All our secrecy for nothing!"

"Her brother?" Patrick's expression darkened.

Stella was already pulling out her phone. "We need to call the boss."

Jenna caught her brother's sleeve at the alley entrance.

"Let me explain." Her voice trembled.

Milo shook her off, his eyes bloodshot. "A convenience store? You lied to me!"

"What text?" Jenna froze.

"Doesn't matter!" His voice cracked. "I'd rather die than have you sell yourself for money!"

Their parents' dying words echoed in his ears.

Jenna raised three fingers in desperation. "I only sell drinks! May lightning strike me if I'm lying!"

"Sis..." Tears splashed onto the pavement.

As he tried to leave again, a figure blocked his path.

Tristan Ashcroft had appeared silently at the alley's mouth.

"Boss." Jenna hung her head in shame.

"It's fine." Tristan studied the boy. "You're Jenna's brother?"

At Milo's stiff nod, he extended a hand. "Tristan Ashcroft. Owner of Studio 54."

Milo hesitated before shaking it.

"Let's talk inside." Tristan stepped aside. "This isn't the place."

Jenna watched her brother's expression nervously.

After a long silence, Milo finally took a step forward.
###Chapter 55

Tristan Ashcroft led the Roland siblings to VIP room 308 on the third floor. The space instantly brightened as the lights flickered on.

He strode to the sofa and sat down, gesturing to the empty seats beside him. "Make yourselves comfortable."

Milo and Jenna exchanged glances before cautiously taking their seats.

Milo clenched his fists, his Adam's apple bobbing several times before he spoke. "My sister..." His voice trailed off, face twisting with discomfort.

Tristan crossed his legs, leaning back lazily against the cushions. His clear gaze locked onto Milo's. "Studio 54 employs professional escorts, but your sister is a beverage promoter." He pointed to Jenna's uniform. "This is her work attire. Decent people see it for what it is—just clothing."

When Milo's frown remained, Tristan added, "If anyone harasses her, they'll answer to me. That goes for all my employees. Every dollar she earns here is clean."

"Are you just covering for her?" Milo's voice tightened with suspicion. He couldn't shake the thought that Tristan's defense stemmed from Jenna's profitability.

Tristan chuckled suddenly. He patted Milo's shoulder. "Your sister is excellent at sales. She just moved two bottles worth over half a million. Any boss would value such an employee, wouldn't you agree?"

Milo pressed his lips together silently.

"Mind if I smoke?" Tristan produced a cigarette case. At Milo's tacit consent, he lit up and exhaled slowly, eyes narrowing through the haze. "Every employer appreciates profitable staff. But your sister's sharp—she never takes unnecessary risks. You'd know that better than anyone."

Milo's shoulders relaxed slightly as he recalled Jenna brandishing a kitchen knife during their uncle's confrontation.

"So she's really not... one of those girls?" Doubt still lingered in Milo's eyes.

Tristan tapped ash into a tray before proposing, "How about this? Work as a temp server tonight and observe her job firsthand."

Jenna's eyes widened abruptly, her handbag nearly slipping from her grasp.
###Chapter 56 

Jenna's fingertips trembled slightly.

She wasn't afraid of gossip, but the thought of those lecherous stares and vulgar remarks made her chest tighten.

What worried her more was Milo's reaction. Though those men wouldn't dare touch her, their eyes felt like slimy snake tongues crawling over her skin.

If her brother witnessed this, even if he believed she was just selling drinks, he'd never let her stay in a place like this.

"Is Stella also a beverage promoter?" Milo suddenly asked, his gaze landing on Stella's identical uniform.

Jenna nodded. "Yes, we're in the same team."

Tristan blew a smoke ring, smirking. "Our escort girls wear much less than your sister. Want to take a look?"

"Boss!" Jenna glared at him. "My brother's still a student."

"The school uniform gives it away." Tristan flicked his cigarette ash, his eyes darting between the siblings.

Milo tightened his grip on his backpack strap. "Sis, this place is too shady."

"I understand your concern." Jenna softened her tone. "But the boss is always here, and there are bouncers keeping order. No one would dare misbehave."

"You're really planning to keep working here?" Milo's voice strained.

Jenna's eyes lit up. "The commission is high. Last time with those two bottles of fifty-thousand-dollar wine, I made over five grand." She counted on her fingers. "At this rate, I'll save up enough soon."

"Five thousand?" Milo gasped. That amount equaled half a year's salary for most people.

Tristan interjected, "A hundred grand is nothing. If she puts in effort, she could earn that in two months." He added meaningfully, "Not everyone can get Mr. Roscente and Tony to foot the bill."

Milo's expression darkened. "But what about your reputation? The relatives' gossip alone could drown you."

He thought of their uncle's family's sneering faces, his throat tightening with bitterness. They already looked down on them. If they found out Jenna worked here, who knew what vile things they'd say?
###Chapter 57

"Milo, do you remember how Uncle Victor treated us after Mom and Dad passed away?" Jenna Roland grasped her younger brother's hand, her voice barely above a whisper.

Milo lowered his head, fingers unconsciously twisting the hem of his shirt.

"The other relatives are even worse." Jenna gave a bitter smile. "Not kicking us while we're down is the best we can hope for."

She took a deep breath and met his eyes. "We can only rely on ourselves now. Money is everything—especially for your surgery."

Milo's lashes trembled.

"I don't have the education for a high-paying job." Jenna's tone remained steady. "But you... your future is still ahead of you."

His head jerked up, eyes red-rimmed. "Jenna—"

"I'm your sister." She cut him off, firm. "Your health is all that matters to me."

She wiped the tear from his cheek. "Remember—staying alive is the only thing that counts."

Milo suddenly threw himself into her arms, voice breaking. "I'm sorry... I've been so selfish..."

Jenna gently patted his back.

Then he abruptly pulled away and dropped to his knees before Tristan Ashcroft.

"What are you doing?" Tristan scrambled to his feet.

"Mr. Ashcroft." Milo's voice shook. "Please... protect my sister."

Tristan yanked him upright. "A man's pride is worth more than gold!"

"My parents are gone..." Milo whispered, barely audible.

Tristan studied the siblings with conflicted eyes.

"Where are you living now?" he asked.

Jenna answered first. "A rental."

Tristan frowned. "But you're married."

"Complications..." She evaded.

Milo shot her a puzzled glance.

"Call me anytime." Tristan's promise carried weight. "I'll keep an eye on her."

Milo bowed deeply.

After Tristan left, Jenna held out her hand. "Let me see that text."

"My phone died." Milo hesitated. "Why didn't you tell him we're staying at Ethan's?"

"Private matters." Her tone was flat.

He nodded. "Promise me you'll quit the club in two months."

"Deal." No hesitation.

"Does Ethan know you work at Studio 54?"

"He does." A humorless smile twisted her lips. "He even brought clients there."
###Chapter 58

"What?" Milo Roland's eyes widened in disbelief as he stared at his sister. "Mr. Roscente knows you work here? And he didn't object?"

Jenna lowered her lashes, her fingers absently tracing the hem of her uniform.

Her marriage to Ethan was nothing but a transaction.

To put it bluntly, they had a contractual arrangement that served their respective needs. He didn't truly care about her—why would he bother with such details?

But Ethan's opinion didn't matter. As long as Milo was okay with it, that was enough.

"He knows I'm just a server, not an escort," Jenna explained softly. "No job is beneath dignity as long as it's honest work."

"I can't believe he's actually been here," Milo mused.

"Exactly. If I were doing that kind of work, he would've divorced me long ago," Jenna quipped lightly.

Milo nodded. "Sis, I don't have classes tomorrow. I'll wait here tonight so we can go home together."

He wanted to see her workplace and make sure no one was mistreating her.

"Alright."

As long as he didn't witness her working, she didn't mind.

"I should get back. If they catch me slacking off again, I'll get scolded." Jenna stood up.

Milo followed her downstairs and was directed to the staff lounge to wait.

Sophia Merouin walked past carrying a tray of drinks. Spotting the teenager in school uniform, she stopped Patrick Klein.

"Who's that?"

"Jenna's younger brother."

Sophia arched a brow. "Her real brother?"

"Of course." Patrick hurried away.

With a dismissive sniff, Sophia dropped the subject. She'd never liked Jenna anyway.

Milo charged his phone for thirty minutes until it reached 40%.

After another half hour, the battery was full.

As he returned the charger, a tall figure strode through the club's entrance.

Milo froze.

Though his sister had mentioned it, seeing it firsthand still shocked him.

Ethan Roscente stood there in an immaculate suit, followed by Gavin Valentine and two other men.

He stopped before Milo, frowning slightly. "What are you doing here?"

Gavin eyed the teenager curiously. "And this is...?"
###Chapter 59

Milo Roland never expected to run into Ethan Roscente here.

He quickly composed himself and spoke respectfully, "Mr. Roscente, I'm here to see my sister."

Ethan frowned slightly, a flicker of confusion in his eyes.

He had assumed Jenna kept her job at this club a secret from her family. Working at such a place wasn't exactly something to boast about.

Yet here was Milo.

Had she already come clean to them?

Gavin Valentine, noticing Ethan's silence, interjected curiously, "You two know each other?"

Milo's gaze shifted between them. "My sister introduced us, but we're not close."

"I see." Gavin nodded thoughtfully.

Ethan's cold stare fixed on Milo. "This isn't the place for you. Go home."

"I'm waiting for my sister to finish her shift." Milo stood his ground. "Don't mind me, Mr. Roscente."

Without another word, Ethan turned and led Gavin's group upstairs.

Milo watched them leave before heading toward the staff lounge.

Jenna had just finished delivering drinks and was about to look for Milo when Patrick Klein and Stella Laurent stopped her.

"Done for the night?" Patrick asked.

Jenna nodded. "Just finished."

"VIP 999 requested you specifically." Patrick gestured upstairs. "Don't keep them waiting."

"Who is it?" Jenna frowned.

Stella smirked. "Big client. Better hurry."

Without further questions, Jenna made her way to VIP 999.

The moment she pushed the door open, she froze.

Ethan and Gavin sat on the sofa.

Weren't they just here a few days ago?

This young master really had a thing for nightclubs.

Grandma Blanche always said her grandson was just reserved but had good character. What kind of respectable person frequented places like this?

Even if he only came to drink, it still didn't reflect well on him.

Gavin waved her over. "Why is your brother here?"

Jenna's pulse jumped. "You saw Milo?"

"He said he's waiting to walk you home." Gavin gave her a meaningful look. "He knows you work here?"

Jenna met his gaze steadily. "I earn my living honestly. Is there a problem?"

The blunt response left Gavin momentarily speechless.
###Chapter 60

"Fine." Gavin didn't press further.

The private room was dimly lit. Miles leaned closer to Ethan and whispered, "I heard this place has escort girls?"

It was his first time at Studio 54, and he wasn't familiar with the rules.

Jenna was about to respond when Ethan's icy gaze cut through the air. "What? Can't drink without company?"

Miles stiffened, forcing an awkward chuckle. "Just making sure we're properly entertained."

Gavin scoffed. "We never involve outsiders when drinking."

"Forget it then." Miles turned to Jenna. "What premium wines do you have?"

Jenna smoothly listed several labels with their prices, detailing each wine's tasting notes.

Gavin raised an eyebrow. "You've done your homework."

She smiled faintly. "Some guests ask. I have to be prepared."

"Two bottles of Romanée-Conti." Miles waved his hand. "And bring some snacks and fruits."

Tonight was about currying favor with Ethan. He needed to keep the man satisfied.

Jenna gave a slight bow. "Right away, sir."

As she exited, her mind reeled.

Two bottles of Romanée-Conti? Miles was splurging.

Ethan was just a regular manager who usually ordered mid-range wines. Who knew he had such influential connections?

Passing the lounge, she spotted Milo glued to his phone game.

"Sis!" His eyes lit up. "Did you see Mr. Roscente?"

"Hosting him now." She ruffled his hair. "Hungry?"

"Nah, gaming."

"Call if you need me."

At the bar, Tristan intercepted her.

"You're handling VIP 999?"

"Yes. Mr. Roscente's party." She nodded. "They ordered two Romanée-Conti."

Tristan frowned. "Miles' doing?"

"Mm-hmm."

"Got it." His expression turned thoughtful. "Deliver promptly."

Miles was the fourth son of the Valentines, a startup founder desperate for resources. Clearly here to suck up to Ethan.

He watched Jenna's retreating figure, hesitating before looking away.

Soon, she returned with the wine and appetizers.
###Chapter 61

Jenna's slender fingers twisted open the cork of the red wine. Amber liquid cascaded into the decanter, releasing tiny bubbles. She arranged the nuts on a platter with the grace of a high-end restaurant server.

Gavin swirled his glass, ice cubes clinking against the crystal. "Miles, what's your startup capital?"

Miles threw back his drink, Adam's apple bobbing. "Five million. All my personal savings." His lips twisted wryly. "Grandpa's condition—turn it into five hundred million within three years to inherit the family business."

Dylan chimed in, "We've got the company structure set. Just need stable clients now."

"You launched without securing clients first?" Gavin's eyebrow arched, his gaze flickering between Ethan and Jenna.

Miles shrugged. "Isn't trial and error how business works?"

Gavin lowered his voice. "Ethan's the project director at HM Group. Win him over, and your order book will overflow."

Both Miles and Dylan choked on their drinks. They exchanged glances—everyone knew Ethan was HM Group's heir apparent.

Jenna poured the aerated wine into crystal goblets, light refracting through the glass. Her silver bracelet shimmered as she served each guest. "Enjoy." She took a sip before exiting, her skirt swirling elegantly.

The moment the door closed, Miles leaned in. "Gavin, Ethan is clearly—"

Gavin pressed a finger to his lips. "Remember, to Ms. Roland, he's just a regular project director." His meaningful glance at Ethan said everything. "Address him as Mr. Roscente."

Understanding dawned on Miles—the heir was roleplaying. He smoothly pivoted. "Mr. Roscente, I heard HM has a new project..."

Ethan's fingers drummed the table, but his gaze lingered where Jenna had disappeared. Under the chandelier's glow, his lips curved in an enigmatic half-smile.
###Chapter 62

The private room was dimly lit, with crystal chandeliers casting hazy reflections.

Ethan Roscente's slender fingers tapped rhythmically against the table, his gaze deep as a still pond.

Miles Valentine nervously rubbed his palms together, beads of sweat forming on his forehead.

"Mr. Roscente, about my new company..."

Ethan raised a hand to silence him, taking a measured sip from his wineglass.

"International trade?"

Miles nodded eagerly. "Yes, mainly clothing and footwear imports."

Ethan traced the rim of his glass, producing a clear, ringing sound.

"Logistics secured?"

Miles stiffened. "Maritime shipping is settled, but land and air transport..."

Dylan Lawrence offered a cigar, which Ethan declined with a subtle wave.

"Price too low?"

Miles forced an awkward smile. "They claim the margins are too thin."

Ethan's attention suddenly shifted to the doorway, his eyes narrowing.

Gavin Valentine was peering inside hesitantly.

"Where's Tristan?"

Gavin scratched his head. "In the next room discussing business."

Ethan's expression turned glacial.

"Get him here."

Miles interjected cautiously, "Mr. Roscente, about our potential partnership..."

Ethan leaned forward abruptly, his black dress shirt accentuating his muscular frame.

"Know why no one wants to work with you?"

Miles held his breath.

"Please enlighten me."

Ethan tapped the table like a ticking countdown.

"No credibility. No connections. No collateral."

Each word drained more color from Miles' face.

Dylan suddenly spoke up. "Sir, Miss Roland just called—"

Ethan's gaze sharpened like a blade.

Miles caught the reaction instantly.

"Miss Roland is...?"

A single icy glance from Ethan silenced him.

Gavin returned with Tristan Ashcroft in tow.

Tristan entered impeccably dressed, all polished smiles.

"Mr. Roscente, long time no see."

Ethan gestured for him to sit, then addressed Miles without turning.

"Bring your proposal to my office tomorrow."

Miles' eyes widened in disbelief.

"Thank you, sir!"

But Ethan had already turned to Tristan, his voice dropping.

"That Southeast Asia shipment..."

Taking the hint, Miles rose to leave.

At the door, he caught Ethan's cold parting words:

"Tell Jenna I won't be home tonight."

Miles paused mid-step, curiosity flickering in his eyes.

Just who was this mysterious Miss Roland to Ethan Roscente?
###Chapter 63

Gavin Valentine pushed open the door of VIP Room 999. Tristan Ashcroft had been waiting inside for quite some time.

"Mr. Roscente." Tristan stood up respectfully, raising his glass in two consecutive toasts. "You asked to see me?"

Ethan Roscente slid a cigarette from his case and offered it to him.

"Thank you, Mr. Roscente." Tristan accepted it hastily, pulling out his lighter to light Ethan's cigarette first before his own.

Amid the swirling smoke, Ethan's piercing gaze fixed on Tristan. "Why is Jenna Roland's brother here?"

Tristan's heart skipped a beat.

He'd anticipated this question, but not the bluntness.

Jenna's importance to Ethan was greater than he'd imagined.

"Here's what happened..." Tristan recounted Milo Roland's visit to the club in detail.

Gavin suddenly cut in, "Who told the kid his sister works here?"

Tristan shook his head. "He didn't say."

Then he remembered the incident with Jenna's cousin two nights prior.

Could it have been him?

Ethan immediately noticed Tristan's shift in expression. "Speak."

Tristan stiffened.

This man was terrifying—reading his thoughts before he even voiced them.

"Jenna's cousin caused a scene here the other night..." Tristan relayed the events.

"Damn it!" Gavin slammed the table. "What kind of monster slanders his own cousin?"

Miles Valentine smirked coldly. "If I ever run into that bastard..."

Tristan stole a glance at Ethan.

The man continued smoking in silence, but his eyes had turned glacial.

Tristan stubbed out his cigarette. "Milo was adamant about stopping his sister from working here. It took everything I had to calm him down. Those siblings have it rough—orphaned, with no reliable relatives, the kid still in school, and from what I hear, battling a serious illness..."

Ethan's fingers paused mid-drag.

So Jenna had approached Grandma Blanche for money?

A shadow flickered in his eyes.

If she dared exploit the old woman...

Studio 54 was packed that Friday night.

Jenna Roland didn't finish serving the last guests until 3 AM.

Her high alcohol tolerance was the only thing keeping her upright.

In the staff lounge, Milo lay curled asleep on the couch.

Jenna changed clothes quietly before gently shaking him awake.

"Sis..." Rubbing his eyes, Milo sat up hoarsely. "Done for the night?"

"Yeah. Let's go home."

She grabbed his phone, checked out with the manager, and the siblings vanished into the darkness.
###Chapter 64

The night deepened as Jenna Roland led her brother Milo out of the club's entrance.

A black Maybach idled by the curb. The tinted window rolled down, revealing Gavin Valentine's chiseled profile.

"Mr. Valentine?" Jenna halted mid-step.

Gavin adjusted his gold-rimmed glasses. "Mr. Roscente instructed me to drive you."

Her fingers tightened around her purse strap. "That's unnecessary. We were planning to grab dinner first."

"Get in." His tone brooked no argument. "I'll take you wherever you want."

After a brief hesitation, Jenna opened the door. Milo gaped at the luxurious interior, discreetly tugging his sister's sleeve.

Twenty minutes later, the car stopped outside a bustling street food stall.

"You can head back now, Mr. Valentine." Jenna forced politeness. "We'll call a cab—"

"Mr. Roscente's orders." Gavin cut her off. "I'll wait."

Inside the stall, raucous laughter and sizzling woks filled the air. Jenna's eyes sparkled as she placed their order.

"Guess how much we made tonight?" She leaned in conspiratorially.

Milo nibbled his chopsticks. "Five grand?"

"Higher."

"Eight?"

Jenna shook her head, holding up two fingers. "Fourteen thousand!"

"What?!" Milo nearly knocked over his soda.

Nearby diners turned to stare. He clapped a hand over his mouth.

"Landed some big clients today." Jenna whispered. "Mr. Roscente's table alone ordered two bottles of Louis XIII."

Milo's cheeks flushed with excitement. "Sis, you're a business prodigy!"

Suddenly, he grabbed her wrist. "What if... we used this money to start something small?"

Jenna's smile froze.
###Chapter 65

Working odd jobs wasn't a sustainable solution. With her limited education, climbing the social ladder through wages seemed impossible.

Gavin's words pierced Jenna's heart like a thorn. She knew this truth all too well. But right now, Milo's condition took priority.

"Let's focus on the surgery first," Jenna cut him off decisively. "We'll figure out the rest later."

Milo lowered his head, fingers nervously twisting his shirt hem. He hated being a burden yet couldn't help worrying about his sister.

"Sis, the club might be..." He bit his lip. "But the money's good. After my surgery, you could save up to open a small shop?"

Jenna remained silent, simply placing a piece of meat in his bowl. Her mind was already made up—once Milo recovered, she'd reclaim their family orchard.

When the waiter arrived with steaming fried noodles, Jenna suddenly remembered something. She hurried toward the parking lot.

The car window rolled down, revealing Gavin's sharply defined features in the dim light.

"Mr. Valentine, care to join us?"

"Pass." His refusal was curt.

Back at their table, Milo stared blankly at his phone. As Jenna sat down, she heard him murmur, "Why is Mr. Roscente being so kind to us?"

That was a question Jenna wanted answered too.

During the drive back, Gavin casually mentioned the incident with their cousin. Jenna's pulse quickened—she hadn't expected Tristan to share that detail.

"Next time just have someone beat him up," Gavin said as casually as discussing the weather. "Tristan knows how to handle the fallout."

Jenna gave a bitter smile. "Strike one and ten will retaliate. We can't afford to provoke that family."

Through the rearview mirror, she saw Gavin's eyebrow arch. "What's there to fear? Anything solvable with money isn't a real problem."

The remark drew a sudden laugh from Jenna, quickly stifled. Watching neon lights streak past the window, she asked softly, "Why are you helping us?"

"Ethan's friends are my friends." His answer came effortlessly.

Jenna pressed her lips together. She didn't believe a word of it.
###Chapter 66

Jenna Roland frowned slightly. When had she ever admitted to being Ethan Roscente's friend?

They were legally married with official certificates.

Though it was a marriage of convenience, the embossed seal on their marriage license was undeniably real.

She pressed her lips together but ultimately didn't correct Gavin Valentine.

Milo Roland gave Gavin a thoughtful glance. Apparently Ethan hadn't even told his closest friend about the marriage.

Gavin's car soon pulled into Beverly Hills.

"Thank you," Jenna murmured, taking her brother's hand as they exited the vehicle.

Walking through the neighborhood, Milo suddenly remarked, "That Gavin seems like a decent guy."

"Mmm." Jenna nodded.

When they reached home, light spilling from under the bedroom door made Jenna pause. Ethan had returned early.

She tiptoed to grab her pajamas before heading to the bathroom.

The next morning, Ethan left without disturbing the sleeping siblings.

At 9:30 AM, the alarm buzzed.

Jenna rubbed her eyes and sat up. She needed to be alert today—they were hosting the elderly couple.

Soon, the aroma of rice filled the kitchen. By 10:30, all prepared ingredients were neatly arranged on the cutting board.

The braised pork knuckle simmered in the clay pot as Jenna wiped her hands and dialed her phone.

"Grandma Blanche, have you and Grandpa Harrison left yet?"

A hearty laugh came through the receiver. "Already on our way, dear. Start cooking first."

After hanging up, Jenna immediately turned on the stove.

Using both burners doubled her efficiency. Just as two dishes were plated, the doorbell rang.

Milo raced to answer it.

Jenna hurried to the foyer and saw three figures standing there.

Beside Grandma Blanche stood a white-haired gentleman with keen eyes—undoubtedly Grandpa Harrison Roscente.

The last person made Jenna blink in surprise. Ethan had returned unusually early today.

"This is Grandpa Harrison," Grandma Blanche introduced warmly.

"Hello, Grandpa." Jenna gave a slight bow.

"Nice to meet you, Grandpa Harrison." Milo offered a proper bow.

The old man's eyes crinkled with delight. "Good, good children, both of you."

Jenna ushered the guests inside before turning to her brother. "Milo, please serve tea to our grandparents."

As rich aromas wafted from the kitchen, Jenna tied on her apron and hurried back to the stove.
###Chapter 67

Grandma Blanche took a sip of tea, her gaze drifting to the armchair in the corner.

Ethan Roscente had been sitting there since he arrived, silently scrolling through his phone with an icy aura that warned others to keep their distance.

She sighed and turned to Milo Roland beside Grandpa Harrison, her eyes softening. "What grade are you in now, dear?"

"Eleventh grade," Milo answered politely.

Grandpa Harrison's eyes lit up. "That means you'll be applying to colleges next year! Have you decided where to go?"

Milo's fingers twisted together unconsciously. He had already resolved to find a job after graduation to help ease his sister's burdens.

Grandma Blanche saw right through him. "Education is your golden ticket. Without a degree, life will be much harder."

"But..." Milo's voice dropped. "College is expensive..."

"Silly boy." She patted his hand. "Your sister's greatest wish is for you to succeed. Would you really disappoint her?"

Grandpa Harrison nodded. "She's right. A good education will help you protect those you care about."

Milo's eyes grew warm. These elders treated him like their own grandson, filling his heart with gratitude.

In stark contrast, Ethan remained as cold as a statue, his expression unreadable since his arrival.

The kitchen door suddenly swung open, revealing Jenna Roland. "Grandma, Grandpa, Mr. Roscente—dinner's ready."

"Coming!" Grandma Blanche immediately rose to help.

But Grandpa Harrison frowned. "Why does she call you 'Mr. Roscente'?"

Ethan didn't even glance up. "Let her call me what she wants."

The blunt reply left the old man speechless. Before he could react, Ethan had already stood and headed to the restroom.

The dining table was set with five dishes and a soup, all vibrant and appetizing. The braised pork knuckle glistened, its rich aroma filling the air.

Grandpa Harrison's eyes widened. "Did you cook all this, Jenna?"

"Please try it." She smiled, handing him chopsticks.

He eagerly picked up a piece of pork. "This is even better than our chef's—"

Before he could finish, Grandma Blanche stomped on his foot under the table.
###Chapter 68

Jenna and Milo's gazes simultaneously landed on Grandpa Harrison.

Jenna blinked. "Excuse me?"

Grandpa Harrison cleared his throat awkwardly. "It's more fragrant than Ethan's mother's cooking."

Grandma Blanche smiled and explained, "Ethan's mother's maiden name is Chu."

The room fell silent.

Ethan frowned, shooting the elderly couple an exasperated look.

Since when did his mother change her surname?

These two were getting increasingly ridiculous in their attempts to please Jenna.

Noticing Ethan's stare, Grandma Blanche glared back. "What are you looking at?"

Ethan silently averted his gaze.

Better not provoke her.

Jenna broke the awkward silence. "Grandpa, Grandma, why don't you taste it first?"

Grandma Blanche's expression instantly softened when she turned to Jenna—a stark contrast to how she'd just looked at Ethan.

The blatant favoritism made Ethan question his place in the family.

He might as well be adopted. Jenna was clearly the biological grandchild here.

"Of course." Grandma Blanche picked up her chopsticks, serving Jenna and Milo each a braised pork knuckle before adding cola chicken wings to their bowls.

Milo had been eyeing the chicken wings hungrily but restrained himself out of respect for the elders.

Now that the wings were in his bowl, he took an eager bite.

His sister's cola chicken wings were always perfection.

A sudden thought struck him—if he were really gone someday, he'd never taste this again.

To keep enjoying his sister's cooking, he had to survive. No matter what.

Grandpa Harrison shared Ethan's picky palate.

Even professional chefs rarely met his exacting standards at home.

Yet Jenna's cooking exceeded all expectations.

He shocked everyone by eating three bowls of rice at lunch—so much that he ended up patting his full stomach with satisfied burps.

"Jenna, who taught you to cook like this?" Grandpa Harrison asked warmly.

Jenna shook her head. "Self-taught. I started cooking at twelve, with occasional tips from my mom."

Grandpa Harrison's eyes shone with admiration. "You could open a restaurant with these skills. I'd be your most loyal customer."

Jenna smiled. "For you, Grandpa, it's always free."

Grandpa Harrison laughed heartily. "Now this is what I call a thoughtful granddaughter. Unlike some ungrateful people I know."
###Chapter 69

Grandpa Harrison set down his chopsticks with a meaningful glance at Ethan.

The unspoken tension thickened the air.

Ethan rose expressionlessly, adjusting his cuffs with slender fingers. "An urgent matter at the office."

Grandma Blanche slammed her chopsticks down, porcelain clinking sharply.

"This is your home, not a hotel!" She glared at him. "Jenna worked all morning, and you're just leaving?"

Jenna frantically waved her hands. "Grandma, I'll clean up—"

She stole a glance at Ethan's stormy expression, a cold sweat breaking down her spine. Offending him meant she and Milo would be homeless.

Grandpa Harrison sipped his tea leisurely. "Ethan, do the dishes."

The sudden clatter of plates echoed from the kitchen.

Jenna's eyes widened. Ethan was actually clearing the table!

Grandma Blanche winked triumphantly at Milo. "Let's give the newlyweds some privacy."

Flustered, Jenna hurried in to find Ethan stacking dishes by the sink.

"I'll wash them," she whispered.

He shook water droplets from his hands, his crisp pine scent enveloping her.

"Suit yourself."

As he turned, his shirt hem brushed her knuckles, sending shivers down her spine.

Watching his retreating figure, her heartbeat stuttered.

Water gushed from the faucet, suds foaming around her slender fingers.

Outside, Grandma Blanche's voice carried deliberately loud: "That's how you train a man!"
###Chapter 70

Jenna Roland pressed her lips together as she scrubbed the dishes.

The faucet ran loudly. When she finished cleaning the kitchen and returned to the living room, Ethan Roscente was already gone.

Grandma Blanche smiled and waved her over. "Ethan had to meet a client unexpectedly. Come rest for a while, dear."

"Okay." Jenna obediently sat beside the elderly woman.

Grandma Blanche took her hand. "Ethan may seem cold and distant, but he's warm-hearted underneath. Isn't that what you young people call 'cold on the outside, warm on the inside'?"

Jenna wanted to say Ethan avoided her like the plague, and there were still unresolved misunderstandings between them. But seeing the kindness in the old woman's eyes, she swallowed her words.

"I understand, Grandma," she replied softly.

Grandpa Harrison chimed in, "Don't spoil him. Make him pull his weight at home. A marriage takes two people working together."

Jenna nodded eagerly. "You're absolutely right, Grandpa."

The elderly couple exchanged knowing glances. They could tell she agreed readily now but would shoulder everything alone once they left. Too soft-hearted for her own good.

An hour later, after seeing them off, Jenna closed the door and exhaled deeply.

Milo Roland peeked out from his room. "Sis, go take a nap. I'll handle the grocery shopping."

Having stayed up late and woken early to cook, Jenna was exhausted. She didn't argue, transferring money to her brother before retreating to her room.

She slept like the dead, waking at four in the afternoon.

The living room was empty. After washing up and doing her makeup, she found Milo on the sofa.

"Where were you?" she asked, tying up her hair.

"Just got back from shopping." He stood and headed to the kitchen. "Hungry? Want me to make you some noodles?"

"Sure."

Following him into the kitchen, Jenna suddenly remembered something. "Wait, show me that text message."

Milo handed over his phone. When she opened the message from the unknown number, her face turned ashen.

"It's definitely Jason Roland!" she spat through gritted teeth. "That bastard!"

"Him?" Milo frowned, confusion flashing in his eyes.

Jenna's hands trembled with rage. "He called demanding forty grand from me. I never thought he'd send you something like this!"

Her chest heaved. When his extortion failed, Jason had exposed her club job to Milo—utterly despicable!

"I didn't expect it either." Milo's fists clenched audibly, his eyes filled with disgust. "That piece of trash."
###Chapter 71 

Jenna's knuckles turned white as she clenched her phone. Her uncle's family had crossed every line of decency, even daring to send threatening texts. This was clearly a warning—they intended to spread exaggerated rumors about her job at the club.

She recalled Milo's naive suggestion to apologize and move back in with them. The thought sent a chill down her spine now. If she'd actually returned, who knew what else they would've done to her.

"I recorded them that night," Jenna said coldly. "If they spread lies, I'll take the recording to the police."

Milo frowned as he stirred the noodles in the pot. "But they didn't succeed. Would the police even care?"

"At least it'll teach them a lesson." Her eyes sharpened. "I won't let them get away with this."

The water boiled, noodles swirling in the pot.

Jenna suddenly pulled five crisp hundred-dollar bills from her wallet and pressed them into Milo's hand.

"Sis?" He stared at the money. "This is too much."
