Xu Chan and Zhou Xian'e turned ashen.

They never imagined their idle gossip could land them in legal trouble.

"No rush." Jenna smiled coolly. "I'll take my brother for his medical exam first. Inspector Cole, please assign an officer to accompany us—lest anyone accuse us of fleeing."

Officer Liam Hill arrived promptly. He recognized Jenna immediately—he'd handled Fiona Roland's extortion case previously.

Ethan's phone suddenly rang.

"Don't let us keep you," Jenna said politely. "I'll reach out if needed."

Her use of "Mr. Roscente" made both officers glance sharply at Ethan.

Without a backward glance, Ethan strode out of the mediation room.
###Chapter 112

"Who was that man just now?" Inspector Cole Macmillan frowned deeply.

Jenna Roland looked up at him. "A friend of mine. Do you know him, Inspector?"

"What's his name? That surname is quite rare." His tone carried a hint of probing.

"Ethan Roscente."

The air instantly froze.

Inspector Cole's pupils constricted sharply.

Officer Liam Hill also showed a stunned expression.

Ethan Roscente?

The second son of the prestigious Roscente family in Los Angeles?

The rumored wealthiest man in the world?

How could someone like that appear at a police station?

And have any connection with an escort girl?

It must be a case of identical names.

Jenna noticed their odd reaction. "Do you two know him?"

"Not personally." Inspector Cole waved his hand. "Might have heard the name during investigations. Officer Hill will take your brother for the medical examination."

Jenna bowed slightly to Liam. "Thank you for your trouble."

The group exited the police station.

Zhou Xian'e and Xu Chan followed behind, their palms sweating.

If the examination revealed serious injuries...

Plus Jenna pressing charges...

The consequences would be disastrous!

The police car headed toward the hospital.

Midway, Liam suddenly spoke. "Miss Roland, does your brother have congenital heart disease?"

Zhou and Xu trembled violently.

Heart disease?

If he'd had an episode during the altercation...

Sheng Fei would be finished!

What if the hospital found other conditions too...

The mother-in-law and daughter-in-law exchanged glances.

Cold sweat drenched their backs.

Jenna sat in the rear seat. "Yes. We couldn't afford the surgery, so it's been untreated."

She suddenly turned to look at the two women.

They immediately stiffened.

Zhou's voice shook. "W-why are you staring at us?"
###Chapter 113

Jenna Roland crossed her arms, fingertips tapping lightly against her sleeves.

"My brother has a weak heart," she murmured, her voice feather-light. "When the test results come out, I hope you're prepared to face the consequences."

The car fell into abrupt silence.

Zhou Xian'e and Xu Chan both stiffened in their seats.

Xu Chan dug her nails into her palms. "His medical condition has nothing to do with us!"

"Oh, but it does." Jenna lifted her gaze. "Your son's punch could have triggered a severe deterioration." She paused. "Medical bills, emotional damages, long-term treatment—surely you're not planning to skip out on paying?"

"You—!" Xu Chan's voice rose sharply. "My son is still hospitalized!"

Jenna nodded. "I'll cover every cent of his expenses." Her eyes flicked to the neon lights streaking past the window. "But my brother's bills? You'd better be ready to pay up too."

From the driver's seat, Liu Shen tightened his grip on the steering wheel. "How much for the surgery?"

"One point two million." The number left Jenna's lips just as the rearview mirror caught the redness rimming her eyes. "After our parents passed, it's just been the two of us."

Milo Roland suddenly broke into violent coughing from the passenger seat.

Liu Shen hesitated before offering tissues. He'd seen plenty of girls hustling drinks at clubs, but never one whose white blouse was worn thin from too many washes.

"Working at a place like that..." He couldn't help himself.

"Pays well." Jenna cut him off. "Once his surgery's done, I'm quitting."

A muffled sob came from the backseat. Milo buried his face in his school uniform sleeve, the fabric darkening with tears. He remembered the sound of his sister's footsteps returning at 3 AM, the scars on her hands from broken bottles.

Zhou Xian'e tugged at Xu Chan's sleeve. Both mothers stared at the girl's scuffed heels and said nothing more.

The wail of an ambulance grew closer. As Jenna pushed the car door open, Liu Shen murmured, "Let me see the medical records."

The night wind lifted her thin shirt, revealing the pain-relief patch on her waist.
###Chapter 114

The car had barely stopped when Jenna told Liam and the others to wait at the hospital entrance.

She tugged at Milo's sleeve, signaling for him to stay.

Milo kept his head down, his bangs shadowing his eyes.

He didn't want his sister to see the redness in them.

Jenna tilted her head closer, determined to get a good look at his bloodshot eyes.

"Oh? Since when does our little tough guy cry golden tears?"

Milo turned his face away, his voice muffled. "I'm not crying."

The hoarseness in his tone betrayed him.

Jenna chuckled softly, standing on tiptoe to ruffle his hair.

"Remember to say your chest hurts during the examination."

Milo jerked his head up, confusion written across his face. "Why?"

"You hit Ethan pretty hard." Jenna lowered her voice. "If you don't make it seem serious, that shrew of a mother won't let this go."

Milo frowned. "But aren't you suing them for defamation?"

"That'll only scare them temporarily." Jenna's lips curled into a cold smile. "If they find out you're fine while Ethan's badly hurt, you'll get expelled for sure. We'd have to pay compensation too."

Milo clenched his fists. "I'm sorry, sis. I shouldn't have fought back."

"Silly boy." Jenna poked his forehead. "You fight back when someone bullies you—that's my brother. So what if we have to pay? I'll just take on more clients."

Milo's eyes reddened again.

Jenna pulled him into a tight hug, gently patting his back. "Don't be afraid. I've got you."

Milo buried his face in her shoulder and gave a muffled "Mm."

By the time they entered the hospital, Liam had been waiting at the entrance for a while.

Registration, payment, examinations—throughout the entire process, Milo kept frowning.

During the MRI, he suddenly clutched his chest. "Doctor, it hurts here."

The doctor immediately grew concerned and urged them to visit the thoracic surgery department for further checks.

Jenna remained calm. This was exactly the reaction she'd anticipated.

But Xu Chan, standing nearby, panicked.

Her eyes locked onto Milo's pale face, her fingers trembling uncontrollably.

If Milo really had heart problems—on top of the defamation charges—her family would be ruined!
###Chapter 115

Jenna Roland arrived at Los Angeles General Hospital with her brother Milo at dawn. This time, she specifically booked an appointment with Dr. Zhou, the chief cardiothoracic specialist. The previous routine check-up results had left her uneasy.

The waiting area was packed. The sharp scent of disinfectant hung in the air. Milo slumped in his chair, his face paler than usual.

"Number 36 to Exam Room 3," the automated voice announced.

Jenna helped her brother up. Ethan and Daisy followed them inside. Dr. Zhou was reviewing medical records on his computer.

"What seems to be the problem?" The doctor adjusted his glasses.

Jenna detailed Milo's medical history and handed over a thick stack of test results. Dr. Zhou studied each report, his frown deepening.

"Rib fracture on the left side. The heart condition is more concerning." He set down the documents. "Was he previously diagnosed with congenital heart disease?"

"Yes, the tests confirmed it was congenital." Jenna clenched her fists. "We've been managing it with medication due to financial constraints. Doctor, how serious is it now?"

Dr. Zhou removed his glasses and rubbed his temples. "Medication only slows progression. Surgery is strongly recommended. The optimal treatment window was during infancy. Delaying further increases the risks."

Jenna's throat tightened. "I understand, but the cost—"

"Prolonging this could lead to organ failure. Surgical risks would double by then." His tone turned grave. "Young patients recover faster. The sooner, the better."

"Is a heart transplant necessary?" Her voice trembled.

The doctor nodded. "The structural deformity is severe. Conventional surgery won't correct it. With post-op anti-rejection therapy, total expenses would be around eight to nine hundred thousand."

The figure made Jenna's vision blur. Despite years of saving, she was still far short.

"Doctor, he complained of severe chest pain today..." Her voice cracked with urgency.

"Could be from the fracture, or the medication losing efficacy." Dr. Zhou suggested, "Hospitalization for observation would be prudent."

Daisy suddenly interjected, "Is he dying or something?"

"Shut your mouth!" Jenna whirled around, eyes blazing. "My brother will live to a hundred. You'll die first!"

Daisy recoiled, face purpling with suppressed rage.

Ignoring the outburst, Dr. Zhou continued, "The fractured rib is dangerously close to the thoracic cavity. I advise—"

Milo suddenly convulsed with violent coughs. Bright red blood splattered across the pristine medical forms.
###Chapter 116

"Without prompt treatment, this could lead to chronic pain and recurrent infections." Director Zhou adjusted his glasses. "Given the patient's history of congenital heart disease, any cardiac infection would have devastating consequences."

Jenna Roland clenched the hem of her shirt. She had only asked her brother Milo to fake chest pains—never expecting actual rib fractures to show up on the scans.

Now the pretense wasn't even necessary.

"Admit him, then." Jenna took a steadying breath.

Director Zhou swiftly prepared the hospitalization forms. At the payment counter, Jenna stared at the staggering number on the bill, her fingers trembling slightly.

After settling Milo into his IV drip, Jenna summoned Mrs. Xu and Liu Shen to the hallway.

"Auntie, here are the examination and hospitalization fees." Jenna handed over a stack of invoices. "Will you be paying cash or transferring the funds?"

Mrs. Xu's hand froze mid-air.

Thirty-eight thousand!

"How could it be this expensive?" Her voice cracked.

Jenna's expression remained impassive. "Where's your son's medical report?"

Though Sheng Fei had been injured by Milo, her brother's condition was far more severe. This accounting needed to be settled properly.

Mrs. Xu hastily shoved the papers back at Jenna. "I need to make a call."

On the other end, Sheng Qingming sounded unconcerned. "Fei just had a nosebleed and some bruises. He'll be discharged after the checkup."

"What?" Mrs. Xu slammed her fist against the wall. "Milo has fractured ribs and a heart condition! This is a disaster!"

"How could—"

"That little bastard Sheng Fei!" Mrs. Xu hissed through gritted teeth. "How much were your tests?"

"A little over three thousand."

Mrs. Xu's vision darkened. Three thousand versus thirty-eight thousand—this was a losing bargain. And now they faced Jenna's defamation lawsuit on top of it.

Leaning against the wall, she felt her blood pressure skyrocket.
###Chapter 117

Jenna Roland slammed the phone down with force. When she turned to face Ethan Roscente, a flicker of panic crossed her face.

"Ethan, about that—"

His gaze turned icy. "Trying to back out?"

Jenna glanced at Liam Hill standing nearby and quickly waved her hands. "No, no! My son's medical bills came to over three thousand."

"Fine." Ethan's expression remained impassive. "Deduct three thousand. Transfer thirty-five thousand to me."

Jenna gritted her teeth as she completed the transfer. The moment her phone chimed with the notification, Ethan spoke again. "Forty thousand upfront for treatment. Any excess will be refunded, any shortage covered."

Her face instantly paled.

She had planned to extort a hundred thousand from Milo Roland, only to find his injuries were far worse. Now not only was she getting nothing, she had to pay out of pocket.

"Plus compensation for emotional distress," Ethan added.

"On what grounds?" Jenna clenched her fists.

"Your son nearly killed my brother." Ethan's voice was glacial. "He has congenital heart disease. He could drop dead any second. Are you paying for that trauma or not?"

If Jenna hadn't been so aggressive at the police station, if her son hadn't been bullying Milo at school, Ethan wouldn't have been this ruthless.

With people like her, mercy was just enabling.

Seeing Jenna's defiance, Ethan smirked. "Your son's an adult now. Assault plus defamation—that's enough for jail time. A criminal record would ruin his life."

Since the orchard dispute, Ethan had studied legal statutes inside out. Every word struck like a blade, leaving Jenna scrambling.

"What do you want?" Jenna forced the words through gritted teeth.

Ethan held her gaze. "Pay what's owed. Apologize where due. Your son assaulted my brother. You spread vicious rumors. Today, you will answer for this."

Jenna made a call with a face like thunder. Half an hour later, Oliver Macmillan appeared at the hospital room door with his son Zachary.

"What's going on?" Oliver looked at Liam.

Jenna yanked Zachary forward. "Why did you spread those lies at school? Saying Milo's sister was some kind of escort?"

Zachary sneered at Ethan. "Isn't she? Was I wrong?"

Jenna slapped him across the face.

"Apologize! Now!"

Zachary jutted his chin. "She is an escort. Why should I apologize?"
###Chapter 118

Jenna Roland took a deep breath, her eyes icy cold. She glared at the woman. "Compensation for emotional distress and medical bills—not a penny less. And expect court summons soon."

She turned to Liam Hill with a nod and strode into the hospital room, slamming the door shut behind her.

Inside, Milo Roland lay on the bed with an IV drip. Jenna sat beside him, gently holding his hand. "Don't worry. I'm here."

Milo's eyes reddened, his voice choked. "I'm sorry, sis. I caused trouble again."

"Don't be silly." She patted his hand. "Rest. I'll watch over you."

His rib fracture wasn't severe. The doctors opted for conservative treatment—a small mercy given his congenital heart disease.

Soon, Milo drifted into sleep.

The door creaked open as Liam entered, keeping his voice low. "They want to talk again."

Jenna scoffed. "My terms are clear. Pay up and apologize, or we go to court."

"They said Sheng Fei is young. A criminal record would ruin his future—"

"Eighteen is adulthood." She cut him off. "He owns his actions."

Liam sighed and left.

Jenna stayed by the bed, unwavering. With no one else to care for her brother, she dialed Tristan Ashcroft.

"Boss, my brother's hospitalized. I need a week off."

Silence stretched on the line. "A whole week?"

"Problem?" Her tone turned frosty.

"N-No. Take care of him." Tristan reluctantly agreed.

She hung up.

Minutes later, Liam returned.
###Chapter 119

Officer Liam Hill straightened his police uniform collar and knocked lightly on the hospital room door.

Jenna Roland looked up and immediately rose to greet him.

"They've agreed to cover all expenses, including compensation for emotional distress and medical bills," Liam said in a hushed tone. "They're also willing to apologize in person."

Jenna glanced at the sleeping Milo before whispering, "Have them wait outside. He just fell asleep."

Liam nodded, his gaze lingering on the bandaged boy in the bed. "Then consider this matter settled. Don't hesitate to contact me if you need anything."

"Thank you for your help." Jenna gave a slight bow.

After seeing Liam out, Jenna leaned against the window, absently tracing patterns on her phone screen.

A rustling sound came from the bed.

"Awake?" Jenna pocketed her phone and approached.

Milo rubbed his eyes, the bruise on his temple glaring under the sunlight.

"The Fei family is waiting outside to apologize," Jenna said, handing him a glass of water. "Are you willing to accept it?"

"No!" Milo sat up abruptly, water sloshing from the cup.

The insults hurled at his sister were carved into his memory like knives. How could he possibly forgive so easily?

"But—"

"Jenna!" Milo cut her off. "Did he consider the consequences when he hit me in front of the whole school?"

Jenna sighed and took his trembling hand.

"What do you want to do then?"

Milo stared at the white sheets and enunciated each word: "I want him to apologize publicly in front of the entire school."

Outside the room, Fei Sheng was kicking the wall impatiently.

"Behave yourself!" Xu Chan pinched his arm sharply.

The door opened.

Jenna relayed Milo's demand with an impassive expression.

"This..." Xu Chan's face paled.

Fei Sheng started to protest but froze under his father's glare.

"We agree," Sheng Qingming said firmly. "We'll go to the school tomorrow."

Jenna nodded. "As for the compensation—"

"Is fifty thousand enough?" Xu Chan fumbled for her wallet.

"Sixty," Jenna met her eyes. "Including follow-up treatment."

Xu Chan's hands shook, nearly dropping her purse.

"O-okay."

As Jenna closed the door, Xu Chan finally lost her temper and smacked her son's back.

"You good-for-nothing!"

Fei Sheng retorted, "Who asked his sister to work at that kind of place!"

"Shut up!" Sheng Qingming snapped. "Haven't you embarrassed us enough?"

The argument in the hallway seeped through the door cracks. Milo clenched his fists.

"Jenna... Am I being too stubborn?"

She ruffled his hair. "You're just protecting me."

Sunlight filtered through the curtains, casting a warm patch of light on the hospital bed.
###Chapter 120

Sheng Qingming smacked Sheng Fei's head so hard the boy staggered.

"You dare complain?" Sheng Qingming hissed through clenched teeth. "Do you have any idea how much your little stunt cost our family?"

Sheng Fei pouted. "I wasn't lying. She really does work as an escort at that club."

Thankfully Jenna wasn't present, or the situation would've escalated further.

Seeing the tension, Xu Chang grabbed Sheng Fei's collar and dragged him away.

......

The next afternoon, Milo Roland had just finished lunch when his phone rang.

"Ryan?" Milo answered, leaning against his hospital bed's headboard.

"Breaking news!" Ryan Watson sounded thrilled. "Sheng Fei apologized to you over the school PA system during recess. I recorded it—want to hear?"

Milo scoffed. "Not interested."

"Suit yourself. By the way, did he really fracture your ribs?"

"What do you think?" Milo snapped. "You think I'm faking this hospital stay?"

"Damn! That bastard went that far? I thought you'd beaten him up worse." Ryan whistled. "Honestly, you shouldn't have let him off so easy."

"You think I wanted to?" Milo lowered his voice. "If it weren't for protecting my sister's reputation, I'd never have agreed to settle."

"Speaking of which, how did Sheng Fei know about Jenna working at the club?"

"Beats me!" Milo's brow furrowed.

Apart from himself, not even Ryan knew about this. How could Sheng Fei...

"I'll look into it. Focus on recovering." Ryan hung up.

Milo set down his phone and glanced at Jenna peeling apples by his bedside. "Sis, won't Mr. Roscente be upset you're not cooking for him?"

"I took leave," Jenna said without looking up. "He said it's fine."

"Good." Milo exhaled in relief.

......

Five days later, Milo was finally discharged.

Jenna headed straight to the market after their early morning return home.

Spotting fresh marrow bones at the butcher's stall, she immediately bought two to make nourishing soup for her brother.

Back home, Jenna started simmering the bone broth, then called Ethan Roscente.

"Mr. Roscente, will you be home for lunch?" she asked softly. After a pause, she nodded. "Understood."

As she hung up, Milo sidled over. "He's coming?"

"Yes." Jenna nodded. "Grandma Blanche too."

"Grandma Blanche?" Milo blinked. "Since when?"

"She called while I was shopping," Jenna explained. "She wants to see you."

Grandma Blanche had known about Milo's hospitalization but was away on a trip. She'd returned yesterday and, learning of Milo's discharge, decided to visit in person.
###Chapter 121

Jenna noticed Milo's wrinkled shirt and frowned slightly.

"Go change your clothes," she said softly.

Milo glanced down at himself and nodded before heading to his room.

In the kitchen, Jenna tied on her apron and checked the wall clock. The hands pointed to ten o'clock—she needed to hurry with lunch preparations.

The stove flame flickered to life as the spatula clinked against the wok.

Milo returned in fresh clothes and silently began washing vegetables.

Time slipped away in the busy kitchen, and soon it was noon.

The doorbell rang precisely at twelve.

"Milo, get the door," Jenna called without looking up from the stove.

Milo set down the dishcloth and strode to the foyer.

Ethan stood at the threshold in a crisp suit, with Grandma Blanche's warm smile glowing behind him.

"Please come in," Milo stepped aside.

Grandma Blanche inhaled deeply as she entered. "Something smells wonderful!"

Ethan's gaze swept the living room before he headed straight for the restroom.

Five steaming dishes already adorned the dining table.

"Jenna, your cooking is simply divine!" Grandma Blanche's eyes crinkled with delight.

Jenna emerged with the final dish, her hair slightly damp with perspiration.

"Lunch is ready," she murmured.

Grandma Blanche eagerly took her seat while Milo poured water for everyone.

"Ethan is truly blessed to have married you," Grandma Blanche praised between bites of braised pork.

Jenna's ears turned pink as she handed Ethan a bowl of rice.

"Thank you." His deep voice resonated.

Her fingers twitched, nearly dropping the bowl. It was the first time Ethan had thanked her.

"Try this," she quickly changed the subject, serving Milo a chicken wing.

Milo's eyes lit up. "You know me best."

Watching their sibling interaction, Grandma Blanche beamed even brighter. The dining room brimmed with cozy warmth—even Ethan's usual stern expression seemed to soften slightly.
###Chapter 122

Grandma Blanche picked up a morsel of food and glanced at Milo with concern. "Milo, how's your recovery going?"

Milo set down his chopsticks and answered politely, "Thank you for asking, Grandma Blanche. I'm feeling much better."

"If anything happens at school, you must tell me." Grandma Blanche patted the back of his hand. "I'll stand up for you."

Milo smiled faintly and nodded.

Grandma Blanche turned to Jenna. "Jenna, how was the matter resolved in the end?"

"The other party compensated for medical expenses and emotional damages." Jenna ladled soup into a bowl. "That student, Sheng Fei, publicly apologized to Milo."

Grandma Blanche hummed thoughtfully, hesitating as if she wanted to say more.

After dinner, Ethan unexpectedly stayed behind to help clear the table.

Jenna looked at him in surprise.

Grandma Blanche cheerfully led Milo to the living room to watch TV.

In the kitchen, Jenna turned on the faucet to wash dishes.

Ethan's tall figure stood beside her, his black suit amplifying his commanding presence.

"Did you need something, Mr. Roscente?" Jenna kept her head down as she spoke.

The water rushed loudly in the sink.

"Quit this job as soon as possible." Ethan's voice was cold.

Jenna's hands paused briefly. Her voice grew quieter. "Milo's surgery will cost nearly a hundred thousand..."

She needed the money.

Ethan had expected Jenna to ask for a loan, but she never did.

"Why not borrow from friends?" he asked instead.

Jenna gave a bitter smile. "That much money isn't a small sum. No one would lend me that kind of amount."

She didn’t want to be burdened with crushing debt.

"Grandma Blanche..." Ethan tested.

"Grandma Blanche lives on her pension. How could I ask her for money?" Jenna shook her head.

Only then did Ethan realize Jenna had no idea of their true identities.

Her closeness to Grandma Blanche wasn’t calculated.

Water droplets slid down the rim of a bowl. Ethan watched Jenna’s busy figure with a complicated expression.
###Chapter 123

Ethan cleared his throat, his fingers tapping lightly on the table.

"I know a renowned surgical specialist. Perhaps he could perform your brother's operation."

Jenna continued washing dishes, water cascading over the plates.

"The main issue isn't finding a doctor. It's the surgery fees."

Ethan's gaze flickered. "I can lend you the money."

"Don't joke." Jenna shook water droplets from her hands. "You just bought a new car and this house. Where would you get spare cash?"

She turned to place a bowl in the cabinet, her tone firm.

"Even if you had it, I wouldn't dare borrow."

Ethan frowned. "Why not?"

"Tens of thousands isn't small change." Jenna dried her hands. "I don't want that kind of pressure."

Ethan's voice lowered. "So you'll keep working at the club?"

"Yes." Jenna nodded. "The money's good there. A few more months should cover it."

Ethan fell silent. After a long look at her, he turned and left.

When Jenna finished cleaning the kitchen, only Grandma Blanche and Milo remained in the living room.

"Mr. Roscente went to the office," Grandma Blanche said cheerfully.

Jenna sent her brother to rest and chatted with the elderly woman.

At 3 PM, Jenna woke from her nap.

She rushed out to run errands, then returned to clean the apartment.

By the time she finished makeup and changed clothes, her shift was about to start.

"I'm leaving," she called out.

At Studio 54's entrance, Stella grabbed her arm.

"Sophia got fired!" Stella whispered. "Heard she had a huge fight with the boss."

Jenna paused. "When?"

"Two days ago." Stella leaned closer. "I bet it's about that last incident."

In the dressing room, Jenna changed while speaking. "Someone followed me the other night."

Stella froze, forgetting to change.

"What happened? Did you see their face?"

"Too dark. Just noticed a black cap." Jenna buttoned her top. "I think Sophia sent them."

Stella gasped, her fingers trembling slightly.
###Chapter 124

"Any other findings?" Stella pressed.

Jenna bit her lip, her fingers absently tracing the edge of her phone. "The stalker followed me all the way to the Beverly Hills gate. I wouldn't have noticed if the taxi driver hadn't pointed it out."

Stella gasped, her brows knitting together. "Who would dare?"

"Either the Rolands or Sophia's hired hand." Jenna smirked coldly. "Only those two have a grudge against me."

"You should report this!" Stella stomped her foot anxiously. "What if something happens?"

Jenna shook her head. "No evidence. If the police come and he denies it, we'll only alert him."

Stella chewed her nail thoughtfully before her eyes lit up. "Buy pepper spray! Carry it with you. If he shows up again, spray him!"

"Already ordered." Jenna waved her phone. "It'll arrive tomorrow."

"That's our Jenna!" Stella gave a thumbs-up.

Under the locker room lights, they quickly changed into work uniforms. Friday nights were always packed, and the manager had emphasized pushing premium drinks.

After the briefing, Stella pulled Jenna into a corner. "How's your brother doing?"

"He'll return to school on Monday." Jenna adjusted her collar when a knock interrupted them.

Patrick peeked in, his forehead glistening with sweat. "Jenna, Tony specifically asked for you."

"Where is he?" Jenna paused.

"VIP Room 308." Patrick lowered his voice. "The boss is in a good mood today. Be careful."

Pushing open the door, Jenna saw Tony Lombardi laughing with Fiona Valrose in his arms. Spotting her, he immediately released Fiona and patted the empty seat beside him.

"Long time no see, Tony." Jenna smiled as she sat down. "You look great."

"How can I not be happy? My wife's pregnant." Tony swirled his glass proudly.

Jenna turned to Fiona in surprise. "Congratulations!"

Fiona stiffened. "It's not me..."

The air in the room froze. Jenna blinked, then quickly recovered. "Oh! You mean Mrs. Lombardi is expecting? Congratulations, Tony!"
###Chapter 125

"Big sister-in-law?" Tony Lombardi blinked before chuckling. "Just call her sister-in-law, no need for the 'big'." He scratched his head. "I told her about you. Knowing you're busy, she asked me to invite you for lunch tomorrow."

He'd deliberately come to Studio 54 tonight—Saturday was perfect. First, to deliver the invitation. Second, to remind Jenna not to slip up in front of his wife.

Jenna Roland hesitated. "Tony, my brother just got discharged from the hospital. I need to take care of him. I really can't make it."

"You have a brother?" His brows furrowed.

"Yeah. Milo Roland. He's a high school sophomore."

"What happened?"

"He got into a fight defending me at school. Fractured ribs. Seven days in the hospital." She sighed. "I can't leave him alone."

Tony's temper flared at the mention of Milo's injuries. "Which bastard dared lay hands on my brother? Give me a name. I'll break his damn arm!"

Jenna hadn't expected this reaction. Or that Tony would claim Milo as his own.

"Tony, he's still in school. The other kid already apologized and paid compensation. Let it go."

"Damn it!" He gritted his teeth. "If it happens again, you call me immediately. I'll end him."

Jenna's eyes crinkled into crescents as she smiled. "Thank you. No one else stands up for us like you do."

He waved a hand, expression solemn. "Always wanted a little sister, but my parents failed me. Now that I've got you, you're family. Of course I'll protect you."

Suddenly, Jenna hugged him. He stiffened before returning the embrace, patting her shoulder with rough affection.

"Bring your brother tomorrow," he said when they parted. "My wife's a great cook. Let him try her food."

With the offer extended like this, refusal was impossible. "Alright."

Tony poured her a glass of water. "No more drinking when you're with me."

"Huh?" She froze.

"How much do you down entertaining clients? It's bad for you. Cut back when you can."

"Thanks, Tony." She raised the water glass like a toast, smiling brilliantly.

Her phone buzzed—a text from Stella Laurent. Tony glimpsed the screen and nudged her. "Go on. Don't worry about me."

"I'll come back after handling this."

"Go." His proud gaze followed her exit. Such a beautiful, capable little sister—his buddies would be green with envy.

Outside VIP Room 888, Jenna took a deep breath and pushed the door open.
###Chapter 126

The dim amber lighting cast long shadows across the private booth where two men sat facing each other.

The man in black drummed his slender fingers against the lacquered table. His chiseled profile looked particularly severe under the mood lighting, radiating an icy aura that seemed to freeze the very air around him.

This was Ethan Roscente—Jenna Roland's husband in name only.

Beside him, Gavin Valentine twirled his wineglass with bored indifference.

Jenna recalled Grandma Blanche's words: "He's just reserved by nature, but has a good heart."

Which decent man frequents nightclubs every day? she thought wryly.

"Good evening, Mr. Roscente, Mr. Valentine." Jenna gave a slight bow, her professional smile flawless.

Gavin arched an eyebrow. "Surprised to see us, Manager Roland?"

"Your patronage honors our establishment." Her smile didn't waver. "What would you like to drink tonight?"

Ethan lifted his gaze, eyes like shards of glacial ice. "Your most expensive vintage."

Jenna's pulse hitched. "The 1974 Romanée-Conti at $260,000 per bottle."

"Two." His tone was as casual as ordering tap water.

Her pupils contracted. This far exceeded their usual spending.

"Problem?" His voice dropped dangerously.

"Right away, sir." Smoothing her expression, she turned—but not before stealing another glance at Ethan.

He'd just bought a new car last week. Where was this sudden extravagance coming from?

"You're paying." Ethan's abrupt statement made Gavin fumble his glass.

"Excuse me?"

Ethan's eyes narrowed lethally.

Gavin gritted his teeth. "...Fine. My treat."

Catching the exchange from the corner of her eye, Jenna barely suppressed a gasp. Now that's what you call friendship goals.
###Chapter 127

The night deepened as Tristan Ashcroft saw off the last group of guests. He loosened his tie and stepped into the elevator.

Patrick Klein hurried over, lowering his voice. "Boss, Mr. Roscente and Mr. Valentine are in VIP Room 888. Guess what they ordered?"

Tristan didn't pause his stride. "The new vintage?"

"Exactly! The most expensive one!" Patrick couldn't hide his excitement. "Jenna Roland is truly our lucky charm!"

Tristan halted mid-step, a flicker of surprise crossing his eyes. He knew better than anyone—that particular wine wasn't even on the recommended list.

"Jenna served them?"

"Yes, it was her again." Patrick nodded eagerly.

After a brief silence, Tristan instructed, "Have the kitchen prepare two signature appetizers for them."

Inside VIP Room 888, Jenna had just finished pouring the wine.

Her phone vibrated. Glancing at the message, she excused herself discreetly.

When she returned, she carried two exquisite small plates.

Gavin Valentine straightened warily. "We didn't order this."

"Compliments of the house." Jenna set the plates down, her gaze briefly skimming over Ethan Roscente.

Once the door closed, Gavin immediately took a bite. "Since when did Tristan become so generous? He was never this hospitable before."

Ethan swirled his glass, the amber liquid catching the light. "Half a million spent, and we get two appetizers in return. Quite the bargain, don't you think?"

"Half a million?!" Gavin nearly leaped from his seat. "Ethan, are you trying to get me killed? My father will skin me alive!"

Ethan lit a cigarette leisurely, exhaling a slow stream of smoke. "The Hudson Yards project..."

Gavin instantly stilled, eyes gleaming.

"Come here once a week. Spend no less than half a million each time." Ethan blew a perfect smoke ring. "And the project is yours."

Gavin's mouth hung open, speechless.

Outside the window, neon lights flickered, casting a ghostly pallor over his face.
###Chapter 128

Ethan Roscente snapped out of his thoughts, his gaze settling on Gavin Valentine's face as his brows furrowed slightly.

"Reason?"

"Don't ask." Ethan's expression remained indifferent, his eyes devoid of any emotion.

Gavin's frown deepened.

Something was off. If Ethan really wanted to drink, he could've just asked Gavin to send a few bottles over. Why bother coming to a place like this?

With Ethan's status, there wasn't a single fine wine he hadn't tasted.

Gavin's eyes involuntarily drifted toward the bar.

Earlier, Ethan had ordered two bottles of Romanée-Conti in one go—the commission on that level of wine was substantial. Was this about Jenna Roland?

Gavin's pupils constricted, shock flashing across his face.

Could Ethan actually have feelings for Jenna?

His expression shifted unpredictably.

Ethan ignored him, picking up his glass and draining it in one go.

"Is this about Jenna?" Gavin leaned in, unable to hold back. "You into her? She is gorgeous. Need a wingman?"

Ethan had no intention of explaining, but to avoid misunderstandings, he spoke anyway. "Her brother's sick and needs surgery money. She refused to borrow it."

"Holy shit!" Gavin shot to his feet, eyes wide. "You actually like her?"

In his eyes, someone as cold as Ethan wouldn't go out of his way to help unless he had feelings for the person.

Ethan shot him an icy glare. "When did I say that?"

"Then why?" Gavin sat back down. "Everyone knows Ethan Roscente doesn't lift a finger unless there's something in it for him. You'd help someone for no reason?"

Ethan crushed the cigarette between his fingers and slammed his glass onto the table.

Gavin felt the chill and scooted away. "Just joking. Don't take it seriously."

"Made up your mind?" Ethan's gaze was razor-sharp.

Gavin forced a laugh. "For old times' sake, how about $260,000? That's exactly the price of one bottle."

Ethan's expression didn't waver. "Non-negotiable."
###Chapter 129

Gavin's lips twitched as he pressed his palms together in a pleading gesture toward Ethan, his face plastered with an ingratiating smile.

"Mr. Roscente, with your family's wealth, this petty cash must be nothing to you. But I'm broke—unemployed, living off my dad's measly $300,000 monthly allowance." He batted his eyelashes. "Cut me some slack. How about $260,000?"

His whining tone stretched like a spoiled puppy's.

Ethan didn't even glance up, taking a slow sip of his whiskey.

Gavin pouted.

The billion-dollar project would guarantee the Valentines massive profits.

$500,000 weekly expenses would total $7 million over three months.

"Ethan," he suddenly leaned in, "if you want to help Jenna, why not just give her the money? $7 million could set her and her brother up for life."

"Would you take it?" Ethan flicked cigarette ash.

"Damn right I would!"

"She's not you." A smoke ring drifted between them. "She'd refuse."

Gavin clawed at his hair. "But this way Tristan pockets everything! It's infuriating!"

Amid the haze, Ethan stubbed out his cigarette.

"I don't need your help anymore."

"Found another way?" Gavin's eyes lit up.

"Mhm."

"About the Hudson Yards project..." Gavin rubbed his hands.

Ethan swirled his glass. "HM Group's opening public bids. Tell your father to follow procedure."

Gavin's grin froze.

"However—" Ethan's tone shifted, "I'll give you a chance to redeem yourself."

"Name it!"

"Bring men to Studio 54 every night." Ethan's gaze turned glacial. "Guard Jenna. Keep the trash away."

Gavin gaped. "You actually like her?"

Ethan's stare could frost hell. "One more word, and Hudson Yards disappears."

Like her?

Ridiculous.

This was simply...atonement.
###Chapter 130

Gavin Valentine arched an eyebrow. "Fine, have it your way. I'll agree to your last condition."

He smirked inwardly. Ethan Roscente was such a hypocrite—clearly smitten with Jenna Roland yet refusing to admit it.

...

Studio 54 buzzed with its usual Friday night energy.

Jenna worked nonstop until 3 AM before finally catching her breath.

She hadn't even noticed when Ethan and Gavin left.

In the locker room, Jenna changed out of her uniform and bid Stella Laurent a quick goodbye before hurrying out.

The night air carried a chill as she scanned the street.

The familiar black Volkswagen Passat was nowhere in sight.

But she knew better. Her stalker was likely lurking in the shadows.

A taxi pulled up.

Jenna instructed the driver to take a detour.

Sure enough, the black sedan appeared in the rearview mirror, tailing them like a phantom.

The dim interior revealed only the silhouette of a driver in a black baseball cap.

Jenna clenched her fists.

Who was following her?

Someone sent by Sophia Merouin?

"Pull over here, please," she suddenly said.

The moment the taxi stopped, the trailing car halted too.

Jenna tried enlisting the driver's help, but fear held him back.

Considering the stalker might be armed, she settled for memorizing the license plate and directed the cab to the police station.

The black sedan maintained its distance the entire way, only peeling off when they reached the precinct.

"Where to now, miss?" the driver asked.

Jenna stared at the retreating taillights. "Wait a moment longer."

Once certain the coast was clear, she gave her Beverly Hills address.

"Look, I'd help if I could," the driver sighed. "But I've got a family to think about. You should file a report—a young woman like you can't be too careful."

Jenna nodded understandingly and stayed silent.

...

A shrill ringtone yanked Jenna from sleep.

Blinking groggily, she fumbled for her phone. Tony Lombardi's name flashed onscreen.

"Tony?" Her voice was thick with sleep.

"Still in bed?" His tone held exasperation.

"Mmm... What's up?"

"We agreed you'd bring Milo for lunch today. Just making sure you didn't forget."

Jenna bolted upright.

"Oh God! It completely slipped my mind!" She raked fingers through tangled hair. "Text me the address—we'll leave right away."

The location pinged through moments after they hung up.
###Chapter 131

Jenna emerged from her bedroom dressed and found Milo curled up on the couch watching TV.

"Sis, you stayed up so late last night. Why are you up so early?" Milo looked up in surprise.

She sat beside him and recounted everything about recognizing a gang leader as her sworn brother at the club.

"He invited us to lunch at his place today," she added.

Milo's brows knitted together. "Is he genuinely treating you as a sister or does he have ulterior motives?"

That club was a shady place, and he couldn't help feeling uneasy.

"He's from the underworld." Jenna chuckled. "At first I thought he was bad news too, but he's actually been really kind to me. That night he not only gave me money for late-night snacks but also ordered the most expensive liquor in the club."

"What?" Milo nearly jumped up. "Underworld? Are you insane?"

"Don't judge by appearances." Jenna glared. "He's been genuinely good to me."

"You just said he seemed shady!" Milo scoffed. "Talk about double standards."

She rolled her eyes. "I trust him. Are you coming or not?"

"I'm still worried he might have bad intentions."

"Oh, by the way, his wife is pregnant and currently on bed rest."

"...Fine." Milo reluctantly nodded.

Jenna's lips twitched. "Unbelievable. I'm going to wash up."

After finishing her makeup, they took a cab straight to the Malibu Beach House.

During the ride, Jenna first called Ethan. "Mr. Roscente, my brother and I are going out for lunch today. Please arrange your own meal."

"Mmm." The icy response came through before the line went dead.

She rubbed her arms. Ethan had always been like this—she should be used to it by now.

Next, she dialed Officer Hill. "Officer Hill, could you help me check a license plate number?"

"Why do you need that?" His tone turned stern.

Jenna tightened her grip on her phone. She knew the request was presumptuous, but for safety's sake, she had to verify this gang leader's identity.
###Chapter 132

Jenna quickly pressed send, forwarding the license plate number to Officer Hill.

"Officer Hill said he'll look into it." She pocketed her phone, brows slightly furrowed.

Milo grabbed her wrist. "Jenna, what's going on?"

"A car's been following me since last week." She pulled her hand free. "Twice now. I only lost them by driving to the police station."

Milo's face paled. "Why didn't you tell me sooner?"

"What could you have done?" Jenna glanced at her younger brother's slender frame.

"I could've picked you up!" His voice rose an octave.

Jenna shook her head. "You have classes."

"That doesn't mean you should take risks alone!" Milo clenched his fists. "What good will a license plate number do?"

"At least we'll know who's behind this." Her eyes turned icy. "I bet Sophia's involved."

"Sophia?" Milo looked confused.

Jenna gave him a quick rundown of their feud.

"That witch!" Milo kicked the tire in frustration. "Why can't she fight fair?"

"If she had the guts for a direct confrontation, things would be simpler." Jenna smirked.

An hour later, their taxi stopped at a Malibu beach house.

Milo gaped at the ornate wrought-iron gates. "Damn, sis. Your brother-in-law must be loaded."

Jenna pressed the doorbell. "Behave yourself inside."

A kindly housekeeper answered. "Miss Roland?" Nanny Florence ushered them in. "The master has been expecting you."

The living room was spacious enough for badminton. Crystal chandeliers dazzled overhead.

Milo sank into the buttery leather couch, whispering, "This place costs a fortune..."

"Study hard and you might afford it someday." Jenna flicked his forehead.

Rubbing his head, Milo grinned. "Books won't cut it. I need to go into business!"

"You'll need startup capital first." Jenna glanced around when footsteps echoed from the staircase.
###Chapter 133

Milo shrugged, a hint of resignation flashing in his eyes.

"Hard work can't compete with being born lucky. These days, luck matters more than education when it comes to getting rich."

He thought of Ethan Roscente's example. Without that stroke of luck, even with all his talent, Ethan would never have become the head of HM Group.

Jenna chuckled and patted her brother's shoulder.

"You're right. But luck alone isn't enough to keep you standing. You need both luck and skill."

Milo dodged her hand, a smirk playing on his lips.

"Don't worry, sis. I won't let you down."

"Good." Jenna blinked. "Our future mansion depends on you."

Just then, Nanny Florence ushered in Tony Lombardi and his wife Wendy.

The siblings quickly stood to greet them.

Tony beamed, none of his usual sharpness present.

"Wendy, this is Jenna Roland, the sister I just adopted. And this is her brother Milo."

Wendy studied Jenna with gentle eyes.

"Hello, I'm Wendy Lombardi, Tony's wife. You can call me sis."

Jenna was surprised. She'd expected disdain given her background.

Instead, Wendy seemed genuinely warm, even eager to bridge the gap.

"Hello, sis." Jenna gave a slight bow.

Wendy's gaze shifted to Milo, admiration flickering in her eyes.

"You two are so good-looking. Your parents must be stunning."

"They're alright." Jenna said modestly.

Wendy waved a hand. "Let's not stand on ceremony."

She turned to Nanny Florence. "Go prepare lunch."

The nanny nodded and withdrew.

Wendy smiled apologetically. "I wanted to cook myself, but I'm not feeling well today. I'll make it up to you next time."

"Don't trouble yourself, sis. Health comes first." Jenna said considerately.

Suddenly, she suggested, "How about I cook instead?"

Wendy raised an eyebrow. "You can cook?"

Milo interjected proudly, "My sister's an amazing cook."

"Then we're in for a treat today." Wendy rose with a smile. "Let me show you the kitchen."

Jenna quickly protested, "You should rest. I can find my way."

"It's just a few steps." Wendy insisted, leading the way.

The two women disappeared into the kitchen.

Watching them go, Tony's heart suddenly leaped into his throat.

......

In the kitchen, Wendy instructed Nanny Florence, "Let Jenna take charge. You assist her."

The nanny bowed respectfully.

Wendy added, "Tell her what dishes to make."

With everything arranged, Jenna picked up a chef's knife and began expertly handling the ingredients.
###Chapter 134

Jenna Roland assumed Wendy Lombardi would leave after questioning her. But the woman remained rooted behind her.

Wendy had claimed pregnancy nausea made her sensitive to cooking smells. Yet she lingered in the kitchen now.

Jenna's grip tightened around the chef's knife.

The blade struck the cutting board in rhythmic thuds.

"Jenna, does your brother frequent Studio 54 often?" Wendy's voice came from behind.

The knife stilled.

Here it comes.

She resumed dicing bell peppers without turning. "I've only worked there two weeks. Saw him twice - first when he claimed me as his sister, then last night's dinner invite."

Wendy chuckled. "Don't overthink it. I just worry about him. Hot-tempered men need watching."

Jenna's lips twitched.

Pathetic excuse.

Tony Lombardi was famously henpecked at home.

"Brother does have a short fuse. You should keep him in check." Jenna turned with an angelic smile.

"Naturally." Wendy stepped closer. "Does he bring company to the club?"

Jenna set down the knife and faced her directly.

"Never seen him with anyone."

Their gazes locked in silent combat.

Wendy narrowed her eyes, searching for cracks in Jenna's composure.

The younger woman's expression remained guileless.

"Since you call me sister-in-law, we're family." Wendy suddenly beamed. "If he steps out of line, you'll tell me."

"Of course." Jenna nodded sweetly.

Her back was damp with cold sweat.

Thank God Tony had warned her beforehand.

Wendy gave her a lingering look before exiting.

The kitchen door clicked shut. Jenna exhaled sharply.

She picked up the knife again. The bell peppers lay in mangled ruins.
###Chapter 135

Wendy Lombardi lounged lazily on the leather sofa, her slender legs crossed. Her diamond-studded pink manicure glittered under the lights.

Tony Lombardi hurried over with an exquisite bone china bowl filled with freshly made tremella soup. "Sweetheart, drink it while it's hot." He offered it carefully, his face plastered with an ingratiating smile.

Milo Roland stood nearby, his eyes wide. This usually imposing tough guy now resembled a fawning puppy.

"The kitchen's full of fumes. You shouldn't go there while pregnant." Tony's rough hands gently massaged Wendy's calves.

Wendy's red lips curved slightly. "I was just chatting with Jenna in the kitchen."

Tony's hands froze. Beads of sweat formed on his forehead.

"Tony Lombardi." Wendy's gaze turned icy. "You know my rules. If I find another woman around you..." Her fingertip traced his Adam's apple. "I'll make her disappear without a trace."

Milo sucked in a sharp breath. This woman was as beautiful as a rose—with equally deadly thorns.

"I swear on my life!" Tony raised three fingers. "You're the only one I'll ever love!" He discreetly wiped his sweat, silently grateful Jenna had kept her mouth shut.

Wendy shoved the empty bowl back into Tony's hands. "Get Milo a bowl too."

"No need, sis—" Milo waved his hands hastily.

"Summer heat causes inflammation." Wendy's eyes gleamed. "Tremella nourishes the lungs."

Tony fled to the kitchen like a pardoned convict. He patted his chest in relief—thank God he'd warned Jenna beforehand, or he'd be skinned alive today.

Aromatic scents wafted from the dining room. Jenna removed her apron and called out, "Tony, Wendy, dinner's ready."

"So soon?" Wendy arched a brow.

"Nanny Florence helped me." Jenna smiled, pulling out a chair.

Wendy rose gracefully, her skirt swishing in a perfect arc. "Then I must taste it properly." Her stilettos clicked sharply against the floor as she strode toward the dining room.
###Chapter 136

Tony Lombardi and Milo Roland followed closely behind as they headed to the dining room.

Wendy Lombardi and Tony froze when they saw the lavish spread on the table.

Wendy's eyes widened in disbelief. "Jenna, did you make all this by yourself?"

Jenna Roland smiled softly. "Yes, sis. Go ahead and try it. Let me know what you think."

Tony and Wendy exchanged glances, stunned by Jenna's culinary skills.

Every dish was beautifully presented, with mouthwatering aromas that rivaled a professional chef's work.

Wendy eagerly took her seat, accepting the chopsticks Tony handed her. She picked up a piece of braised fish.

The moment the fish touched her tongue, her eyes lit up. "Oh my God, this is incredible!"

Jenna blushed. "If you like it, I can come cook for you more often."

"That's a promise!" Wendy beamed. "If you don't show up, I'll have your brother pester you every day."

Jenna nodded. "Deal."

The table was laden with delicacies—steamed sea bass, sweet and sour ribs, and Milo's favorite cola chicken wings.

The meal was a joyous occasion. Even Wendy, who usually only ate one bowl of rice, went for seconds.

Tony devoured three full bowls, leaving Nanny Florence speechless.

The housekeeper marveled silently. In all her years of service, she'd never seen the family enjoy a meal this much.

After dinner, Wendy went upstairs and returned with two thick red envelopes.

She handed one to Jenna and the other to Milo. "This is a little something from your brother and me for your first visit."

Jenna immediately protested. "Sis, we can't accept this."

Tony frowned. "What, do you not consider us family?"

Milo shook his head. "Bro, sis, we appreciate the gesture, but we really can't take this."

Tony's expression darkened. "If you refuse again, I'll be offended."

The envelopes were visibly stuffed with cash.

Jenna and Milo exchanged glances, torn between gratitude and discomfort.
###Chapter 137

Jenna Roland clutched the thick red envelope, its weight heavy against her fingertips.

It was the first time since their parents' death that someone had given them a gift like this.

Tony Lombardi and Wendy Lombardi's gesture made Jenna's eyes grow slightly moist.

"Tony, we really can't accept this." Jenna pushed the envelope back. "You've already helped us so much."

She thought of the $20,000 transfer and last night's bottle of Romanée-Conti.

Tony frowned. "It's tradition for first-time guests."

Wendy laughed and tucked the envelope into Jenna's hand. "Consider it a welcome gift. No arguments."

Milo Roland discreetly squeezed the envelope, its thickness making his pulse quicken.

"Thank you, Tony. Thank you, Wendy." The boy lowered his head shyly.

Tony suddenly pulled a gold-embossed business card from the coffee table drawer.

"Take this." He handed it to Milo. "If anyone gives you trouble, call this number."

Milo accepted the card, his fingers trembling slightly.

He understood the power this card represented.

"Jenna, you should rest." Tony turned to her. "You have work tonight."

Jenna hesitated, glancing at Wendy. "Wendy... you don't mind that I work at the club?"

Wendy burst out laughing. "I was wilder than you at your age."

She linked arms with Jenna affectionately. "There's no shame in earning an honest living."

Jenna finally relaxed into a smile.

Watching her brother carefully tuck away the business card, she felt a long-lost sense of security.

For the first time in years, they weren't alone in this world anymore.
###Chapter 138

Jenna's instincts told her there was more to the story.

The corner of Jenna's lips curled into a faint smile. "Alright, then. Wendy, Tony, it's getting late. We should head out."

"Be careful on your way home," Wendy said, turning to Tony. "See them out, will you?"

"Of course." Tony stood and escorted Jenna and Milo to the door.

Standing on the villa's front steps, Tony asked, "How did you get here? Did you drive?"

"We took a cab," Jenna replied, pulling her coat tighter.

Tony immediately called his driver.

Within ten minutes, Charlie arrived with the car.

Tony watched until the siblings were safely inside before returning indoors.

The moment Jenna stepped into her apartment, her phone rang.

"Did you make it home?" Tony's voice came through the receiver.

"Just got in." Jenna collapsed onto the couch, exhaustion washing over her. She stifled a yawn.

"Tired?" Tony caught the sound instantly.

"A little." She rubbed her eyes. "You didn't call just to check if I got home, did you?"

A low chuckle sounded on the other end. "You know me too well. I wanted to ask—what did Wendy talk to you about in the kitchen?"

Jenna's gaze sharpened. Just as she'd suspected.

"She asked if there were other women in your life." Jenna didn't mince words.

"What did you say?" Tony's tone grew tense.

"I said no." Her voice turned icy. "Tony, Wendy treats you so well, and she's pregnant. You shouldn't be messing around. Do you have any idea how devastated she'd be if she found out?"

Silence stretched between them.

"I understand," Tony finally said. "I promise I won't betray her trust again."

"Remember your words." Jenna emphasized each syllable. "Don't agree with me now only to go running back to Fiona Valrose."

"Don't worry. Get some rest. Goodnight."

She hung up and went straight to bed.

When she woke, it was already 4 PM.

Since starting at Studio 54, her sleep schedule had shifted dramatically. Back at her uncle's place, six hours had been enough. Now she needed at least eight, or she'd feel groggy all day.

Yawning, Jenna stepped out of her room to find Milo counting red envelopes on the couch.

"How much?" she asked with a smile.

His eyes sparkled. "Twelve grand! They're really generous."

Remembering how Tony splurged at the club, Jenna scoffed. "He's got money to burn, that's for sure."
###Chapter 139

A bitter smile tugged at Ethan Roscente's lips.

He should have known.

In her heart, he would never measure up to Miles Valentine. Now, he couldn't even compare to a mere maid.

What was he still hoping for?

Time and again, the truth stared him in the face—he meant nothing to her.

Why humiliate himself further?

"Ethan—" Jenna Roland moved to follow him.

Liam Hill grabbed her arm. "Princess! The Duke's injuries need tending!"

"He smells of Chloe's medicine!" Jenna's eyes burned. "Chloe's missing!"

Liam remained level-headed. "The Duke wouldn't harm Chloe."

"How can you be so sure?"

"Princess," Liam sighed, "you're being reckless tonight."

Jenna sheathed her sword.

She had lost control.

Now, clarity returned—Ethan would never hurt Chloe.

But that faint medicinal scent didn't lie.

They'd crossed paths.

"I'm finding her." Jenna turned toward the exit.

Liam stepped forward.

"Pack our things," she ordered without looking back. "Be ready to leave."

If Chloe had truly gone to assassinate Sophia or Vanessa...

Attempting to kill a royal heir meant execution in Nanjin Palace.

She had to prepare for the worst.

Ethan's chambers.

Nathan Watson set down the medical kit. "Your Grace—"

"Send Zachary to locate that maid."

"Chloe's really vanished?"

"She wounded Vanessa's attendant and disappeared." Ethan clenched his fists. "Prepare to depart. If she's in danger, we break her out and leave immediately."

Nathan paled. "Your Grace would storm the dungeons?"

For a maid? Abandoning everything in Nanjin?

Even forsaking the Duchess?
###Chapter 140

Jenna Roland gripped her phone, her knuckles turning white.

Officer Liam Hill's words made her heart race.

Sophia Merouin was actually involved with that kind of person?

She took a deep breath and quickly scrolled through Stella Laurent's social media.

The group photo surfaced almost immediately.

In the picture, Sophia was beaming, showing no signs of association with underworld thugs.

"Officer Hill, the one on the right is Sophia Merouin."

After sending the message, Jenna mechanically ate her noodles.

Each bite tasted like cardboard.

While washing dishes, her phone remained silent.

Police work was indeed demanding.

Before leaving, Milo Roland gave her a concerned look.

"Jenna, you don't look well."

"Just tired, probably."

The wind outside Studio 54 was chilly.

Liam's call came abruptly.

"It's her." His voice was firm. "Byron Valdemar runs an auto shop now but still has ties to the underworld."

A cold sweat broke out on Jenna's back.

That stalker...

"You didn't see his face?"

"It was too dark."

"Try to get a photo. If it's Byron, call the police immediately."

The moment the call ended, Tristan Ashcroft appeared in her line of sight.

"Why are you standing outside?"

"Just got off the phone." Jenna hesitated. "Tristan, do you know Sophia Merouin well?"

His expression froze.

"Why the sudden question?"

Jenna explained everything.

Tristan's face darkened with each word.

"You were stalked?" His voice sharpened. "Are you hurt?"

"I lost him at the police station."

His shoulders relaxed slightly, but his gaze remained razor-sharp.

This was someone Ethan Roscente had personally entrusted to him.

Nothing could happen to her.
###Chapter 141

Tristan Ashcroft crossed his arms, his sharp gaze fixed on Jenna Roland. "Did you get a good look at who was following you?"

Jenna shook her head. "It was too dark. I couldn't see their face."

"I'll look into it," Tristan said grimly. "Be careful. If it happens again, call me immediately."

"But they were in a car. Will your people get there in time?"

"Just stall them," Tristan explained. "Call me with your location. My team will handle the rest."

Jenna nodded.

Tristan pulled out his phone and dialed Sophia Merouin without hesitation.

The call connected quickly.

"Sophia, did you send someone to follow Jenna?" Tristan's voice was ice-cold.

Jenna's heart skipped a beat.

She hadn't expected Tristan to confront Sophia directly. They'd already had a falling out—Sophia had quit long ago.

"Jenna told you?" Sophia's voice dripped with venomous hatred.

"Answer the question," Tristan demanded, his tone even colder.

Sophia scoffed. "Go ahead and call the police. What can you do without proof?"

"So it was you."

Suddenly, Sophia shifted tactics. "You care about her that much? Do you like her?"

Tristan ended the call abruptly.

"It's Sophia," he said, turning back to Jenna.

The police had traced the license plate to Byron Valdemar—Sophia's boyfriend.

After a moment of silence, Jenna decided to come clean.

"Boss, there's something you need to know."

"Speak."

"When Sophia was with you, she was already dating Byron Valdemar. He owns an auto repair shop." Jenna met Tristan's eyes steadily. "The car that followed me belongs to him."

"What?!"

Tristan froze as if struck by lightning.

Jenna repeated herself.

Tristan's temples throbbed with rage. He remembered all the money he'd given Sophia—now he realized it had all gone straight into Byron's pockets!

That damn woman!

She'd been using his money to fund her affair?

Furious, Tristan dialed Sophia's number again.
###Chapter 142

The phone rang abruptly.

Sophia had just picked up a piece of salmon with her chopsticks when she saw the caller ID. The utensils clattered onto the table.

"Tristan Ashcroft?" She hesitated before answering.

"Sophia, you bitch!" Tristan's furious roar exploded through the receiver. "Is Byron your boyfriend? How fucking dare you lie to me?"

Her fingers turned ice-cold.

Instinctively, she glanced at Byron sitting across from her. He was calmly cutting his steak.

"I..." Her throat tightened.

Byron noticed her discomfort. "Who is it?" he asked.

The private dining room was eerily silent. Tristan clearly heard the male voice.

Sophia fumbled to end the call.

"It's over..." Her face paled. "Tristan knows about us."

Byron leisurely lit a cigarette.

Through the haze of smoke, he narrowed his eyes. "So what? What are you afraid of?"

She clenched the napkin in her fist.

The thought of Tristan's connections sent chills down her spine.

"You don't understand him..." Her voice trembled. "If he finds out we've been deceiving him all this time..."

Byron scoffed and flicked the ash from his cigarette.

"What can he do to you now?" He exhaled a smoke ring. "Remember, you're not working at his club anymore."

......

Outside Studio 54.

Jenna Roland took one look at Tristan's livid expression and her stomach dropped.

"Boss..." she ventured cautiously.

The veins on Tristan's hand bulged as he gripped his phone.

"That man was Byron Valdemar," he spat through gritted teeth. "I heard his voice."

Jenna stayed silent.

She watched as Tristan dialed another number.

"Zachary, find Sophia's address," Tristan's voice was glacial. "And dig up everything on that Byron Valdemar. I want every detail."

After hanging up, he turned to Jenna.

"Stay alert," he warned. "If you notice anyone following you, contact me immediately."

Jenna nodded vigorously. "Understood, boss."

A cold night breeze swept past, making her shiver involuntarily.
###Chapter 143

Jenna Roland pushed open the doors of Studio 54, her stilettos clicking sharply against the marble floor.

She had just finished a staff meeting and immediately dragged Stella Laurent into a secluded corner.

"I've got some piping hot tea to spill," Jenna whispered, her eyes gleaming with excitement.

Stella arched an eyebrow. "What's so juicy?"

"That bitch Sophia Merouin has been secretly dating some young hunk named Byron Valdemar behind Ethan's back!" Jenna hissed through gritted teeth.

"Holy shit!" Stella gasped, her manicured nails nearly digging into her palms.

Who would've thought the seemingly innocent Sophia was playing such dangerous games?

"Ethan's already investigating them," Jenna gloated, waving her phone. "Once he gets solid proof, those two are done for."

Stella nodded vigorously. "With Ethan's temper, he'll skin them alive."

"Shh—" Jenna suddenly glanced around warily. "This stays between us. If word gets out and embarrasses Ethan..."

"Got it." Stella mimed zipping her lips. "But speaking of which, all those limited-edition bags he gave her..."

Their gossip session was interrupted when the glass doors swung open. Gavin Valentine entered with two unfamiliar men, his tailored suit accentuating his broad shoulders and narrow waist.

"Mr. Valentine." Jenna instantly switched to her professional smile. "Not joining Mr. Roscente today?"

Gavin smirked. "Miss him already?"

Jenna's smile froze.

"Just kidding." Gavin smoothly changed the subject, gesturing to his companions. "This is Xavier Lefèvre and Ronan Abendroth."

Both men gave curt nods. The one in the black shirt had well-defined muscles, while the gray T-shirt guy radiated an icy aura.

"Booth 309." Gavin flashed a black card between his fingers.

As Jenna led them upstairs, she couldn't shake the feeling of being watched. When she returned downstairs after delivering their drinks, she nearly collided with Tristan Ashcroft.

"Is Mr. Roscente here?" Tristan stopped her abruptly.
###Chapter 144

Jenna Roland shook her head lightly. "Only Mr. Valentine and his friend are here."

"Which private room?"

"309."

Tristan Ashcroft nodded and instructed Jenna to fetch the wine before heading straight to Room 309.

He pushed the door open to find Gavin Valentine lounging on the sofa, legs crossed. Spotting Tristan, Gavin grinned. "Boss Ashcroft, long time no see!"

Tristan took a seat beside him. "No need for formalities."

"Shouldn't I call you 'boss' in your own club?" Gavin swirled his wine glass.

Tristan chuckled. "Suit yourself."

Gavin's smile suddenly faded as he turned serious. "Mr. Roscente has instructed that all our expenses here go on his tab."

"I know. His assistant called this morning."

Gavin narrowed his eyes. "Miss Roland is Mr. Roscente's most cherished person. If anything happens to her here..."

"Most cherished?" Tristan frowned. "Are they together?"

Gavin smirked meaningfully. "That's unclear. But Mr. Roscente has been particularly attentive to her lately. You understand."

Tristan's gaze shifted to the two unfamiliar faces in the room. "And these gentlemen?"

"My bodyguards," Gavin said casually. "Here specifically to protect Miss Roland."

Tristan's heart skipped a beat. Sending bodyguards? Ethan Roscente must truly value Jenna.

Just then, Jenna entered with the wine.

The conversation in the room halted abruptly.

Gavin smoothly changed the subject. "Business has been good lately, Boss Ashcroft?"

"Not bad." But Tristan's eyes remained fixed on Jenna.

There was something undeniably special about her—not just her beauty, but her poised demeanor. No wonder even someone like Ethan Roscente treated her differently.

Jenna expertly poured the wine and raised her glass. "Mr. Valentine, Mr. Lefèvre, Mr. Abendroth, a toast to your enjoyment."

She downed the drink in one go, exchanged a few pleasantries, then turned to leave.
###Chapter 145

Saturday night pulsed with restless energy. The club throbbed with laughter and clinking glasses.

Jenna Roland navigated between private rooms in stiletto heels. Champagne flutes cast fractured light across her path.

By 3 AM, the last patrons finally departed.

She massaged her aching ankles, fingertips still carrying the rich aroma of red wine.

The dressing room mirror reflected her exhaustion. Smudged eyeliner framed her weary eyes.

"Stella, I'm heading out," she called toward the lounge.

Night air greeted her with the first chill of early autumn.

The taxi glided past neon-lit streets. In the rearview mirror, a black Volkswagen Passat maintained steady pursuit.

Her phone screen illuminated. Liam Hill's contact topped her recent calls list.

Her finger hovered momentarily before selecting Tristan Ashcroft's name instead.

"Boss, that car's back."

The clink of crystal echoed through the receiver. Tristan's voice carried a whiskey warmth. "Text me the plate number."

The driver studied her through the mirror. "Miss, should I call the police?"

"No." She tightened her grip on the phone. "Take Sunset Boulevard instead."

Park Avenue's flickering streetlights revealed the black sedan maintaining precise distance.

A sudden vibration. An unknown number flashed on her screen.

"Miss Roland, we're in position."

Two blinding headlights appeared in the rearview, boxing in the Volkswagen.
###Chapter 146

"Six men, all armed." The voice on the phone was low and grim.

"Understood." Jenna Roland's reply was clipped.

She turned to the driver. "Pull over at the park up ahead."

The driver's grip on the wheel tightened. "Pay the fare first. I'm leaving the moment you step out."

"Fine."

Jenna understood his caution. These days, no one wanted trouble.

The taxi screeched to a halt at the park entrance.

The moment Jenna's feet touched the pavement, the cab sped away, its taillights painting red streaks in the darkness.

Within a minute, a black Volkswagen Passat rolled to a stop before her.

Jenna's hand slid into her bag, fingers closing around the pepper spray.

The door opened. A tall man in a baseball cap emerged. Beneath the brim, his eyes glinted with malice.

Two more men climbed out from the backseat—one with a buzz cut, the other with bleached hair and grotesque tattoos snaking down his arms.

Then came a woman.

Jenna's pupils contracted.

Sophia Merouin.

So she was behind the stalking.

"Long time no see, Jenna." Sophia sauntered forward in stilettos, crimson lips curling into a sneer.

Just then, two SUVs roared onto the scene.

Six hulking men swiftly surrounded Sophia's group.

Her face paled. "You set me up?"

Jenna brandished the pepper spray with a cold smile. "Did you really think I'd come alone?"

Realization dawned on Sophia. Her expression turned ashen.

The bleached-haired thug foolishly spat, "Back off if you know what's good for you!"

Without hesitation, Ryan Casstevensa drew his gun and fired at the man's thigh.

BANG!

The gunshot shattered the night.

The thug crumpled, howling as he clutched his leg.

The buzz-cut man barely twitched before another bullet tore through his kneecap.

Sophia stumbled back in terror, her heels twisting as she fell hard onto the pavement.

Ryan's 6'3" frame loomed like an iron tower, wisps of smoke curling from his gun barrel.
###Chapter 147

Jenna Roland's pupils constricted sharply.

Six pitch-black handguns were trained on her in unison, their metallic surfaces glinting coldly under the streetlights.

Tristan Ashcroft's men actually carried firearms—a serious felony in this country.

Ryan Casstevensa's gaze was razor-sharp as it pinned Sophia Merouin. "Was trailing Miss Roland your idea?"

Sophia's face turned ashen, her lips trembling. "N-no... It wasn't me..."

"She ordered it!" Jenna stated with absolute conviction.

Sophia shuddered violently, nearly collapsing to the ground.

She let out a hysterical scream. "Jenna! What good would my death do you?"

"Plenty." Jenna's laugh was icy. "At least no one would stalk me anymore. But—" Her tone shifted abruptly, "Murder's illegal. I won't let you die."

Though she loathed Sophia, she wouldn't go so far as to take a life.

Ryan exchanged a glance with Xavier Lefèvre. "Tie them up."

Xavier swiftly holstered his gun and retrieved ropes from the trunk.

Within moments, Sophia and her two accomplices were bound tightly.

"This is kidnapping!" Sophia thrashed wildly. "I'll call the police!"

Jenna scoffed. "Now you care about the law? Did you consider consequences when having me followed?"

Venomous hatred flashed in Sophia's eyes.

This bitch had cost her everything—her wealthy patron, her status, everything!

"Take them away," Ryan commanded.

Jenna stopped him. "Where are you taking them?"

"The boss wants to see them." Ryan lowered his voice. "Tristan Ashcroft."

Understanding dawned on Jenna.

Sophia had been two-timing Tristan and Byron Valdemar, even using her patron's money to fund her side piece.

What man would tolerate such humiliation?

"I'll drive you back." Ryan opened the car door.

Jenna gave the name of a Beverly Hills neighborhood, keeping her voice deliberately soft.

The black sedan glided soundlessly into the night.
###Chapter 148

Dawn's first light filtered through the curtains as Tristan Ashcroft awoke.

Cold water droplets traced the sharp angles of his face in the bathroom mirror.

His white robe hung loosely, revealing a sculpted chest beneath.

In the living room, he dialed Ryan Casstevensa's number.

"Did you find them?"

"Boss, Sophia and the others are already at the ranch."

Tristan ended the call, his black dress shirt accentuating his broad shoulders and narrow waist.

Butler Raymond approached with a coffee tray. "Young master, breakfast is—"

"Not needed."

The black Bugatti sliced through the morning light like a blade.

Deseret Ranch sprawled across the outskirts, purchased by Tristan for a staggering sum three years prior.

Tall walls shielded the property from prying eyes, creating an oasis of silence.

Gravel crunched beneath tires, startling sparrows pecking at the ground.

By the wooden cabin, Ryan trimmed roses with a cigarette dangling from his lips.

"Boss."

The interior fell silent as men snapped to attention.

Tristan's gaze swept across them. "Lead the way."

Behind the chicken coop, a hidden cellar door exhaled damp mildew into the morning air.

In the dim glow, Sophia Merouin shivered in a bound chair.

"Boss!" Her voice cracked. "I can explain—"

Tristan seized her chin. "Using my money to fund your lover?"

Kevin Heilbronn struggled against his restraints until Xavier Lefèvre's boot sent him sprawling.

"How long did you think you could hide Byron's involvement?"

Sophia's nails bit into her palms, her face bloodless.

Releasing her, Tristan methodically wiped his fingers with a handkerchief.

"I despise betrayal." His eyes glinted like frost in moonlight as he turned. "Especially from greedy little vipers."

The cellar door slammed shut, swallowing Sophia's sobs.
###Chapter 149

Sophia Merouin was tied to a chair, her face swollen and bruised. Blood trickled from the corner of her mouth. She looked up at Tristan Ashcroft with bloodshot eyes filled with terror.

"Boss, I've been loyal to you all these years!" Her voice trembled as tears streamed down her cheeks. "I swear, if I'm lying, may I die a horrible death!"

Tristan stood before her, impeccably dressed in a tailored suit. His gaze was icy cold. Slowly, he removed his Patek Philippe watch and handed it to Ryan Casstevensa.

"We've checked everything." His voice was soft, yet it made Sophia shiver. "Jenna Roland talked."

Ryan wordlessly untied the ropes binding Sophia. The moment she was free, she collapsed to her knees and clung to Tristan's leg.

"Boss!" she wailed. "After all these years of serving you, don't I deserve some mercy?"

Tristan looked down at her, a cold smirk curling his lips. He kicked her away without hesitation.

"Do it." His order was brief.

Leon Massies and Ronan Abendroth stepped forward. Sophia screamed and tried to scramble away, but Leon yanked her back by the hair. Fists rained down on her until her face was unrecognizable.

Kevin Heilbronn stood in the corner, his face pale. He watched as Sophia coughed up blood, his legs shaking uncontrollably.

"Mr. Ashcroft!" he suddenly shouted. "Sophia and Byron Valdemar have been together for eight years! She used your money to buy him a car and open a shop! They were the ones who ordered Jenna to be followed!"

Sophia's head snapped up, blood obscuring her stunned expression. She glared at Kevin with pure hatred.

"You—" she spat through gritted teeth. "Byron treated you like a brother!"

Kevin flinched, his voice trembling. "I... I'm just telling the truth..."

Tristan's eyes darkened. He walked slowly toward Sophia and stepped on her fingers with his leather shoe.

Sophia let out a piercing scream.

"Cut off her thumb." Tristan's voice was eerily calm. "Then break her legs."

Sophia shook her head frantically, dragging herself backward. "No! Boss, I was wrong! I'll do anything!"

Tristan turned and walked toward the exit without looking back. "Do it."

Ryan pulled a gleaming dagger from his suit pocket and advanced on Sophia. Her screams echoed through the empty warehouse, like a dying animal caught in a trap.
###Chapter 150

Tristan Ashcroft's gaze was like a poisoned ice blade, piercing straight into Kevin Heilbronn's soul. "After successfully tailing Jenna Roland, what were your plans for her?"

Kevin's legs trembled. Cold sweat beaded on his forehead. His eyes darted to Sophia Merouin, curled up in the corner, before his Adam's apple bobbed. "They... they wanted me to assault Ms. Roland first, then let Byron Valdemar's men take turns... take turns defiling her. They wanted to turn her into—"

"Into what?" Tristan's voice sharpened.

"A... a whore..." Kevin's whisper was barely audible.

Sophia's head snapped up, her eyes blazing with venomous fury. "Kevin! Say one more word, and I'll have Byron wipe out your entire family!"

"Ah—!"

A bloodcurdling scream tore through the basement. A flash of steel, and Sophia's thumb hit the floor with a sickening thud.

Blood sprayed across the concrete, stark and horrifying.

Ronan Abendroth swung a metal chair with chilling precision, smashing it into Sophia's left leg.

The crack of shattering bone echoed in the confined space.

Sophia's screams cut off abruptly as she collapsed like a broken doll.

"Boss, she's out," Ronan reported tonelessly.

Tristan didn't even glance at Sophia as he stalked toward Kevin. "Throw her out."

Two men in black dragged Sophia away like a sack of garbage.

"Tell Byron this." Tristan gripped Kevin's jaw, forcing eye contact. "Every cent Sophia ever spent on him will be in my hands within three days. Otherwise—" His fingers dug in. "I'll teach him the meaning of living hell."

Kevin trembled violently, nodding like a puppet. "Message received! Message received!"

Tristan paused at the door. "If anyone touches Jenna again..." He turned, baring his teeth in a predator's grin. "Sophia's fate will seem merciful."

Only when the basement door clanged shut did Kevin crumple to the floor. His shirt clung to his back, drenched in sweat.

Staring at the darkening bloodstain, he suddenly laughed. "Byron... you've signed your own death warrant."

Of all people to cross, he had to provoke the devil himself.

......

Jenna was plating sweet-and-sour ribs when her phone buzzed in her apron pocket.

"Boss?" She wiped her hands hastily.

"Kevin Heilbronn was tailing you," came Tristan's voice, still edged with violence. "Sophia and Byron's orders. But—" A deliberate pause. "They won't get another chance."

Jenna's grip tightened on the phone.

"If Sophia dares try anything..." Tristan's chuckle sent chills down her spine. "I'll make her regret being born."
###Chapter 151

Jenna's hand trembled slightly as she clutched her phone.

The moment the kitchen door closed, she lowered her voice. "Boss, what did you do to Sophia?"

"Nothing much." Tristan Ashcroft's tone was eerily light. "Just chopped off one of her fingers and broke her leg."

Jenna's vision darkened. She nearly lost her balance.

Sophia had lost a finger? And her leg was broken?

She sucked in a sharp breath. Tristan was even more ruthless than she'd imagined.

But then again, Sophia deserved it. How dare she use Tristan's money to support her young lover? She was practically begging for death.

"Is she... still alive?" Jenna's voice tightened.

"Dead?" Tristan let out a cold laugh. "Trash like her doesn't get to die that easily."

A chill ran down Jenna's spine. His voice was like ice.

Now she truly understood the terrifying consequences of crossing someone like him.

After hanging up, Jenna leaned against the wall to steady herself.

She needed to save up enough money and leave this place as soon as possible. Otherwise, she might be the next one to suffer.
