Grace Roscente cut in sharply, "Where did you sleep last night?"

Grandma Blanche shot her son and daughter-in-law a disapproving look. "What's wrong with young people going to bars? It's not like she's committing crimes!"

Sophie's eyes lit up as she pulled a thermal container from her bag.

"Grandma, look what I brought you!"

She opened the box like presenting a treasure. The rich aroma of steamed dumplings filled the air.

"The last four dumplings from that alleyway shop. I waited in line for half an hour."

Grandma Blanche's eyes crinkled with delight as she accepted them. "My granddaughter is the most thoughtful."

Benjamin massaged his temples. "Mom, you're spoiling her rotten."

The old lady lifted her chin. "She's my only precious granddaughter. Who else should I spoil?"

Grace frowned. "Who would want to marry a girl who stays out all night?"

She remembered the constant complaints from Sophie's college advisor—how her daughter would sneak out past curfew to hit the clubs, always returning with heavy makeup and revealing outfits.

No amount of discipline changed Sophie's ways.

All because Grandma Blanche always took her side.

Sophie hugged the old woman's arm. "Grandmaaa~"

Grandma patted her hand. "Young people need to have fun. As long as she's not breaking laws."

Sophie immediately vowed, "I just drink with friends and always stay at Fiona's place. Nothing inappropriate."

The grandmother nodded approvingly. "See? My granddaughter knows her limits."

Sophie planted a kiss on Grandma's cheek. "Love you most!"

Grandma Blanche chuckled. "Go rest now."

Sophie bounded upstairs.

The moment she collapsed onto her bed, her phone rang.

Fiona Cortez's voice came through. "You're home? So... how was that hottie from last night?"
###Chapter 191

Sophie Roscente lounged lazily on her bed, twirling a strand of hair around her finger. "Last night's adventure?" She drawled, mischief glinting in her eyes.

Fiona Cortez gasped dramatically on the other end of the line. "Oh my god! Don't tell me you actually—"

"Stop right there." Sophie flipped onto her back. "What happens at Studio 54 stays at Studio 54. If Mom finds out, I'll be grounded for life."

"Since when have I ever ratted you out?" Fiona protested before changing the subject. "Speaking of which, how's your brother's whirlwind marriage going?"

Sophie snorted. "What do you think? It's a marriage of convenience."

She still couldn't fathom why her parents had disapproved of Ethan's relationship with Yvonne Sherwood, who came from a prominent family. Yet now they were treating Jenna Roland—a nobody with no connections—like royalty.

"You're so dense!" Fiona's voice rose an octave. "If your parents adore Jenna that much, get on her good side. She could be your golden ticket next time you're in trouble."

Sophie bolted upright, eyes sparkling with realization.

"Genius!" She laughed, slapping her thigh.

Fiona rolled her eyes audibly. "Honestly, is there room in that head for anything besides hot guys?"

"Time to butter up my new sister-in-law." Sophie's mind raced. Grandma Blanche was getting old—she needed someone influential to back her up when things got messy.

"I'm calling Ethan right now."

"Idiot!" Fiona cut in. "Do it in person if you want to make an impression."

Sophie bounced off the bed. "You're the best!"

She dashed downstairs and draped herself over Grandma Blanche's shoulder. "Grandma, can I have Jenna's address? I want to meet her."

Grace Roscente set her teacdown with a clatter. "What are you scheming now?"

"Mom!" Sophie rolled her eyes. "I'm not going to eat her alive. Can't family visit family?"

Grandma Blanche fretted. "Maybe start with a photo first?"

"Grandma!" Sophie's face fell. "You used to spoil me rotten. Now you won't even grant me this tiny favor?"

The old woman fell silent, flustered.

Grandpa Harrison rubbed his temples. "Let her go."

"Dad!" Benjamin Roscente stood abruptly. "You know how tactless she can be."

The realization hit Sophie like a ton of bricks—her entire family was guarding against her loose lips.
###Chapter 192

Sophie Roscente took a deep breath and raised three fingers. "Grandma Blanche, Grandpa Harrison, Mom Grace, Dad Benjamin—I swear I'll keep my mouth shut. If I spill the beans, you can freeze my credit cards and ground me for a month!"

She knew exactly what was at stake. The entire family had conspired to conceal Ethan's true identity when he married Jenna. One careless word from her could unravel everything.

Though usually mischievous, Sophie understood the gravity of this situation.

Grandma Blanche's expression turned stern. "Remember your promise. If your brother's marriage falls apart because of you, I'll deal with you first!"

Despite doting on her granddaughter, the old woman never compromised on principles.

"Got it~" Sophie chirped sweetly.

After receiving the Beverly Hills address, Grandma Blanche repeatedly warned her not to overstay.

Sophie agreed eagerly and skipped out the door.

Grace Roscente frowned. "Mom, are you sure about letting her go?"

"Relax." Grandma Blanche smiled knowingly. "Ethan will return home for lunch. That girl fears her brother more than anything. With him supervising, nothing will go wrong."

...

The red sports car pulled up in Beverly Hills.

Following the address, Sophie found the house and rang the doorbell.

Her smile froze when the door opened.

"Brother... Why are you here?"

Ethan Roscente blocked the doorway with a cold expression. "What are you doing here?"

Sophie twisted her fingers together. "I... I just wanted to meet my sister-in-law." She added hastily, "I promise to behave!"

Jenna Roland's voice carried from the dining room. "Mr. Roscente, who's at the door?"

Sophie's eyes lit up. Standing on tiptoes, she called out, "Sister-in-law, it's me!"

Ethan's face darkened instantly.

He'd planned to say it was a salesperson, but his sister had reacted too quickly.

Jenna appeared at the doorway, looking puzzled. "And you are...?"
###Chapter 193

Ethan stepped aside, his face darkening like a thundercloud.

His lips pressed into a tight line as he turned and walked inside without a word.

"Let's talk inside." Sophie beamed, stepping into the foyer where the aroma of food immediately greeted her.

She completely forgot to introduce herself, heading straight for the dining room. The sight of the table laden with Ethan's favorite dishes made her eyes light up.

"Jenna, did you make all this?" She turned to Jenna with delighted surprise.

In the Roscente household, their mother rarely cooked, leaving meals to the staff. Sophie had always admired women who could cook—a skill she could never master.

Jenna fidgeted slightly. "Yes, I did."

Sophie leaned over the table, inhaling deeply with an expression of pure bliss. "It smells amazing! You're so talented!"

"Would you like to join us? We were just about to eat," Jenna offered.

"Yes, absolutely!" Sophie agreed eagerly.

Jenna blinked. "Then... have a seat. I'll get the rice."

"I'll help!" Sophie chimed in, following her with honeyed words.

Ethan watched his sister's retreating figure, his brow furrowed.

In the past, he would've welcomed any distraction. But now, an inexplicable unease settled over him, fearing Sophie might say something wrong.

They returned to the dining room with bowls of rice.

Sophie immediately took her seat, greeting them before picking up her chopsticks.

Jenna handed Ethan his bowl. "Ethan, dinner's ready."

"Hmm." He took it without looking up.

Sophie gazed at her brother enviously. Getting to eat such delicious meals every day was pure happiness.

Midway through the meal, Jenna turned to Sophie. "By the way, I didn't catch your name?"

Sophie blinked. "I'm Sophie, Ethan's younger sister."

"So he has a sister." Jenna smiled lightly.

"We also have an older brother who's abroad," Sophie added.

Jenna's curiosity piqued. "Studying overseas? Your family must be well-off."

Sophie opened her mouth to reply when a sharp kick under the table silenced her. Meeting Ethan's warning glare, she quickly caught on.

"Actually... we're just average," she scrambled to improvise. "Our brother got sent abroad for training because of his outstanding work performance."

She shot Ethan a triumphant wink, as if seeking praise.

Jenna nodded. "Then your brother must be exceptional."
###Chapter 194

Sophie Roscente's lips curled into a mischievous smile. "But big brother still can't compare to Ethan. Ethan is..."

Before she could finish, Ethan's leather shoe connected sharply with her shin.

The kick was forceful enough to make Sophie nearly jump out of her seat.

She pouted in protest, certain she hadn't said anything wrong.

This tyrant didn't even spare his own sister from his brutality.

Jenna Roland immediately noticed the disturbance. "What happened?"

Rubbing her sore leg, Sophie quickly amended her statement. "I meant academically. Big brother never ranked first in school, but Ethan was the top of the top."

"Really?" Jenna's eyes brightened as she gazed at Ethan with newfound admiration. "No wonder Mr. Roscente became HM Group's director at such a young age. You're truly exceptional."

Ethan's stern expression softened slightly.

He cleared his throat. "Let's eat."

"Of course." Jenna nodded obediently before turning to Sophie. "You should eat more too."

"Thanks, sis!" Sophie cheerfully picked up a piece of braised pork. "Your cooking beats Michelin chefs. Did you train professionally?"

Jenna shook her head. "My mother was an excellent cook. I learned everything from her."

"It's in your blood!" Sophie praised between bites. "The sweet and sour ribs are perfectly seasoned."

Thanks to Sophie's unexpected visit, the four dishes and soup prepared for dinner were completely devoured.

Sophie wiped her mouth contentedly. "Sis, I really imposed on you today."

"Don't mention it." Jenna smiled warmly. "Next time just let me know in advance, and I'll prepare more of my specialties."

"Perfect!" Sophie immediately pulled out her phone. "Let's exchange contacts first."

As soon as they swapped numbers, Ethan abruptly stood up.

"Sophie, help clean up." He glanced at his watch. "I'm returning to the office."

Shortly after Ethan left, Sophie's phone vibrated.

The screen displayed a stark warning from Ethan: Watch your mouth.

Sophie rolled her eyes and tossed her phone aside, continuing to help Jenna clear the table.

After washing the dishes, Jenna thoughtfully brought over two cups of floral tea.

"Try this. It aids digestion." She placed a cup gently before Sophie.

"Thanks, sis!" Sophie accepted it with both hands. After taking a sip, her eyes lit up. "This is amazing!"
###Chapter 195

Ethan slid into the driver's seat but didn't start the engine. He pulled out his phone and dialed Grandma Blanche.

"Grandma, why did you give Sophie the address to Beverly Hills?" His voice was low and icy.

His long fingers tapped impatiently against the steering wheel, his brows furrowed. Sophie had never been good at keeping secrets. What if she accidentally let something slip to Jenna?

"She promised not to say anything," Grandma Blanche replied breezily.

"No matter what she promised, she shouldn't have gone to see Jenna." Ethan's tone darkened with displeasure.

"She said Jenna is her sister-in-law and they'd meet eventually." Grandma Blanche spoke unhurriedly. "Your grandfather and I both think it's time Jenna got to know the family, now that she's married into it."

Ethan took a deep breath and rubbed his temples. "Fine."

What was done couldn't be undone.

"Ethan, are you afraid Jenna will find out who you really are?" Grandma Blanche suddenly asked, a sly glint in her eyes.

"I have work to do. Goodbye." He abruptly ended the call.

Grandma Blanche huffed as she set down the phone. "That boy, still pretending with me!"

Grandpa Harrison chuckled. "Well?"

"The moment I asked if he liked Jenna, he hung up." She smirked triumphantly. "Definitely guilty."

"That girl is quite lovable," Grandpa Harrison nodded. "It's only natural Ethan would fall for her."

"I just hope they get together soon." Grandma Blanche beamed. "Then I can finally hold my great-grandchild."

......

Beverly Hills.

Jenna had just seen Sophie off and was about to rest when her phone rang. It was Hugo.

"Mr. Valence?" She answered.

"Miss Roland, we have results from the orchard investigation." His voice was grave. "It's already been transferred to your uncle's name. Legally, it'll be difficult to reclaim."

Jenna bolted upright in bed, her face instantly draining of color. "What?"

"The transfer was completed on May 4th, 2018," Hugo added.

The date made her hands tremble so violently she nearly dropped the phone.

"Miss Roland?" Hugo noticed her distress.

"My parents... died on April 29th, 2018," Jenna whispered, her voice shaking, eyes reddening.

"Which means..." Hugo paused.

"It was transferred less than a week after their deaths." Her fists clenched, nails digging into her palms. "Mr. Valence... do you think my uncle had something to do with their deaths?"
###Chapter 196

"Only he can tell you the truth."

"Attorney Valence, how should I investigate my parents' death?"

"Search your uncle's house, especially his study drawers. Any items related to your parents could be clues."

Jenna knew the odds were slim. If Uncle Victor was truly involved, the evidence was likely long gone.

"I understand."

"Focus on the condition of your parents' vehicle at the time of the accident, surveillance footage from the scene, and whether they had conflicts with anyone before their deaths."

"I'll do my best."

"Call me anytime."

After hanging up, Jenna tossed and turned. Memories of her parents and uncle haunted her.

Years ago, her parents' orchard thrived. Victor had demanded a stake but was refused. Out of family loyalty, her father still paid her cousins' tuition and taught Victor orchard management.

Then came the loan request—right when her father invested in a new orchard. The argument still echoed in her mind, Victor's enraged shouts accusing her father of heartlessness.

If their "accident" was really Victor's doing...

Jenna clenched her fists, nails digging into her palms. She would uncover the truth and make the killer pay.

Tristan Ashcroft readily approved her leave request, clearly still guilty over the club incident.

Next, she called Victor Roland.

"Jenna? You dare call me?" His voice dripped with fury.

She inhaled deeply, suppressing the hatred rising in her throat.

"Uncle, I've realized something. After losing my parents, you're our only family. Milo and I are still young—we'll need your guidance. I was foolish before. Please forgive me."

A dull thud sounded—likely a shovel hitting dirt. Victor sneered, "You think an apology erases putting your aunt and cousins in detention?"
###Chapter 197

Victor Roland's knuckles turned white as he gripped his phone. How dare Jenna call to beg for forgiveness?

He wanted to strangle that insolent girl with his bare hands.

"I acted rashly. I shouldn't have caused such a scene." Jenna clenched her jaw so hard it ached, her nails digging into her palms.

The silence on the other end was deafening.

Jenna thought the call had dropped until she noticed the timer still counting.

"Out of respect for your parents," Victor finally spoke, his voice icy, "come apologize to your aunt and cousin in person. Then we'll consider this matter closed."

"Fine. I'll be there this afternoon."

Victor hung up without another word.

Determined to uncover the truth about her parents' accident, Jenna grabbed her things and sped toward her uncle's house on her e-bike.

At this hour, Heidi would be playing mahjong, Jason helping at the clothing store, and Victor tending his orchard.

Halfway there, her phone rang again.

"Buy groceries. You're cooking dinner." Victor's tone brooked no argument.

Jenna's culinary skills were legendary in the family. Even Victor had grown accustomed to her cooking during her absence.

"..."

Her face darkened like storm clouds.

That greedy bastard wouldn't miss any chance to exploit her.

"Understood." She ended the call before her rage could spill over.

After mentally cursing Victor a hundred times, Jenna turned toward the market.

Groceries in hand, she headed straight to the Roland residence.

Thankfully she'd kept her key after their last argument, saving a trip to the orchard.

The house stood empty as expected.

Jenna stored the groceries in the kitchen, then slipped into Victor's bedroom.

She rifled through nightstands and wardrobes with methodical precision.

Just as she was about to give up, a locked wooden chest caught her eye.

Buried under clothes, its brass padlock gleamed ominously.

Whatever hid inside must be damning.

Jenna remembered the keyring Victor always wore on his belt.

The front door lock clicked.

She shoved the chest back in place and grabbed an armful of dirty laundry just as—

"Jenna?" Jason stood frozen in the living room, his face twisting with fury. "You bitch! Who let you in here?"
###Chapter 198

Jason Roland was seething with rage. That bitch had gotten him and his mother detained for fifteen whole days! Those fifteen days had been pure hell—humiliated, bullied, wishing for death.

His hate-filled eyes burned into Jenna Roland.

"You deserved it," Jenna said coldly. "Extortion is a crime. Consider it a lesson."

Jason raised his fist, ready to strike.

"Go ahead," Jenna didn’t flinch. "I’d love to send you back for another two weeks."

Jason’s hand froze mid-air. The trauma of detention forced him to lower it.

"You’ll pay for this!" He pointed at her, teeth clenched.

Jenna ignored him, gathering a pile of dirty laundry before heading to the bathroom.

Jason cursed under his breath as he dialed Victor Roland. "Dad, why is she here?"

After listening to the explanation, his face twisted in disbelief. "She’ll apologize? Yeah, right!"

Hanging up, he smirked and gathered another heap of filthy clothes.

"Wash these!" He hurled them at Jenna’s feet.

"Why should I?"

"Then get the hell out of this house." Jason stormed off, slamming the door behind him.

Jenna stared at the toilet, a sinister smile creeping onto her lips.

"You asked for it." Without hesitation, she stuffed the clothes into the bowl.

In the living room, Jason lounged on the couch, cracking sunflower seeds and littering the floor with shells.

"Clean this up," he ordered without looking up.

Jenna gripped the broom, mentally cursing his entire bloodline.

The phone on the coffee table lit up—an incoming call from 10086.
###Chapter 199

Jenna Roland noticed the sudden glow of Jason Roland's phone screen. Her eyes narrowed as she read the caller ID. His expression darkened instantly.

He switched off the TV abruptly and strode toward the bedroom, gripping his phone.

Jenna arched a brow.

Since when did customer service calls require privacy?

She crept to the bedroom door, pressing her ear against it.

"Just got home. Remember that bitch I told you about? She's back."

"Who knows what she's scheming."

"Enough about her. Baby, did you miss me?"

"Good. See you soon."

Jenna slipped back to the living room and grabbed a broom, pretending to sweep.

A cold smirk curled her lips.

She'd come for evidence. This was an unexpected bonus.

Jason flung the door open and scoffed at the sight of Jenna cleaning. He marched past her without a word.

Jenna watched him change his shoes.

Off to meet his secret lover.

If Heidi Roland knew...

She dropped the broom and followed.

The elevator doors slid shut just as she arrived. Jenna jabbed the button for the next one.

In the lobby, Jason disappeared through the revolving doors. Jenna adjusted her cap and trailed behind.

At the curb, he ducked into a private car. She flagged down a taxi.

Twenty minutes later, a hotel sign loomed ahead.

Jenna waited until Jason entered the elevator before approaching the front desk.

"Which room did that gentleman take? I need the one next to his."

The receptionist eyed her skeptically. "And you are...?"

"His sister." Jenna feigned concern. "He's meeting some online fling. I'm worried he's being catfished."

After checking her ID, the clerk handed over a keycard.

Room 504.

The moment Jenna stepped inside, stiletto clicks echoed from next door.

Through the peephole, a woman in a skin-tight black dress swayed into 503.

Jenna snapped a photo.

Her lip curled in disdain.

Did Heidi know what trash her husband really was?

Pressing her ear to 503's door, Jenna heard nothing.

The soundproofing was annoyingly effective.
###Chapter 200

Jenna Roland clenched the voice recorder in her pocket, her fingertips trembling slightly.

She had hoped to capture some crucial conversations for future use. But given the current situation, her plan was falling apart.

She exhaled quietly and turned to leave.

......

When she returned to Victor Roland's house, the place was in complete disarray.

Jenna scanned the mess, a cold smirk curling her lips. If she wanted them to lower their guard, she might as well go all in.

Rolling up her sleeves, she began cleaning up the chaos.

By 4:30 PM, the aroma of cooking filled the kitchen.

At exactly 5:00, Heidi and Fiona Roland barged in. Their faces darkened the moment they saw Jenna.

"How dare you show your face here?" Fiona shrieked, her nails digging into her palms.

Jenna didn’t even glance up as she slammed the kitchen door shut.

Amid the roar of the exhaust fan, a glint of ice flashed in her eyes.

By 5:30, four dishes and a soup were laid out on the dining table.

Victor and Jason Roland had already taken their seats in the living room. Jenna went to fetch them one by one, as if serving royalty.

"You must be out of your mind!" Fiona threw her bag onto the table, rattling the dishes.

Victor picked up a piece of braised pork, then frowned. "Why aren’t you eating?"

"Not hungry." Jenna stood in the kitchen doorway, shadows masking half her face.

Heidi suddenly flung her chopsticks down. "Did you poison the food?"

The air turned frigid.

Jenna strode forward, grabbed a pair of chopsticks, and tasted every dish. She locked eyes with Heidi. "Satisfied?"

The sound of running water echoed from the bathroom.

Fiona shoveled rice into her mouth, teeth gritted. "She got us thrown in jail, and you—"

"Her cooking’s good," Victor smacked his lips. "And she cleaned the house."

Jason grinned. "Free help—why not use it?"

The three exchanged greedy glances.

"Not a cent less for rent and expenses!" Heidi suddenly raised her voice.

The conversation died as the doorknob turned.

Jenna emerged, hanging the last shirt to dry. She wiped her damp fingers on her apron. "Uncle Victor, I’m leaving."

Victor’s chopsticks froze mid-air. "You’re not staying?"
###Chapter 201

Jenna Roland's expression remained indifferent. "I'm not coming back."

The answer sent shockwaves through the room.

They had assumed her sudden goodwill meant she wanted to bring her burden of a brother home.

No one expected such a blunt refusal.

Victor Roland frowned deeply. "Then what's all this for?"

Jenna knew she needed a plausible excuse.

"I need to borrow money."

Before she could finish, mocking laughter erupted around her.

She was long accustomed to such cruel remarks.

Victor's voice turned grave. "We're expanding the orchard. No funds to spare."

"Not even thirty thousand?"

"No."

Jenna's gaze dropped to the keyring at his waist.

Among those many keys, one must unlock that mysterious wooden box.

She lifted her chin. "Then I'll do housework. A hundred a day."

Fiona Roland sneered. "Club earnings not enough?"

"Milo needs surgery."

Jenna met Victor's eyes squarely. "Call it charity."

The orchard had once belonged to Jenna's parents. After a tense pause, Victor gave a stiff nod.

"Fine."

Jenna turned to leave.

"Report to the orchard tomorrow for weeding," Victor added abruptly.

Her steps faltered slightly. The calculation was transparent.

The moment the door closed, Fiona exploded. "A hundred a day for housework? Have you lost your mind?"

Victor shot her a cold look. "If you didn't gamble daily, I wouldn't have agreed."

Jason Roland smirked. "Mom, we can just refuse payment at month's end."

Heidi Roland clapped excitedly. "Brilliant, darling!"

"Free labor—what a bargain." Jason preened.

Victor silently resumed eating, tacitly approving the scheme.

Fiona beamed. "Finally showing some sense!"
###Chapter 202

Jason Roland pouted and muttered unhappily, "Mom, is that really fair to say about me?"

...

When Jenna Roland returned to Beverly Hills, the night was already deep.

Only Milo Roland was in the living room.

Seeing Jenna back so early, Milo immediately ended his call, surprised. "Sis, you're not working today?"

Jenna sat on the couch, rubbing her sore neck. "I took the day off to visit Uncle Victor's place."

"What?"

Milo's eyes widened as he plopped down beside her. "Why would you go there? Did they give you any trouble?"

She couldn't tell him about their parents' murder yet—not before his surgery. He wouldn't be able to handle it.

Jenna kept her tone casual. "Attorney Hugo said Uncle Victor already transferred the orchard. To get it back, we need to find Mom and Dad's will."

"But didn't he burn it?" Milo frowned.

Jenna pressed her lips together. "Something that important? He wouldn't have actually destroyed it. What he burned that day must've been a fake."

"Oh." Milo's face lit with understanding. "So you went looking for the real one?"

"Yeah." Jenna picked up the remote. "I'll need to sneak into his house these next few days for a chance to search."

Milo burst out laughing. "You sound like a secret agent."

Jenna chuckled too. "Keep this between us."

Milo nodded emphatically. "Don't worry. My lips are sealed."

"Good." Jenna turned on the TV, then suddenly remembered. "Ethan's not back yet?"

"He usually comes home around eleven." Milo studied her. "Sis, have you eaten?"

"I grabbed something on the way." Jenna nodded.

"Then enjoy your show. I'm heading back to my game." Milo stood up.

Jenna hummed in acknowledgment.

Not long after Milo left, the doorbell rang.

Jenna checked the time with a frown—only 7:30 PM. Ethan never returned this early. Very few people knew she lived here. Who could it be?

"Who is it?" She approached the door.

"Me."

Ethan Roscente's cool voice came through.

Jenna froze, then quickly opened the door.

Seeing him standing there, she blinked in surprise. "Mr. Roscente, how—"

Ethan strode past her into the living room and took a seat on the couch. "The dinner meeting ended early."

"Oh." Jenna followed and sat down. "I thought you'd be back much later."

She hesitated. "Mr. Roscente... are you hungry?"

"...No." Ethan glanced at her before looking back at his phone.

Heat rushed to Jenna's ears—of course he wouldn't be hungry right after a business dinner. What a stupid question.

She bit her lip, gathering courage. "Mr. Roscente—"

Before she could continue, Ethan's brows drew together slightly. He met her gaze. "No need for formalities. Just call me Ethan."
###Chapter 203

Jenna's pupils constricted slightly. Her fingers unconsciously tightened around the hem of her blouse.

Ethan pulled a cigarette case from his suit pocket. The metallic click of his lighter echoed sharply in the quiet room. Wisps of pale smoke curled around his sharp features, making his hooded eyes appear even more unfathomable.

"Problem?" His deep voice rumbled as he exhaled a smoke ring.

Jenna shook her head hastily. "N-no."

Milo pushed open the door and froze at the sight of the man in the living room. "Mr. Roscente? No meetings today?"

"Finished early." Ethan tapped ash into the tray, his gaze fixed on the television screen.

Milo retreated into his room with practiced discretion. The click of the closing door sounded unnaturally loud in the silence.

The ashtray refracted light from the ceiling lamp. Ethan suddenly spoke. "New?"

"Pardon?" Jenna blinked.

"This." He rapped his knuckles against the glass vessel. "Your doing?"

The tips of Jenna's ears burned. "Last time I saw you flicking ashes into the flowerpot..."

Ethan stubbed out his cigarette without comment and stood. Silk fabric clung to his lean waistline as he disappeared into the master bedroom.

Only then did Jenna notice her damp palms. Three months of cohabitation, yet every private moment still felt like treading on thin ice.

Her phone vibrated. Tristan Ashcroft's name flashed on the screen.

"Can you report tomorrow?" Static distorted his voice.

Jenna bit her lip. "Mr. Ashcroft, I may need leave..."

"What?" Tristan's tone turned razor-sharp. "Your brother's surgery still needs $200k. Quitting now?"

"I found anomalies in my parents' crash footage." Her nails dug into her palms. "The autopsy shows cut brake lines."

Glass clinked on Tristan's end. He lowered his voice. "You're certain?"

"The medical examiner was my professor." Jenna glanced toward the master bedroom. "Keep this...from Mr. Roscente for now."
###Chapter 204

"Second, the acquired poison must fully merge and transform into innate poison."

"Finally, the most crucial step!" The Frostblade Immortal sighed heavily, his gaze solemn. "She must endure another heavenly thunder tribulation, like the one you faced yesterday. By all accounts, that was the weakest form of heavenly thunder."

"But..."

His eyes fell upon Ji Lin, flickering with pity. "Asking a newly ascended Divine Transformation cultivator like Ji Lin to withstand thunder capable of obliterating a Star Aperture Realm deity is sheer fantasy!"

"It would be like an egg striking a rock!"

"This is why, since the fall of the Innate Poison God three hundred millennia ago, no true innate poison physique has emerged. Even acquired poison physiques are rarer than fingers on one hand, and all perished before reaching maturity."

"Ji Lin's current condition..."

"She has at most a year left. There is another option—to place her in eternal slumber. But what difference is there between that and death?"

"Disciple, think carefully. She must face the heavenly thunder alone. If you interfere, its power will double. The power of the Cycle Graveyard is finite—it may block one strike, but not necessarily a second."

"Moreover, yesterday's thunder was only the first of the contract."

"The true heavenly tribulation consists of three strikes, each more terrifying than the last..."

Ye Chen fell into deep contemplation.

Heavenly thunder!

He had experienced it twice. The first was during the alchemy tribulation in Danxu Town when refining an Emperor Realm pill—its power equivalent only to a mid-stage Emperor Realm strike. Kunlun Void was a lower martial world with limited heavenly law, capping at the combined Dao Realm's might.

But the Spirit Martial Continent was different!

This was an upper martial world where heavenly thunder rivaled the full-force strike of a Void Transcendence Saint. Unless he possessed saintly cultivation, resistance was impossible.

As for the second time...

It was the heavenly punishment for violating a heavenly contract. Three thunder strikes—the first equivalent to a third-layer Star Aperture Realm strike, the second to a sixth-layer, and the third nearing the ninth-layer!

Three heavenly thunder strikes!

Throughout history, those who survived could be counted on one hand!

At his current strength, without the Cycle Graveyard's aid, death was certain!

"No!"

"Ji Lin is Siqing's sister. She helped me so much in the past—I won't let her become a living corpse!"

"What's heavenly thunder? I've shattered two tribulations already—a third means nothing!" Ye Chen's gaze hardened as he looked at the Frostblade Immortal and the six divine buddhas and sovereigns. "Masters, since the Innate Poison God succeeded, there must be a method."

"Could there be..."

"A powerful array to weaken the thunder?"

"An array?" The Frostblade Immortal frowned. "Arrays could work, but..."

The Eternal Blood Demon Array?

The Heaven-Surveying Earth-Inquiring Array?

The Universe-Sealing Demon Array?

...

None would suffice!

Their power was insufficient to withstand heavenly thunder.

Unless a peerless expert presided over them—at least a Star Aperture Realm deity. But such experts were more likely to kick you when you're down than lend aid. The cost of their assistance would rival a divine artifact!

Divine artifacts!

A single divine artifact's value exceeded ten spacetime weapons!

Ye Chen couldn't afford it. Neither could they.

"An array!"

"Grave Keeper, I've just recalled something!" The Nine Dances Sovereign suddenly spoke. "In Kunlun Void's resource-scarce past, arrays often drew power from mountain and earth veins. Such arrays could transcend realms to resist powerful enemies."

"Like the Universe Dragon Array!"

"Deployed by Chaos Unity Realm cultivators, it could briefly withstand a ninth-layer Combined Dao Sovereign's attack!"

The Universe Dragon Array!

Ye Chen's eyes lit up.

Back then, leading Kunlun Void and Spirit City's factions, he gathered ninety Divine Transformation cultivators to form this array, barely holding off a late-stage Divine King Realm Blood Spirit clansman. Only the intervention of a Soul Clan Combined Dao elder shattered it.

"Feasible!"

"The Spirit Martial Continent's mountains and earth veins contain dragon pulses."

"Dragon pulses nurture earth qi, forming earth dragons. If we can connect the dragon pulse's earth qi with an array, supplemented by spacetime weapons and Combined Dao artifacts, we might withstand the thunder!"

Ye Chen's mind raced.

Such heaven-and-earth-powered arrays were exceedingly rare. Fortunately, Kunlun Void's ancient Star Aperture experts left behind such legacies.

His plan: eight spacetime weapons occupying the eight trigrams, fifty Combined Dao artifacts forming the Five Elements Grand Array. After dual weakening, the thunder's power might drop to the Chaos Unity Realm level.

Then...

He could use the Cycle Graveyard to mask his aura, entering the array to endure the thunder for Ji Lin. Once he helped her fully merge the Thousand Demon Ginseng, she would awaken with an innate poison physique!

"This method..."

"Isn't impossible, but the risks are extreme!"

"The slightest misstep could mean your demise, Grave Keeper!" The Frostblade Immortal spoke after a long silence. He wanted to dissuade him but found no grounds.

"Demise?"

"The heavenly law can't claim me!"

"Nor can the grand dao—nothing in this world can take my life!"

Ye Chen stared at the unconscious Ji Lin, his voice resolute. "I will never let my people become living corpses. Never. This array will be deployed!"

The Frostblade Immortal looked up, studying Ye Chen with unfamiliar eyes.

This disciple...

Was too stubborn, stubborn to the point of obsession!

In Ye Chen's eyes, nothing was impossible, no obstacle insurmountable.

And in truth, he had repeatedly forged miracles.
###Chapter 205

The Wanlong territory originally belonged to Quentin Croix. Wilson Parvis was just a lowly underling back then.

Who could've imagined that after Quentin's death, Wilson would rise to power and become Wanlong's new overlord overnight?

Rumors said Wilson commanded tens of thousands of elite soldiers. His influence was so formidable that even the infamous Vincent Agrigent dared not cross him lightly.

Tristan Ashcroft was stunned. He never expected Tony Lombardi to be Wilson's son-in-law!

"Exactly. He's my father-in-law." Tony swirled his wine glass. "Without him, I wouldn't be where I am today."

Tristan raised his glass for a toast.

After downing his drink, he said meaningfully, "Then you'd better tread carefully. If your wife gets upset..."

Tony gave a bitter laugh. "Tell me about it. Her pregnancy hormones are raging these days. I can't even breathe too loudly around her."

"Good luck with that." Tristan checked his watch and stood. "I've got business to attend to. Excuse me."

"Go ahead." Tony waved him off, watching him leave.

......

Jenna Roland stepped into the bedroom, drying her damp hair. Ethan Roscente leaned against the headboard, reading.

She sat at the vanity and picked up her old jar of Dabao moisturizer.

Ethan's gaze lifted from his book, landing on the cheap skincare product in her hands. His brows furrowed.

"Why aren't you using the skincare set I bought you?"

Jenna applied the cream while facing the mirror. "I'll switch after finishing this one."

"And the clothes in the wardrobe—you've never worn them." His voice turned icy.

He'd personally selected those haute couture dresses, even removing the tags himself. Yet they remained untouched.

After moisturizing, Jenna walked to the bed. "Those outfits are too expensive. I do housework all day—it'd be wasteful to wear them."

Ethan's expression froze.

He couldn't believe his ears.

"Clothes are meant to be worn." His tone was glacial. "If you won't wear them, I'll have them tossed tomorrow."

Hearing his anger, Jenna quickly relented. "I'll wear them tomorrow. Don't be mad."

Ethan snorted and turned away.

Jenna silently arranged her floor bedding. After scrolling through her phone, drowsiness soon overtook her.

She set the phone aside and fell into deep sleep.
###Chapter 206

Jenna Roland soon fell into a deep slumber, her breathing steady and even.

Ethan Roscente turned slightly, quickly sending two messages before his gaze inadvertently drifted to the figure on the floor bedding.

Jenna shifted unconsciously, turning her back to him.

The movement caused the thin summer blanket to slip halfway down, revealing the smooth curve of her back and the delicate dip of her waist.

The slender contour glowed softly under the moonlight.

Ethan's throat tightened as his eyes remained fixed on that pale expanse of skin.

Jenna frowned suddenly, scratching her neck before rolling onto her back again.

Her exquisite face now faced him directly, the moonlight tracing her flawless profile.

His gaze traveled downward, where a dozen red scars marred the porcelain skin of her neck.

Ethan's brow furrowed.

He remembered her skin being flawless the last time he saw her.

Further down, the tantalizing curves made his mouth go dry, his breathing growing ragged.

He squeezed his eyes shut, taking several deep breaths.

This was madness. How could he be having these thoughts about Jenna?

Too long without release, apparently.

Irritated, he switched off the bedside lamp.

Moonlight filtered through the curtains, illuminating her silhouette even more vividly.

The narrow waist, the flat stomach, and the suggestive curves hidden beneath the blanket.

Unwanted fantasies flooded his mind.

His pulse quickened, heat spreading through his body.

A sudden phone ringtone snapped him out of his trance.

Damn it. How long had he been staring at her?

Ethan muted the call instantly.

Gavin Valentine's name flashed on the screen.

Pinching the bridge of his nose, he stepped onto the balcony, closing the glass door before answering.

"Speak."

His voice came out rough and strained.

"I'm at Studio 54. Tristan Ashcroft says Jenna didn't show tonight." Gavin's voice crackled through the line. "And she's only working two-hour shifts from now on. Should I keep monitoring her?"

Ethan's gaze drifted back through the glass door.

Somehow, Jenna had kicked off the blanket completely, now lying fully exposed toward him.

Moonlight bathed every alluring curve in silver.

He forced himself to look away.

"Ethan? You there?" Gavin's voice pulled him back.

"What?" His reply was hoarse.
###Chapter 207

"Bright red blood?" Huang Rong frowned slightly, studying Yang Guo's swollen black palm with suspicion. She retrieved a Nine-Flower Jade Dew Pill from her embroidered pouch and handed it to him. "Chew and swallow it."

Yang Guo took the pill and bit down. A refreshing sweetness instantly filled his mouth. The cooling medicinal energy flowed down his throat to his dantian, spreading comfort throughout his body. He marveled inwardly—the legendary Peach Blossom Island's remedy truly lived up to its reputation.

"Thank you, Aunt Guo." Yang Guo's eyes sparkled with an innocent smile. "My mother always said you were the most beautiful and brilliant woman in the world. Seeing you today, I know she wasn't exaggerating."

Huang Rong froze. Since when had Mu Nianci spoken of her like that? Then she realized—this sly boy must have inherited his father's silver tongue. A faint smile touched her lips. "Your mother flatters me too much."

Guo Jing suddenly tensed, scanning their surroundings. "That demoness must be nearby." He threw back his head and let out a thunderous roar that shook the air. Willow branches trembled, and birds scattered in alarm.

Though Yang Guo knew the plot, the sheer force of the roar still sent a jolt through his heart. Guo Jing's internal energy was far more profound than he'd imagined. The sound waves layered upon each other like the thunder of ten thousand horses charging.

Not to be outdone by her husband, Huang Rong gathered her qi and released a clear, melodious roar. Her cry intertwined with Guo Jing's mighty bellow, soaring into the heavens like a phoenix's song meeting a dragon's roar.

After years of rigorous training on Peach Blossom Island, the couple's internal energy had reached perfection. Though Huang Rong's strength couldn't match Guo Jing's, her technique was far more agile and versatile. Their combined roars carried for miles.

Yang Guo suppressed a laugh. In the original story, these roars had scared away both Huang Yaoshi and Ouyang Feng. Even Li Mochou had retreated in despair. Today's performance was likely wasted effort.

He stole a glance at Huang Rong and noted the lingering suspicion in her brow. This sharp-witted aunt wasn't easily fooled. His earlier flattery probably hadn't dispelled her wariness.

A faint rustle came from distant treetops, as if someone had fled. Yang Guo narrowed his eyes—Li Mochou had indeed been frightened off by the roars. His fingers brushed against the Five Venoms Secret Manual hidden in his robe as he plotted his next move.

Guo Jing ceased roaring, his thick brows furrowed. "Strange. No one answered the challenge."

Huang Rong gently touched his arm. "Perhaps the demoness knew she was outmatched."

Suddenly, Yang Guo clutched his arm with a pained expression. Huang Rong's sharp gaze bore into him, as if seeing through his act. The boy's heart sank—this brilliant aunt was far too perceptive to deceive.
###Chapter 208

"Furong, mind your words from now on." Guo Jing's tone had softened, but the sternness in his brow remained.

Guo Furong secretly exhaled in relief and quickly replied, "I'll remember, Father."

Footsteps approached from nearby as Ke Zhen'e led Guo Furong through the grove.

The moment Guo Furong spotted Huang Rong, she rushed into her mother's arms, cooing like a spoiled child.

As she prattled on with trivial chatter, Guo Jing's frown deepened.

Afraid of her father's reprimand, Guo Furong's eyes darted around before suddenly pointing at Yang Guo. "Hey, you! Go pick some flowers to make me a wreath!" She glimpsed his soiled sleeves and shabby clothes, curling her lip in disdain. "Never mind. You're filthy. You'd just stink up the flowers."

Guo Jing's expression darkened instantly.

But Yang Guo merely lowered his head, forcing a weak smile. "You're right. I am dirty. The flowers would get dirty too. If I soiled your new dress, you'd be cross with me again."

As he spoke, he took two steps back, his fingers unconsciously plucking at his frayed hem. His eyes reddened slightly, the very picture of a pitiful, mistreated boy.

In the original tale, Yang Guo would have been deeply wounded by Guo Furong's words—sensitive and insecure. But this Yang Guo was no longer that helpless youth who took abuse meekly.

Dealing with a spoiled, simple-minded young mistress like Guo Furong required neither defiance nor submission.

Yang Guo studied the girl before him. She wore a delicate green silk dress, pearls gleaming at her throat, her skin so fair it seemed one could pinch water from it. Her almond-shaped eyes sparkled with mischief beneath arched willow-leaf brows.

'Pretty enough,' he mused inwardly, amused. 'Just not very bright.' Such naive girls were always the most entertaining to tease, reminding him of simpler days.

"At least you know your place," Guo Furong scoffed, tilting her chin up proudly, completely missing the sarcasm lacing his words.

Huang Rong sighed inwardly. Her daughter had inherited none of her wit—a beautiful fool through and through.

She shot Yang Guo a knowing glance, recognizing how his carefully chosen words would ignite Guo Jing's temper.

Sure enough, Guo Jing misinterpreted Yang Guo's feigned meekness as habitual cowardice. His fury erupted instantly.
###Chapter 209

Morning light filtered through the curtains, casting golden streaks across the dining table. Ethan Roscente set down his coffee cup, his gaze lingering on Jenna Roland across from him.

She wore the white dress he'd carefully selected, her dark hair casually tied into a bun. The morning light illuminated her bare face, giving her an ethereal glow.

"It suits you," Ethan murmured, his voice deep.

Jenna glanced at the hem of her dress, a faint smile touching her lips. "Thank you."

She hadn't wanted to wear it, but the displeasure in Ethan's eyes last night had changed her mind.

"Urgent matter at the office." Ethan rose. "You handle the dishes. I'll take care of lunch."

"I'm cooking at Uncle Victor's place these afternoons," Jenna explained.

Ethan grabbed his phone and left without another word.

After Milo Roland rushed out with his backpack, Jenna began clearing the table. As she dried the last plate, she realized she'd never seen Ethan's dirty laundry.

"Maybe he sends it to the dry cleaners," she muttered. "What a waste. I should tell him I can do it."

Just as she finished hanging the laundry, Victor Roland's call came through.

"Why aren't you at the orchard yet?" His voice was sharp.

"On my way." Jenna snatched her keys and dashed out.

At the orchard, Victor was bent over, pulling weeds. He straightened when he spotted his tardy niece, his expression darkening.

"Slacking off again?" he demanded.

Jenna lowered her head. "I stayed up late."

"If not for your father, who'd pay you for this?" Victor scoffed.

Jenna's gaze flickered to the jingling keys at his waist before she silently moved to the field's edge and knelt.

They worked in silence amid the overgrown orchard. After ten minutes, Victor suddenly spoke.

"Heard you got married. Living with him now?"

"Divorced already." Jenna kept her eyes on the weeds. "Milo and I rent our own place."
###Chapter 210

Jenna Roland had just announced her divorce when Victor Roland let out a piercing sneer.

"I knew this would happen!" He shot her a sideways glance. "What wealthy man would ever want a woman like you?"

Jenna clenched her fists, her nails digging deep into her palms.

She forced herself not to react.

Victor's disdainful gaze cut through her like a blade.

Just then, his phone rang.

"What?" he answered impatiently.

Fiona Roland's excited voice came through. "Victor, remember Daisy Dimucci?"

"That fat woman?" Victor frowned. "What about her?"

Fiona lowered her voice. "She knows a wealthy businessman looking for pretty girls to spend the night with. If it's their first time, he pays eighty thousand!"

Victor's head snapped toward Jenna.

She was bent over weeding the vegetable garden, her slender waist catching the sunlight.

"Eighty thousand?" He swallowed hard. "You're sure?"

"Absolutely!" Fiona urged. "Jenna's so beautiful—he might pay even more!"

Victor's greedy eyes locked onto Jenna's back.

"She'd never agree," he muttered.

"That's why we need a plan!" Fiona insisted. "Be nice to her these next few days. Don't let her suspect anything."

Hanging up, Victor immediately plastered on a smile.

"Jenna," he cooed, approaching her. "Your aunt won big at mahjong. She's treating us to lunch."

Jenna didn't look up. "Milo's going to a friend's house."

"Then we'll bring him something delicious," Victor said eagerly.

Jenna eyed him suspiciously.

Her usually cruel uncle's sudden warmth set off alarm bells in her mind.

At eleven, Fiona called again.

"Reservation's ready. Let's go." Victor hung up, rubbing his hands together.

Jenna followed in silence.

In the parking lot, Victor opened the car door for her. "Ride with me."

After a pause, Jenna slid inside.

The black sedan pulled away, heading toward an unknown destination.
###Chapter 211

Jenna Roland entered the private room arm-in-arm with her father Victor Roland. Fiona Roland and her family were already seated around the round table.

"Jenna's here!" Fiona beamed with exaggerated warmth.

Jason and Heidi immediately stood up, pulling out a chair for her with excessive courtesy.

Jenna's brows furrowed slightly. Alarm bells rang in her mind.

These people usually greeted her with either cold sarcasm or outright indifference. Their sudden hospitality reeked of ulterior motives.

Heidi poured her a cup of black tea with exaggerated care.

Jenna tapped the rim of the cup lightly before meeting Fiona's flushed face. "Had good luck at the tables, Aunt Fiona?"

"Just a small win." Fiona's grin stretched ear to ear. "Only about ten grand."

Jenna smirked inwardly.

For this compulsive gambler, winning five figures was indeed cause for celebration.

The door swung open as Sean Roland strode in with his long legs.

"Sean?" Jenna stood up in surprise.

He took the seat beside her without ceremony. "Dad mentioned Aunt Fiona was treating. I happened to be free."

Victor glanced around. "Have we ordered yet?"

"Already taken care of." Fiona suddenly changed the subject. "Jenna, I heard you got married recently?"

Jenna nodded calmly. "Already divorced."

She braced for the expected snide remarks, but was met with unusual silence.

Fiona forced a chuckle. "Young people have plenty of opportunities."

Heidi leaned forward eagerly. "Did you two... live together?"

"No." Jenna eyed her suspiciously.

Fiona and Heidi exchanged a look of barely concealed delight.

This answer clearly pleased them immensely.

Waiters began serving the meal. Jenna's lips curled at the meager spread.

For a restaurant famed for seafood, only a single sea bass graced the table.

Sean suddenly stopped a departing waiter. "Do you have lobster?"

"Yes, sir." The waiter bowed slightly. "We have both Australian lobster and Caribbean spiny lobster available."
###Chapter 212

Fiona Roland's heart lurched violently, her fingernails digging into her palms without conscious thought.

She forced composure as she waved at the waiter. "That will be all for now."

The waiter bowed and retreated, leaving the private dining room in eerie silence.

Jenna Roland tapped her chopsticks twice against her bowl before speaking abruptly. "Uncle Victor, you still have my parents' suicide note, don't you?"

Victor Roland froze mid-bite, his chopsticks suspended in air. Deep furrows appeared between his brows. "Why bring this up now?"

"Just occurred to me." Jenna poked at her rice. "Five years ago you claimed to have burned it. But something never added up."

Victor's expression darkened as he set down his chopsticks and wiped his mouth. "Why dredge up ancient history?"

"Suicide notes..." Jenna lifted her gaze to meet his directly, "are written by people expecting to die. My parents died in a car crash. When would they have had time to write one?"

Fiona's soup spoon clattered into her bowl.

Victor's temple vein bulged. "What exactly are you implying?"

"Take it literally." Jenna's smile turned icy. "My brother verified the handwriting. It wasn't our father's. And we all know who benefited."

Victor slammed the table. "Preposterous! That note was in your father's bedroom! I never had access to your house keys!"

"What about the orchard then?" Jenna pressed relentlessly. "Why was it secretly transferred to your name?"

Sean Roland gaped at his father. "Dad...is this true?"

"You know nothing!" Victor snapped before forcing a conciliatory smile at Jenna. "You'll marry eventually. We couldn't let the orchard go to outsiders..."

Jenna clenched her fists until her nails drew blood. The surveillance footage of her parents still lay in her bag. Tonight's performance had only just begun.
###Chapter 213

Jenna Roland clenched her fists, nails digging deep into her palms.

She would marry someday, but not now.

That orchard was her parents' legacy. She and her brother Milo were the rightful heirs. Why should they hand it over to Victor Roland, an outsider?

"Milo can't manage the orchard because of his health?" Jenna scoffed. "If not for your interference, the orchard would've been mine years ago!"

Victor lounged with his legs crossed, smug. "Your parents died young. Without my hard work, the orchard would've gone to waste. You should be thanking me."

His words ignited Jenna's fury.

"The will clearly states the orchard returns to me upon marriage," she shot up from her seat. "How dare you go back on your word?"

"Naive!" Victor slammed the table. "After all my effort, you think I'd walk away empty-handed? The orchard is under my name now. Forget about reclaiming it!"

Fiona Roland kicked Victor under the table, shooting him a venomous glare.

"What's wrong with you?" Victor yelped in pain.

Fiona gritted her teeth. They were supposed to coax Jenna, but this idiot had ruined everything. The $80,000 reward was slipping through their fingers.

"Where's the will?" Jenna demanded.

"Burned it," Victor sneered. "You saw it yourself."

Jenna's heart sank.

She had wanted to verify the handwriting. But if the will was forged, Victor would've destroyed the evidence.

That mysterious wooden box was her only hope now.

In the past, she would've stormed out. But for the truth, she had to endure.

"Dad," Sean Roland spoke up, "the orchard never belonged to you. Return it to Jenna and Milo."

Victor was about to explode when Fiona kicked him again.

"Enough! We're here to eat, not argue!" Fiona snapped.

Heidi Roland quickly mediated. "We're family. Let's not fight."

Jenna silently finished her meal, then looked up. "You're right. The orchard should be yours."

"What?" Victor gaped.

"You've managed it for years. You understand it better than I do." Jenna forced a smile, swallowing her disgust. "I won't take it back."

Victor froze.

He knew better than anyone how far Jenna would go to reclaim the orchard—even marrying a stranger.
###Chapter 214

Jenna's gaze lingered on the keychain at Victor's waist.

"Still going to weed the orchard this afternoon?" she asked abruptly.

Victor froze.

They'd just been arguing heatedly moments ago. Now she was asking about gardening?

What game was this girl playing?

Fiona smoothed things over with a smile. "The sun's too intense now. Let's wait till it cools down."

"Then I'll take my leave." Jenna stood and walked out without another word.

Sean hurried after her.

Once they were out of earshot, Fiona's pleasant expression twisted into fury.

"Victor!" she hissed through clenched teeth. "You almost ruined everything!"

Victor snorted. "I can't stand her smug face."

"Eighty thousand dollars!" Fiona lowered her voice. "We might even squeeze out more. But if you scare her off, we get nothing!"

She glared at her husband. "You will control yourself until that money's in our hands!"

The mention of money finally subdued Victor.

......

Outside the restaurant, Sean caught up with Jenna.

"I never thought he'd secretly transfer the orchard's ownership," he said bitterly.

Jenna gave a humorless laugh. "There's plenty you don't know."

"You think the will was forged?" Sean frowned.

"The sole beneficiary being him? Highly suspicious," Jenna said flatly.

Sean shook his head. "Knowing my father, he'd seize the orchard with or without a will. I doubt he even wrote it."

"Then who did?" Jenna stopped abruptly.

"If we find the will, I can verify if it's his handwriting," Sean offered.

Jenna bit her lip. "Even if we find it, Milo said the signatures don't match."

"You're planning to use it in court?" Sean looked startled.

"A genuine will would force him to return the orchard," Jenna sighed. "Too bad it's fake."

Sean gave a pained smile. "If only your father were still—"

"If he were alive, your father wouldn't have gotten his hands on that orchard," Jenna cut in coldly.

The will was just a pretext anyway.

What she truly sought was the truth behind her parents' deaths.

That wooden box held too many secrets.

She had to get those keys.
###Chapter 215

Jenna Roland leaned against the doorframe, arms crossed. Her piercing gaze locked onto Sean Roland. "Big brother, have you ever seen Dad's carved wooden box?"

Sean paused while organizing documents. He looked up, confused. "What box?"

Since graduating college, he'd moved out of the Roland family home.

The old house was too small. If he returned, Jenna and Milo would have to share a room. Over the years, he'd preferred renting near the company rather than going back.

A flicker of disappointment crossed Jenna's eyes before she forced a casual smile. "Never mind. I just saw it while cleaning the closet. Thought it looked unique."

She'd lived in the Roland house for five years and never once spotted that box.

Victor Roland must have hidden it deliberately. Only after she moved out did that old fox dare to leave it in plain sight.

"Should I ask for you?" Sean closed the file folder.

"No!" Jenna waved her hands hastily. "If Uncle Victor finds out I'm asking, he'll accuse me of meddling again."

Sean considered this and dropped the subject. He grabbed his car keys. "Where to? I'll drive you."

"The orchard." Jenna slung her backpack over her shoulder.

Sean nodded and led her to the parking lot. He opened the car door for her like a gentleman, waiting until she buckled up before starting the engine.

"It's scorching today. Didn't we agree you'd skip the orchard?" Sean glanced at the blinding sunlight outside.

Jenna stared at the scenery whipping past the window. "Just checking on things. Not working."

"How much longer at the club?" Sean asked abruptly.

Jenna turned to him, lips curving slightly. "Two more weeks. I'll quit once I've saved enough."

"Better leave sooner." Sean kept his eyes on the road. "That place isn't for you."

Jenna gave a soft "Mm."

She'd only taken the club job to pay for Milo's surgery. Now that her brother's treatment was secured, she couldn't wait to get out.

The car stopped at the mountain's base. Sean turned to her. "Call me if you need anything."

"Got it." Jenna waved as the car drove off.

Once the taillights vanished around the bend, she faced the lush orchard. Under the blazing sun, her eyes burned hotter than the daylight.

"Dad... Mom..." she whispered. "I will uncover the truth."

The orchard stood empty at noon. Jenna found a shady spot beneath a dense fruit tree and waited silently.

At 3 PM, Victor's figure finally appeared on the mountain path.

Jenna stood immediately, pretending to prune branches. By 4 PM, she wiped her sweat and approached Victor. "Uncle, I lost my keys. Can I borrow yours?"

Victor frowned. "How?"

"Probably dropped them on my way down." Jenna feigned innocence. "I searched everywhere."

Victor's face darkened, but remembering Fiona's warnings, he suppressed his anger. Slowly, he unhooked the keyring from his belt—

Jenna's heartbeat spiked. A thin layer of sweat coated her back.
###Chapter 216

Victor Roland's slender fingers flicked through the keychain. He detached a single brass key and handed it to her.

Jenna Roland stared at the solitary key, surprise flickering in her eyes.

She had expected the entire set.

"Thanks." Her expression remained neutral as she accepted the cold metal.

"I'll go grocery shopping first."

Victor gave a curt nod, his attention already returning to the documents in his hands.

Descending the hill, Jenna tightened her grip around the key.

Getting the full set wouldn't be that easy.

She could wait a day or two. But weeks? No patience for that.

The mountain breeze lifted her hair. Suddenly, her eyes brightened.

A brilliant idea flashed through her mind.

The market buzzed with noise.

Jenna returned to the Roland residence with a heavy basket of groceries, her steps light.

Pushing open the door, she found only Jason Roland in the living room.

The teenager was curled on the couch gaming, not even glancing up.

"Dinner's ready." Jenna set down the basket. "I'm leaving now."

Jason grunted, his fingers smashing the game controller buttons.

Outside, Jenna stopped at a street vendor for a bowl of beef noodles.

The neon lights of Studio 54 glowed vividly in the night.

"Jenna!" Chloe Blanchet rushed over, grabbing her arm. "Something terrible happened!"

Jenna frowned. "What?"

"Jake Varley attacked Stella Laurent with his gang!" Chloe whispered urgently. "The video's gone viral. You haven't seen it?"

Jenna's pupils constricted.

"When?"

"This afternoon!" Chloe pulled out her phone. "Here, watch."

The footage showed Jake and several thug-like men vandalizing Stella's shop.

Jenna's heart plummeted.

"I'm calling Stella."

The first call went unanswered.

The second rang endlessly before a stranger picked up.

"Hello?" A tired female voice.

"This is Jenna Roland, Stella's friend. Is she there?"

"I'm her sister, Sylvia." Exhaustion laced the reply. "She just fell asleep."

Medical equipment beeped in the background.

"How badly is she hurt?"

"That bastard!" Sylvia's voice suddenly sharpened. "When I get my hands on him—"

A nurse's warning cut her off.

Jenna quickly got the hospital address and hung up.

Chloe leaned in. "Well?"

"At the hospital." Jenna's face paled. "It was definitely Jake."
###Chapter 217

Jenna Roland and Chloe Blanchet were fully aware that Jake Varley had brought people to beat Stella Laurent. The day Jake came looking for trouble with Stella, he ended up being taught a lesson by Tristan Ashcroft's men. To make matters worse, the secret stash of money he'd been saving was stolen by Stella right under his nose.

Jake couldn't swallow this humiliation.

"If I'd known he'd retaliate, I would've told them to beat him harder that day," Jenna said through gritted teeth.

Chloe sighed. "When are you planning to visit Stella?"

"Not today. I have work." Jenna glanced at her watch. "Tomorrow, maybe. It's too late after my shift."

"Alright, call me tomorrow." Chloe nodded.

Jenna turned to change in the locker room. Chloe followed and suddenly lowered her voice. "Speaking of revenge... Sophia Merouin hasn't caused you any trouble since she quit, has she?"

Jenna paused mid-motion.

"She had someone follow me," Jenna said, buttoning her blouse. "The boss found out. That night, Sophia and her lackey were taken away by his men."

Chloe gasped.

"She actually—" Chloe paled. "Thank God the boss stepped in."

Jenna smirked coldly. "She thought there was something between me and the boss. That's why she went crazy."

"So... you and the boss—" Chloe wiggled her eyebrows suggestively.

"Don't even go there!" Jenna shoved her clothes into the locker with force. "We're just employer and employee."

Chloe pouted. "You're gorgeous. It's normal if he's attracted to you."

Jenna shot her a stern look. "Don't spread rumors. That kind of talk helps no one."

They stepped out of the locker room, and Jenna was immediately called away by a client.

The club was unusually busy tonight. With her sweet looks and sharp social skills, Jenna had built a loyal clientele. She barely had time to catch her breath before midnight arrived.

Tristan had promised to let her leave by eleven, but it was already past twelve when Jenna finally got a break.

"The boss wants to see you," a server informed her.

Smoothing her dress, Jenna knocked on Tristan's office door.

"Have a seat." Tristan gestured to the chair across from him.

Jenna closed the door behind her, anxiety creeping in. "Boss, what did you need?"
###Chapter 218

Tristan Ashcroft held a cigarette between his slender fingers, the smoke curling around him as he lounged lazily in his leather chair. His deep gaze settled on Jenna Roland as his thin lips parted. "Some things are better discussed in person. Jenna, you know how much I value you."

He exhaled a slow ring of smoke. "Stay. Name your terms."

Jenna hadn’t expected this again. She rubbed her eyes, her voice steady. "Boss, my brother’s surgery is coming up. I only came here to save up for his medical bills."

"I have enough now. I need to leave."

She paused. "I appreciate everything you’ve done for me, but my mind’s made up."

Tristan took a sharp drag, his brow furrowing. "What will you do after leaving?"

"Maybe open a small diner." Jenna pressed her lips together. "If I don’t have enough capital, I’ll start with a food stall."

"A food stall?" Tristan straightened abruptly. "You’d rather do that than come back?"

Jenna gave a bitter smile. "Not everyone can accept what I do here."

Another cigarette butt joined the ashtray. Tristan stepped closer, his voice low. "One last offer. You can transfer departments—no more alcohol sales."

"I’m sorry." Jenna bowed deeply. "I really can’t stay."

His Adam’s apple bobbed before he finally spoke. "Don’t tell Ethan I approached you."

"Understood."

As Jenna walked away, Tristan slammed his fist onto the desk. Papers scattered as his expression darkened.

The next morning.

Jenna stood at Victor Roland’s doorstep with a grocery basket. Finding the house empty, she dialed a number.

Thirty minutes later, a locksmith named Mason Mackillop arrived in a black T-shirt.

"Can you open this?" Jenna handed him a wooden box.

After inspecting it, Mason shook his head. "Only by force."

"Forget it, then." Jenna frowned. Forcing it would make too much noise—Victor would notice.

After seeing Mason out, she returned the box to its place. Scanning the room, she began searching for other clues.
###Chapter 219

Jenna Roland searched every corner of the bedroom, even crawling under the bed, but only found that suspicious wooden box.

She rubbed her throbbing temples and picked up Victor Roland's dirty clothes from the floor, heading to the bathroom.

The moment the clothes hit the ground, a metallic clink rang out.

Jenna's heart skipped a beat. She frantically pushed aside the fabric. A set of keys lay glinting coldly under the light.

Her breath caught. Her fingers trembled slightly.

This was fate.

She snatched the keys and rushed back to the bedroom. On the fifth try, the lock clicked open.

Inside the box were neatly stacked receipts and bankbooks.

Kneeling on the floor, she flipped through them with ice-cold fingertips. When she unfolded the last document, her blood turned to ice.

Her parents' suicide note.

She stuffed the note into her pocket and noticed a bankbook bearing her father's name.

A fixed deposit of $250,000, inaccessible until August.

Jenna clenched her jaw until it ached, her nails digging into her palms.

So this was why. That bastard Victor wouldn't even spare the dead.

Forcing herself to stay calm, she restored everything. The keys went back on the belt loop. The clothes returned to their pile.

Her heartbeat pounded in her ears.

The front door suddenly creaked open. Jenna slipped into the kitchen, pressing her back against the cold tiles.

Jason Roland's footsteps grew louder.

"Dad, I found the keys," his voice carried through the door. "They were on the pants you wore yesterday."

A spatula slipped from Jenna's grip and clattered loudly against the floor.
###Chapter 220

Jason ignored Jenna's icy glare and walked straight to the couch, sitting down. He pulled out his phone and quickly dialed a number saved under "10086."

The aroma of food wafted from the kitchen. As Jenna plated the last dish, the wall clock struck half past eleven.

The front door swung open. Victor and Fiona walked in one after the other. Jenna silently set the table before calling everyone to eat.

"Aren't you eating?" Fiona glanced at the empty seat.

Jenna shook her head. "I ate before coming."

Victor set down his farming tools. "Come with me to weed the orchard this afternoon."

"Fine." Jenna agreed without hesitation.

Victor frowned at the all-vegetable spread. "Not even a piece of meat?"

Jenna stood beside him. "Meat prices went up. I didn't have enough money."

Jason slammed his chopsticks down. "What about the money you earn at the club? Can't even spare a few bucks for meat?"

"Why should my money feed you?" Jenna smirked coldly.

Heidi rolled her eyes. "So stingy. How much could meat possibly cost?"

"The orchard makes hundreds of thousands a year. If you won't even buy meat for yourselves, why covet my paycheck?" Jenna crossed her arms. "I'm not your cash cow."

Fiona tried to mediate. "She's right. It's not her responsibility."

Victor shoveled rice into his mouth without a word. Jenna's gaze lingered on Heidi before curling into a smirk. "Sis-in-law, you might want to keep an eye out. Wouldn't want your husband to run off with someone else without you knowing."

She hadn't found all the evidence yet, but with her father's will and bankbook secured, Jenna had no qualms about exposing everything.

Jason's face paled. "What nonsense are you spouting?"

"Take it literally. Or do you need it spelled out?" Jenna arched a brow.

Heidi whirled toward her husband. "What have you been doing behind my back?"

Victor slammed his bowl down. Every time Jenna visited, chaos followed.

"She's lying!" Beads of sweat formed on Jason's forehead.

Jenna shrugged. "Just saw a strange number in his phone—something like 10086. Why don't you call it yourself, sis-in-law?"

Jason's pupils constricted. How did she know about that number?

Heidi snatched his phone and dialed the number from his contacts. When Jason tried to stop her, she slapped him across the face.

"Shut up!" she snapped.

The line connected. A sugary female voice cooed, "Jason, missing me already? It's only been an hour since you left..."

Heidi froze as if struck by lightning. The phone clattered to the floor.

Jason dropped to his knees, clutching her legs and begging for forgiveness.
###Chapter 221

In Jenna Roland's eyes, Jason Roland was nothing but a spineless coward.

He acted all high and mighty in front of her, yet cowered like a beaten dog the moment Heidi Roland showed up.

Watching the scene unfold, Jenna curled her lips into a cold smirk.

"Auntie, I'll take my leave now."

She turned to go.

After two steps, she suddenly glanced back at Victor Roland and the others with a sweet smile.

"Almost forgot to mention—the water I used to wash your vegetables came straight from the toilet."

"And I added some... special seasoning to your dishes."

"Hope this little surprise doesn't ruin your appetite."

"Enjoy your meal. Bye~"

The Roland family froze in shock.

By the time they processed her words, Jenna had already slammed the door behind her.

Heidi didn't even bother scolding Jason—she bolted to the bathroom and vomited violently.

Victor flew into a rage, overturning the entire dining table.

Fiona Roland trembled with fury, pointing at the door and screaming.

"Victor! This is all your fault!"

"Why did you ever let that bitch come back?!"

The thought of eating those "enhanced" meals for the past two days made her stomach churn.

Victor's face darkened. "How was I supposed to know she'd pull this?!"

"If I ever see her again, I'll kill her myself!"

Heidi emerged from the bathroom, glowering at Jason.

"Get inside! Now!"

Jason had planned to slip away.

He wanted to wait until Heidi cooled down before explaining.

But before he could move, she caught him.

Cursing Jenna a thousand times in his head, he reluctantly entered the bedroom.

The door slammed shut behind them with a deafening bang.

Two sharp slaps landed across his face.

Bright red handprints bloomed on his cheeks.

He hunched his shoulders, not daring to make a sound.

Heidi jabbed a finger at his nose. "Feeling brave, aren't you?"

"Daring to keep a mistress behind my back?"

"You're not leaving this room alive unless you explain everything!"

Her entire body shook with rage.

All these years, she thought he was different from other men.

Turns out it was all an act!

If Jenna hadn't exposed him, she'd still be in the dark.

Jason dropped to his knees with a thud.

"Sweetheart, let me explain—"

"I did it all for our family!"

"You're the only one in my heart!"

Heidi let out a bitter laugh.
###Chapter 222

Heidi kicked over the coffee table, sending glass shards scattering across the floor. Her trembling finger pointed at Jason's face. "Jason Roland, you dare say cheating on me was for my own good?"

Jason knelt on the floor, sweat beading on his forehead. "Honey, let me explain—"

"Explain my ass!" Heidi grabbed a vase and smashed it at his feet. "Four years! I've drunk enough herbal medicine to drown you!"

Jason grabbed her wrist. "Three failed IVF attempts! What was I supposed to do? Grandpa keeps demanding an heir!"

She wrenched free, chest heaving. The memories flooded back—quack remedies that made her vomit, the agony of egg retrieval that left her unconscious.

"So you went whoring in bars?" Her voice cracked.

Jason groveled. "Just a $5,000 transaction! That woman isn't fit to lick your boots!"

Heidi yanked his collar. "You only met her during ovulation? How convenient!"

His face paled. "I'm sorry—"

"Buy me a Hermès tomorrow." She shoved him away. "Lie to me again—" The fruit knife plunged into the sofa.

Jason gulped. "Done! Anything you want!"

She studied his shifty eyes and smirked. "Where does she live?"

"Eastside Apartments..." He stammered. "Honey, what are you—"

Heidi grabbed her jacket. "To meet the mother of my future 'son.'"
###Chapter 223

Heidi's nails dug deep into her palms.

Jason's words were like a blunt knife, sawing through her heart over and over. The images haunted her—his entangled silhouette with that woman.

She lowered her gaze to her flat stomach.

Why could others conceive so easily, while she remained barren? Had she committed some unforgivable sin in a past life?

Tears slid down her cheeks silently.

She wasn't weeping over her husband's betrayal. She was mourning her own inadequacy.

She understood the looks Fiona and Victor exchanged. If she failed to conceive soon, they'd force her to divorce Jason.

But she couldn't bear to let go.

Taking a shuddering breath, Heidi wiped her tears. "What will you tell your parents about the baby?"

Jason answered without hesitation. "We'll say you're pregnant, and I'm sending you to your parents' place for prenatal care. After the other woman delivers, we'll bring you back."

Her heart plummeted.

He'd already prepared the lie.

"Must you... sleep with her?"

"What choice do we have?"

She bit her lip. Apart from artificial insemination, there truly was no other way.

"Don't tell me about your... encounters." Her voice trembled. "I can't bear it."

Jason nodded.

......

Jenna hung up the phone and sped to Blue Bottle Coffee on her e-bike.

Sean was already waiting by the window.

"Big brother." She slid into the seat across from him. "Have you been waiting long?"

"Just got here."

After the server delivered their coffees, Sean cut to the chase. "What's this about?"

Jenna pulled the suicide note from her bag and pushed it toward him. "Is this your father's handwriting?"

Sean studied it carefully before shaking his head. "No."

His father had minimal education. Such elegant cursive was beyond him.

"Then who wrote it?" Jenna's gaze sharpened.

"No relative could write like this." Sean's eyes turned flinty. "An outsider must have penned it."

Jenna frowned. "Could your father have hired someone?"
###Chapter 224

Sean Roland tapped his slender fingers against the table. "That's certainly possible."

Jenna Roland leaned back on the couch, her eyes dim. "Even if we're sure he forged it, he'll deny everything in court. We have no solid proof."

"Jenna," Sean said gently, "Managing an orchard is too much for you. Why not find an easier job? It would give you more time to care for Milo."

She gave a bitter smile. "I can't even get the orchard back now. There's nothing left to manage."

A waiter approached, placing a latte in front of Jenna. "Your coffee, ma'am."

"Thank you." She took a sip, then turned to Sean with a thoughtful gaze. "Why would Uncle Victor hide the will for so long?"

She remembered him claiming years ago that it had been destroyed. Its sudden reappearance was suspicious.

Sean shook his head. "Father's motives are hard to guess. But if he kept it all these years, it must be important. Keep it safe."

"Mm." She carefully folded the document and tucked it into her bag.

Glancing at her watch, Jenna stood. "I need to visit Stella. Her ex-boyfriend beat her up—she's in the hospital."

Sean's brow furrowed. "What happened?"

After hearing the details, his expression darkened. "That scum. At least she got away in time."

Jenna grabbed her purse. "I’ll head out now. We’ll talk later."

"Be careful." He watched her leave before finishing his coffee at a leisurely pace.

In the hospital room, Sylvia Savigny sat by the bed, peeling an apple. The conversation stopped when Jenna entered.

"Feeling any better?" Jenna set a fruit basket on the nightstand, then froze at the sight of Stella.

A bandage covered Stella's forehead. Her left cheek was bruised, her right lip crusted with dried blood. Puffy eyes barely stayed open. Worst of all, her left leg hung in a cast, suspended by a metal frame.

"It's just minor injuries," Stella rasped, forcing a weak smile.

Sylvia slammed the fruit knife down. "A fractured leg and internal bleeding—'minor'?"

Dressed in an elegant navy velvet gown, her curls cascading over her shoulders, Sylvia's polished appearance only magnified Stella's haggard state.

Jenna sucked in a sharp breath. "That bastard! I should’ve let security break his legs that night!"

"My mistake for trusting him." Stella's voice was hoarse. "Don’t waste your energy on me."

Sylvia crossed her arms, fury burning in her striking eyes. "I already gave Jake Varley’s file to Mr. Lucien. He promised to make that trash pay."
###Chapter 225

Jenna frowned slightly, turning to Stella. "Who's this 'Brother Lu'?"

Stella glanced at Sylvia, who remained silent, then lowered her voice. "You must keep this confidential."

"I promise." Jenna raised three fingers solemnly.

Stella leaned closer, whispering, "Lucien Valois. The second son of Mayor Valois of Los Angeles. My sister is... involved with him."

Jenna's pupils contracted sharply. She'd seen the mayor on the news but never imagined Sylvia would be entangled with his son.

"How did they meet?" Jenna pressed.

She only knew Sylvia had worked at a nightclub, not the specifics.

Sylvia crossed her legs, twirling a lock of hair around her finger. "He frequented the club. Others couldn't handle him. I could." Her red lips curved. "Over time, this happened."

"You two..." Jenna trailed off.

Sylvia smirked. "Exactly what you're thinking."

Jenna inhaled sharply. So Sylvia was Lucien's mistress!

No wonder Jake Varley had bitten off more than he could chew.

Suddenly, Sylvia's smile vanished. Her gaze turned icy. "Jenna, I'm only telling you because of Stella. Not a word leaves this room."

"Why?" Jenna asked, confused.

Stella bit her lip. "Lucien... is married."

Jenna nearly dropped her glass.

Lucien Valois had a wife?!

The implications hit her instantly. If this got out, Sylvia would face public scorn. The mayor's daughter-in-law wouldn't let it slide.

A woman who could marry into the Valois family undoubtedly had formidable connections.
