What she didn't notice were the piercing eyes watching her intently from behind the tinted window.
###Chapter 339

Ethan Roscente's gaze lingered on the slender figure until she disappeared around the street corner. The warmth in his eyes faded, replaced by a cold sharpness.

"Mr. Roscente, the clothes are ready. Should I deliver them to you?" Lucas Roscente, his assistant, asked cautiously from the driver's seat.

"No need." Ethan withdrew his gaze. "Take me back to the office."

"Understood." Lucas placed the shopping bag on the passenger seat and started the car.

At seven in the evening, Jenna Roland finished packing up her street stall and pedaled her e-tricycle home.

Three men in black suits stood smoking under her apartment building. Jenna glanced at them but paid no mind. She parked and was about to unload her goods when one of them suddenly spoke.

"Need help?"

Jenna eyed them warily and shook her head. "No, thanks."

She struggled to drag a large bag of clothes toward the entrance. Unexpectedly, the three men picked up the remaining packages without prompting.

"What are you doing?" Milo Roland immediately stepped forward to block them.

The leader flashed a friendly smile. "You looked like you could use a hand."

Jenna, now at her door, turned back. "We don't know each other. Why help me?"

The man pulled out his ID. "We just moved in—seventh floor. Check my ID if you're worried."

Jenna hesitated. She'd never encountered such eager strangers before.

"You live here too?" she asked skeptically.

"Yeah, seventh floor." He pocketed his ID. "Which floor are you on?"

"Sixth." After a pause, she relented. "Well... thanks."

The three efficiently carried the packages upstairs. When the elevator stopped on the sixth floor, Jenna took them back. "I can handle the rest."

She watched them head to the seventh floor before unlocking her door.

Upstairs, Ryan Roland's phone rang. He straightened instantly at the caller ID.

"Mr. Roscente."

"Did you see her?" The voice on the line was icy.

"Delivered Miss Roland's belongings to her doorstep," Ryan answered respectfully.

"Keep watching." Ethan ended the call without another word.
###Chapter 340

Morning sunlight streamed through the curtains as Jenna Roland rose early to prepare breakfast. She placed golden fried eggs and steaming milk on the table before calling Ethan Roscente to join her.

After their meal, Jenna began organizing the clothes she planned to sell that day. As she dragged two heavy bags toward the door, she ran into Wyatt Roland, who had helped her yesterday.

"Good morning!" Jenna's eyes brightened. "Thank you again for your help."

Wyatt grinned. "No trouble at all."

"Are you here to see a friend?" Jenna asked curiously.

"Yeah, but he went out to buy groceries." Wyatt glanced at the bags on the floor. "Setting up your stall?"

Jenna nodded. "I need to catch the morning crowd."

"Let me carry these down for you," Wyatt offered. "I've got nothing else to do."

Jenna hesitated. "I couldn't impose..."

"Don't worry about it." Wyatt bent down and hoisted two bags effortlessly. "Grab another one, and I'll take them all down."

Jenna returned with two more bulging sacks, expecting Wyatt to make two trips. Instead, he lifted both in one hand and strode toward the elevator.

"My God!" Milo Roland's eyes widened. "That's insane strength!"

Jenna swallowed hard, equally stunned.

Ethan, standing nearby, narrowed his eyes, his expression darkening.

"I'll help," he said abruptly, striding past Jenna to grab the last bag before she could respond.

Jenna and Milo exchanged startled glances.

Inside the elevator, Wyatt and Ethan arranged the bags neatly in the corner. The confined space crackled with unspoken tension between the two tall men.

"Do you work out often?" Jenna asked, trying to ease the awkwardness. "These must weigh at least sixty pounds."

Wyatt chuckled. "I'm used to it. This is nothing."

Ethan stood behind Jenna, his gaze icy. Wyatt sensed the hostility and fell silent.

When the elevator reached the ground floor, Wyatt quickly unloaded the bags. Jenna noticed the veins standing out on Ethan's forearms as he carried two sacks.

"I'll get the bike," Jenna said, pulling Milo away.

By the time she returned with the e-tricycle, the men had already loaded everything. Wyatt muttered a hasty goodbye and retreated upstairs.

"See you later." Jenna started the engine and waved at Ethan.

He remained motionless, watching until the e-tricycle vanished around the corner. Morning light carved sharp shadows across his rigid profile.
###Chapter 341

At the corner of Taihe Road pedestrian street, Jenna Roland was setting up a food stall with her younger brother Milo Roland. Early summer sunlight filtered through the plane trees, casting dappled shadows on their stand.

Milo's phone suddenly vibrated.

He pulled it from his canvas bag. The screen displayed "Ryan Watson."

After taking the call by the sidewalk tree, Milo's expression darkened.

"Ryan's got acute appendicitis. The hospital needs six thousand for surgery." His grip tightened on the phone. "His parents aren't reachable. Can we lend him the money?"

Jenna kept working while scanning a QR code to transfer funds.

"Sent fifty-five hundred. That covers surgery and recovery expenses." She glanced up at her brother. "Tell him to focus on getting better. The money can wait."

Milo's eyes reddened slightly as he hailed a cab to the hospital.

With no customers at the moment, Jenna sat on a plastic stool playing mobile games. Occasionally she helped Tanya Hill, the neighboring accessories vendor, with customers. Morning slipped into noon.

At exactly eleven, Jenna headed to "Tasty Bites" on the corner.

The affordable eatery offered four dishes for ten dollars—a lunch staple for local vendors.

Carrying takeout boxes back, Jenna froze mid-step.

A sharply dressed figure stood by her stall.

Ethan Roscente had his back to her, phone pressed to his ear. His tailored suit accentuated broad shoulders tapering to a narrow waist.

As if sensing her gaze, he turned abruptly. Their eyes met, and Jenna's heartbeat stuttered.

"What are you doing here?" she asked, approaching.

Ethan pocketed his phone, gaze dropping to her takeout. "Client meeting nearby. Thought I'd stop by."

Jenna arched a brow. "Female client?"

His Adam's apple bobbed in silent confirmation.

"Had lunch yet?" She extended the containers. "Try some working-class cuisine."

Ethan's brow twitched almost imperceptibly at the flimsy plastic boxes. As CEO of HM Group, his usual haunts were Michelin-starred restaurants.

Today, he was just an ordinary department manager.

"Thanks." His fingers brushed hers as he accepted the food.

Jenna turned to fetch another meal, missing the intensity in his eyes as they followed her retreating form.
###Chapter 342

Jenna returned to find Ethan sitting behind their street stall, finishing his takeout lunch.

The plastic container was nearly empty.

She crouched beside him and sampled her own meal. "Not bad, right?"

Ethan glanced up. "Not as good as yours."

Her eyes curved into crescents. "Obviously. If I opened a restaurant, the whole block would line up." She propped her chin on her palm. "Too bad I'm chicken."

"Caution is a virtue," he said flatly.

"Exactly." Jenna shook her head. "Money's safest in the bank."

The corner of Ethan's mouth twitched. He didn't respond.

To her surprise, he'd cleaned his entire portion.

"You said it wasn't tasty," she teased, arching a brow.

"You paid for it." His gaze remained steady. "Waste is unacceptable."

Laughing, she collected the empty container. "Smart man. Every penny counts."

Suddenly clutching her stomach, she stood. "Watch the stall for me?"

Ethan gave a noncommittal hum without looking up.

The moment Jenna left, two girls stopped at their display.

"How much for this?" A floral-dressed girl held up a gray T-shirt.

Ethan pocketed his phone and approached.

Both girls flushed.

"Eighty," he said absently.

"Sold!" The girl pointed to a white dress. "And this?"

"Ninety."

She handed over the clothes. "Could you wrap them?"

Silently, Ethan bagged the items. "One-seventy."

After scanning the payment QR code, the girl dragged her friend back to browse more.

Soon, a growing crowd of young women gathered around.

"Can I add your WeChat?" A ponytailed girl asked boldly.

Jenna returned just in time to hear the question.

She couldn't suppress a giggle.

Ethan's expression darkened instantly. "Amusing?"

Jenna pressed her lips together. "Not at all."

For business's sake, she winked at the girls. "He's single, you know."

The crowd erupted in excitement.

Ethan's face turned thunderous.
###Chapter 343

The night market buzzed with neon lights and lively chatter. Ethan Roscente pushed through the crowd, his gaze instantly locking onto Jenna Roland surrounded by giggling girls.

"Hey handsome, can I get your number?" A redhead batted her lashes, leaning too close.

Jenna flashed her practiced customer-service smile. "Sure! My brother's actually single—"

Ethan's expression darkened. He strode forward and yanked Jenna against his side.

"She's my wife."

Silence crashed over the group.

Jenna's eyes widened, lips parting like a startled rabbit.

The girls froze, then erupted.

"Married? What a liar!"
"Playing games with people?"
"Disgusting!"

As insults flew, the crowd dispersed. Jenna paled, stealing a glance at Ethan.

His chiseled face was stormy, eyes brewing danger.

"Why...why'd you say that?" She shrank back, voice fading.

Ethan caged her against the stall wall, forearm braced beside her head. His breath scorched her cheek.

"I don't have a girlfriend?" The low threat vibrated between them.

She ducked her chin. "It's just business..."

"So you tell them I'm single?" His lids lowered to slits.

"Well...you don't have a girlfriend." Her mutter barely carried. "We're married..."

"Jenna!" His jaw clenched audibly.

Nearby vendors perked up, ears practically twitching.

She twisted her fingers. "It's not like you wanted this marriage anyway."

A vein throbbed at Ethan's temple. His fist slammed into the wall beside her head.

"Last warning." His whisper seared her ear. "Remember your place."

Heat flooded Jenna's face. She turned away stubbornly, only to hear his scoff as he stalked off.

The night breeze carried away his lingering warmth. Watching his retreating figure, her pulse stuttered inexplicably.
###Chapter 344

"Did you remember what I said?" Ethan's voice was icy, his gaze sharp.

Jenna pressed her lips together and nodded reluctantly. "I did."

Ethan scoffed and strode away without another word.

She watched his retreating figure, fingers tangling in her hair in confusion.

What was his problem?

He'd been forced into this marriage by Grandma Blanche. He clearly didn't like her. So why did he care so much about her response?

Jenna rolled her eyes, her expression dismissive.

Only when Ethan's taxi disappeared around the corner did she return to her stall.

Tanya immediately scooted closer, eyes bright with excitement. "Jenna, was that really your husband?"

"Technically," Jenna replied flatly.

"What do you mean 'technically'?" Tanya frowned.

Jenna looked up. "We're married on paper. No feelings involved."

Tanya stood abruptly. "Legally, you're husband and wife. And he's gorgeous! He even treats you well. Why not give it a real shot?"

"Treats me well?" Jenna's brows knitted together.

"He helped you sell clothes earlier. Then he publicly announced your marriage with his arm around you. Would he go that far if he didn't like you?"

Jenna froze.

Tanya's words triggered a memory—waking up that morning to find Ethan lying beside her.

Had that been... intentional?

And just now, when she'd said Ethan didn't have a girlfriend, he'd clearly been angry.

A shiver ran down Jenna's spine.

Oh god. Could Ethan actually have feelings for her?

Tanya nudged her. "Hey, what's with the spaced-out look?"

"Why would he like me?" The words tumbled out before Jenna could stop them.

Tanya laughed. "You're beautiful and capable. Who wouldn't fall for you? Too bad you're already taken."

"Too bad?" Jenna arched an eyebrow.

Tanya sighed. "I was going to introduce you to my son. Now that's off the table. Though honestly, compared to your husband, my boy wouldn't stand a chance."

Jenna bit back a laugh.

If they hadn't been in public, she would've doubled over with laughter.
###Chapter 345

Jenna Roland's smile faded as her gaze settled on Tanya Hill. "How old is your son this year?"

Tanya sat back on the small stool. "Twenty-eight. He writes code at an internet company."

Jenna's lips curved slightly. "Being a programmer is good—stable income. He'll definitely find a nice girl someday."

"Good? He stays up all night and loses hair!" Tanya waved her hands dismissively. "Don't even mention him. Gives me a headache."

"Alright."

Jenna had just pulled out her phone to call Milo Roland about Ryan Watson's condition when three young girls walked into the shop to browse clothes.

After seeing the customers out, Jenna picked up her phone again—only for the screen to light up with an incoming call from Grandma Blanche.

Her brow furrowed as she answered. "Grandma."

Blanche's gentle voice came through. "Jenna, dear. Do you have a moment? There's something I'd like to discuss."

"Go ahead."

"Ethan's cousin was released from prison yesterday. His uncle wants Ethan to arrange a position for him at the company. Could you mention it to him?"

Jenna's frown deepened. "Grandma, you're his grandmother. Wouldn't it be more appropriate for you to ask?"

"Ah, but Ethan only listens to you now." Blanche sighed. "Of course, if it's inconvenient, just forget it."

Jenna knew this wasn't a request—it was an obligation. That "if it's inconvenient" was nothing but politeness.

"What if he refuses?"

"He'll agree if you ask."

The certainty in Blanche's tone left no room for refusal. Jenna took a deep breath. "Fine. I'll try."

After hanging up, she massaged her temples. At least she'd cut ties with her own relatives. If they knew Ethan was a director at HM Group, every distant aunt and cousin would be knocking down her door.

Sometimes, having no family was a blessing.

......

At 7:30 p.m., Jenna returned home to find Ethan still absent.

She organized the day's inventory before heading to the kitchen. Though she'd had snacks in the afternoon, she decided to prepare a simple meal since Milo would be joining them.

The fridge still had fresh vegetables. Jenna settled on scrambled eggs with tomatoes, stir-fried water spinach, and a simple cabbage and egg drop soup.

Just as she set the dishes on the table, Milo walked in.

"How's Ryan?" Jenna handed him a bowl of rice.

Milo accepted it. "The surgery went well. Otherwise, I wouldn't be back."

"Who's taking care of him at the hospital now?" Jenna served herself some water spinach.

"Me." Milo shoveled rice into his mouth. "I have to go back after this."
###Chapter 346

Ryan Watson's fingers trembled slightly as he took the e-bike keys. Jenna Roland felt a pang of pity watching him.

"Ride safely."

Milo Roland wolfed down his meal and grabbed his keys.

"See you later, sis!"

Jenna called after her brother's retreating figure. "Slow down!"

After washing the dishes, Jenna took a hot shower. When she stepped out, the wall clock showed 9:30 PM.

She frowned at her phone screen, hovering her finger over Ethan Roscente's contact. Finally, she lowered her hand.

"He'll just get angry if I call this late."

A familiar black profile picture suddenly caught her eye in the WhatsApp contacts. Jenna's pupils contracted, her finger freezing mid-air.

"Strange... Didn't he delete me?"

She opened the chat window and typed after some hesitation: "When are you coming back?"

Two minutes passed with no response. Jenna headed to the bedroom, completely missing the incoming call notification flashing on the sofa.

Just as she finished her skincare routine, she noticed Gavin Valentine's missed call. This reserved man never called without reason.

The moment she answered, Gavin's urgent voice came through: "Ms. Roland, why didn't you pick up?"

"I was busy. What's wrong?"

"Ethan's drunk at Studio 54! If I hadn't run into him—"

Jenna's chest tightened. "Which room?"

"VIP 888. Don't mention my call!"

"Can't you take him home?"

"My clients are still here!" Gavin hung up abruptly.

Jenna stared at the darkened screen, nails digging into her palms. Studio 54—the place she never wanted to set foot in again.
###Chapter 347

Jenna Roland stepped into Studio 54, her heels clicking against the marble floor.

The glow of crystal chandeliers cascaded over her, illuminating her delicate profile.

Staff members nodded respectfully as she passed.

"Good evening, Ms. Roland."

"You look stunning tonight, Ms. Roland."

She acknowledged them with a slight tilt of her head and headed straight for VIP Room 888.

"Jenna?"

Tristan Ashcroft's voice came from the side.

She paused mid-step and turned to face the impeccably suited club owner.

"Boss."

Tristan closed the distance between them, lowering his voice. "What are you doing here?"

"Gavin said Ethan was drunk. I came to take him home."

Understanding flickered in Tristan's eyes.

He'd always known the true nature of their marriage.

"Bad timing."

Jenna's brows drew together. "Why?"

"Lucien Valois is upstairs." His expression darkened. "If he sees you, there'll be trouble."

Her face paled.

She pushed open the private room door without hesitation.

The opulent space held only one occupant.

Ethan Roscente's pale complexion stood in stark contrast against his black dress shirt.

Slumped on the sofa, his tie hung loose. Unnatural flush colored his cheeks.

Jenna hurried forward.

"Ethan?"

He lifted his head slowly, gaze unfocused.

As he tried to stand, his legs gave way, sending him crashing toward her.

Instinctively, she caught him.

His scorching body weight pressed against hers.

The pungent scent of alcohol assaulted her senses.

"Ethan! Get up!"

His breath fanned across her neck.

Eyes half-lidded, he suddenly smiled—soft, tender.

"Yvonne..."

Jenna froze.

The name stabbed through her heart like a blade.

She shoved him away violently.

Ethan hit the floor with a heavy thud.

Without looking back, she fled the room.

The impact jolted him awake.

The lingering scent of roses clung to his fingertips.

When he looked up, all he caught was a glimpse of retreating figure through the closing door.

Ethan's expression contorted.

He scrambled to his feet, but only heard the fading click of heels.

The door still swayed slightly.

Rubbing his temples, he frowned.

What had he just said?
###Chapter 348

The sudden ringtone shattered the silence.

He struggled to rise from the couch, only to collapse back onto it. Gritting his teeth, he finally grabbed the phone.

Gavin Valentine's name flashed on the screen.

He answered the call.

......

Jenna Roland had just reached the stairwell when she nearly collided with Stella Laurent ascending the steps.

"Jenna?" Stella's eyes widened in surprise. "What are you doing here?"

Jenna quickly schooled her expression, forcing a smile. "Just passing through. Don't mind me."

Stella immediately noticed her bloodshot eyes and trembling voice.

"What happened?" Stella reached for her hand.

Jenna pulled away. "Not now."

As she turned, she spotted Ethan Roscente and Gavin descending the stairs.

The chandelier light illuminated Ethan's face with cruel clarity. That intimate nickname echoed in her ears again.

"I'll call you tomorrow." Jenna shook off Stella's grip and fled down the stairs without looking back.

Stella stared after her retreating figure, brow furrowed.

Ethan leaned heavily against Gavin, clearly intoxicated.

"What did she say?" Gavin's voice was dark.

Stella shook her head. "She wouldn't tell me."

Gavin didn't press further, guiding Ethan away.

Stella climbed the stairs and pushed open the door to VIP Room 308.

Lucien Valois lounged at the center of the leather sofa, his pink silk shirt unbuttoned at the collar.

Three black-suited bodyguards stood sentry around the room.

"Mr. Valois." Stella stopped at a respectful distance.

Lucien swirled his whiskey, sharp eyes assessing her. "I thought you and Jenna were close friends."

Stella instantly understood his implication.

"We... haven't spoken recently." Her voice was barely above a whisper.

Lucien chuckled and downed the remaining liquor in one swallow.
###Chapter 349

Stella clenched her fists so tightly her nails dug into her palms. The deference in her eyes had vanished, replaced by seething hatred.

"Mr. Valois, I just want to know where my sister is." Her voice trembled, each word forced through gritted teeth.

Seven days. Seven days without a single trace of Sylvia. Stella had called her sister's phone until it went dead. She'd questioned every friend, followed every lead—nothing.

Her first suspects were Lucien Valois and his wife Yvonne.

After all, Sylvia had been Lucien's mistress for years. She'd even sabotaged his affair with Jenna. If Yvonne discovered her husband's infidelity, she wouldn't let it slide.

Stella had turned the city upside down searching for Lucien. Now that she'd cornered him, she wouldn't back down.

"What did you say?" Lucien's brow furrowed.

"Stop pretending!" Stella's voice cracked like a whip. "Did you kill my sister?"

Her eyes burned with unshed tears. Sylvia was her only family. For her, Stella would risk everything.

Lucien's expression darkened. "I didn't kill her."

"Then was it your wife?" Stella advanced on him.

After a weighted pause, Lucien said, "I'll look into it."

He handed her his business card. Stella dialed the number on the spot to verify it before leaving.

The moment she was gone, Lucien summoned his bodyguard.

"Talk." His voice could freeze hell. "What do you know?"

The bodyguard kept his head bowed, barely daring to breathe.
###Chapter 350

The bodyguard trembled violently, nearly collapsing to his knees.

"Madam Yvonne had Miss Sylvia kidnapped. Her condition is unknown." His voice shook with fear.

Lucien Valois slammed his glass down, pressing his knuckles against his temple.

Yvonne had actually targeted Sylvia.

He knew his wife's temperament too well. Sylvia's chances of survival were slim.

His slender fingers picked up a cigarette. The bodyguard immediately offered a light.

Amid the swirling smoke, Lucien narrowed his eyes.

"Find her. I want to see her alive or dead."

The bodyguard bowed and retreated.

......

Jenna Roland stood by the roadside hailing a cab.

She had intended to go to a hotel, but all her belongings were still at Beverly Hills.

In the end, she took a taxi home.

The moment she entered, she grabbed her charger to leave again.

Then she hesitated. Walking out like this would be irresponsible.

Grandma Blanche had been so kind to her. She couldn't betray the old lady's goodwill.

Jenna sighed, dropping her bag before heading to shower.

She had just towel-dried her hair when the door clicked open.

Gavin Valentine supported a heavily intoxicated Ethan Roscente at the threshold.

"Mr. Valentine." Jenna gave a curt nod, turning toward her room.

Gavin's brow furrowed.

He guided Ethan onto the sofa.

"Water." Ethan loosened his tie, his voice hoarse.

Tonight's excessive drinking stemmed entirely from the day's events.

He'd vomited twice during the ride, only now regaining slight sobriety.

Gavin handed him a glass, unable to contain his question. "What happened between you two?"

Ethan lit a cigarette, taking a deep drag.

He wished he knew the reason too.

"No idea."

Gavin nearly leapt up.

"You must've done something! She used to be so polite to you!"
###Chapter 351

Ethan Roscente's cigarette burned halfway between his fingers. He lifted his gaze to Gavin Valentine, his voice low. "All I remember is lying on the floor and Jenna Roland slamming the door on her way out. Everything before that is a blank."

Gavin's eyes widened in disbelief.

What kind of excuse was this? A drunken blackout? But Ethan had been conscious. How could he not remember anything?

Wait—Ethan said he fell. Did he trip on his own, or did Jenna push him?

If it was the latter, something must have happened to provoke Jenna's fury. Or... had Ethan crossed a line while drunk?

Either scenario would explain Jenna's current attitude.

Gavin sighed and pulled a cigarette from Ethan's pack.

Leaning back into the leather sofa, he took a deep drag and exhaled a slow stream of smoke. "Man, you're in deep trouble."

Ethan remained silent, mechanically repeating the motion of smoking.

Gavin stubbed out his cigarette and turned to him. "Want me to test the waters for you?"

"Fine."

The immediate answer nearly made Gavin choke on his smoke.

This guy really had no shame.

Whatever. He was family. Gavin resigned himself and stood. "Stay out of sight. I'll call Jenna out to talk. I can't just barge into your bedroom—"

Before he could finish, Ethan was already striding toward the door.

Gavin's lips twitched as he watched him leave, then turned toward the master bedroom.

"Jenna, it's Gavin," he said softly, knocking. "Can we talk?"

Inside the bedroom, Jenna had just lain down when the knock came.

She opened the door, confirming Ethan wasn't in the living room before asking coldly, "What do you want, Mr. Valentine?"

"Let's talk in the living room." Gavin motioned for her to follow.

Once seated, he cut straight to the point. "What happened between you and Ethan at the club's private room?"

Jenna's brows furrowed slightly. "Why do you ask?"

"You've been ignoring him since you got back, and the pickup mission was a failure. I need to know why."

"Nothing happened." Jenna met his gaze, her expression eerily calm, but an icy aura radiated from her.

Gavin gave a wry smile. "You really expect me to believe that?"

Jenna pressed her lips together. "He lost his balance and fell on me. That's all."

Gavin rubbed his forehead.

Even a three-year-old wouldn't buy that flimsy excuse.

"Jenna, we're adults. You don't have to tell him, but you can tell me the truth."

How could she admit that Ethan had called another woman's name while kissing her? The humiliation was too much to voice.

"Mr. Valentine, Ethan has done so much for me. No matter what happened, I have no right to be angry. Let him come back and rest. I'm going to sleep."

Without waiting for a response, Jenna stood and retreated to her room.

Gavin shook his head at the closed door. It seemed this marital crisis would have to be resolved by the two of them alone.
###Chapter 352

Gavin Valentine rose and walked to the door, turning the handle.

Ethan Roscente stood outside with a stormy expression.

"She didn't say anything." Gavin shrugged. "Your call."

He patted Ethan's shoulder and stepped past him.

Ethan entered silently, closing the door behind him.

No light seeped from beneath the bedroom door.

Pushing it open gently, he saw Jenna Roland already lying on the floor bedding, illuminated by the hallway light.

Ethan stood over her, gaze fixed on her curled form.

Two minutes passed before he spoke. "Take the bed. I'll sleep in the living room."

Only the hum of the air conditioner filled the silence.

"About the club... I'm sorry." Ethan drew a deep breath. "I apologize."

Jenna remained motionless, her back to him.

His fists clenched.

Did he really think a simple apology could make up for calling her the wrong name?

He turned and left, shutting the door quietly behind him.

Jenna opened her eyes, staring at the dark wall.

Selective amnesia?

He'd been perfectly lucid at the time. Now he played dumb.

She rolled over as her phone screen lit up.

Grandma Blanche's caller ID flashed.

"Grandma." Jenna answered.

"Jenna dear, are you asleep?" Concern laced the older woman's voice.

"About to." Jenna kept her voice soft.

"Did you mention what we discussed earlier to Ethan?"

Jenna studied the shadows on the ceiling.

"Forgot. I'll tell him tomorrow."

"Is Ethan asleep?"

"Probably." Jenna hedged.

"Aren't you sharing a bed?" Grandma Blanche sounded suspicious.

Jenna bit her lip.

"He's facing away. Let me check."

She pretended to look, pausing before saying, "He's asleep."

"Well then—"

The bedroom door swung open, cutting her off.

"Jenna, did you wash my towel?" Ethan's voice carried clearly.

Jenna froze.

"Ethan's still awake?" Grandma Blanche pounced.

Jenna massaged her temples.

The woman had bat-like hearing.

"Sorry Grandma, he's actually not asleep."

"Perfect timing. Ask him now." Grandma Blanche urged. "Your uncle Victor's whole family is waiting for an answer."
###Chapter 353

Jenna Roland was fuming, in no mood to deal with Ethan Roscente.

Grandma Blanche's call had put her in an impossible position.

Refusing the old lady's request would only raise suspicions.

She took a deep breath and reluctantly agreed, "Understood, Grandma. I'll call you back tomorrow."

After hanging up, she marched over to Ethan with a frosty expression. "Your grandmother wants you to arrange a job for your uncle's son."

Without another word, she turned on her heel, determined to avoid any mention of the towel incident.

Ethan frowned. "Did you wash the towel?"

"Still wet." Jenna kept her back to him, willing him to leave.

Instead, he flicked on the light and dragged a chair beside her floor bedding.

"Do you know what time it is?" Jenna sat up angrily.

Ethan met her gaze directly. "What exactly happened at Studio 54 that night?"

"Stop pretending to have amnesia." Jenna scoffed. "You know damn well what you did."

"I was too drunk to remember."

"Being drunk doesn't excuse anything." Her voice turned sharp.

Ethan remained calm. "I don't want misunderstandings between us."

Jenna arched an eyebrow. "So you're not leaving until I talk?"

"Correct." His tone brooked no argument.

"Ethan," Jenna sneered, "we both know why we got married. Stop acting like you care."

His fists clenched briefly before relaxing.

"You promised not to mention divorce," he said darkly.

Jenna faltered. "I did say that."

"Then we're still husband and wife." Ethan softened his tone. "We should communicate."

She bit her lower lip before finally asking, "Who is Yvonne Sherwood?"
###Chapter 354

Ethan's pupils constricted sharply.

He had imagined countless questions Jenna might throw at him, but never anticipated she'd bring up that long-buried name.

"I said it at the club?" His voice tightened.

Jenna pressed her lips together and nodded, hurt flashing in her eyes.

At the moment their lips were about to meet, he'd called out someone else's name. The realization made her chest constrict.

"Yvonne was my college girlfriend." Ethan's Adam's apple bobbed. "We broke up five years ago. She lives abroad now. We've had no contact since."

He paused. "After we got married, I didn't even think about her."

Jenna turned her face away, nails digging unconsciously into her palms.

"Forgotten when sober, remembered when drunk." Her voice trembled. "If you can't let go, why did you involve me?"

Ethan suddenly seized her wrist.

"I was drunk that night." His knuckles whitened. "I apologize. Can we forget this happened?"

Jenna wrenched free and walked to the window, taking deep breaths.

The glass reflected her red-rimmed eyes.

"Let's divorce." She turned back with forced calm. "Go find her. Don't waste each other's time."

"Never!"

His raised voice startled her.

Ethan's eyes were bloodshot, jaw clenched tight, veins bulging on his hands.

"Five years is enough to forget anyone." Each word sounded ground between teeth. "That night was a moment of weakness, but I swear she means nothing to me now!"

Jenna froze at his intensity.

Suddenly Ethan dropped to one knee, grasping her cold hands.

"At first I resented this marriage." He gazed up, dark eyes turbulent. "But you changed that."

His thumb gently stroked her knuckles.

"You're ridiculously kind, stubbornly endearing." His voice softened. "Even the way you pout when upset makes me unable to look away."

Jenna's heart skipped.

"Don't leave." He pressed her palm against his chest. "There's only you here now."

Beneath her fingers, his heartbeat raced wildly.

Jenna yanked her hand back, ears burning. She'd thought this marriage was purely transactional—never expecting a confession.

Worse, her own pounding heart betrayed her true feelings.

"I—I need water."

As she fled, she missed the dark glint in Ethan's eyes.
###Chapter 355

Ethan's fingers lightly covered Jenna's hand as he noticed her hesitation.

His gaze burned with intensity. His voice was deep and firm. "Give me a chance. If I ever disappoint you, you can leave anytime."

Jenna's lashes fluttered. Memories of the past few months flashed through her mind.

He had brought her warm midnight snacks during overtime work. He had stayed by her side when she caught a cold. He remembered every little habit of hers.

Compared to starting over with a stranger, this man who knew her so well seemed far more trustworthy.

"Okay," she finally nodded, then raised a warning finger. "But if you dare lie to me—"

Ethan's eyes lit up with joy before she could finish. He leaned in eagerly. "You're saying yes?"

"We already signed the marriage certificate. Why ask now?" Jenna turned her face away, the tips of her ears turning pink.

"Of course it matters." Ethan suddenly lowered his voice, his warm breath brushing her ear. "This way, I can rightfully—"

The room plunged into darkness before he could finish.

Before Jenna could react, she felt herself being lifted into the air.

"Ethan!" She gasped, pounding his shoulders. "Put me down!"

Effortlessly, he placed her on the bed, caging her beneath his arms. Amusement laced his voice. "It's not our first time sharing a bed. Why so nervous?"

"You've been drinking!" Jenna pushed against him. "I'm sleeping on the couch!"

Ethan suddenly released her and walked toward the closet.

Just as Jenna thought she'd escaped, he scooped her up again.

"If you don't want the bed," he strode toward the prepared floor bedding, "then we'll sleep here together."

Jenna glared at him, indignant. "I meant I don't want to sleep with you!"

Ethan had already settled down, pulling her firmly into his embrace.

"Don't move," he murmured, resting his chin atop her head. "I promise I'll just sleep."

Jenna tensed to struggle, but then heard his muffled voice. "I'm really exhausted today."

Her heart softened inexplicably, and she stilled.

"No crossing the line," she warned gruffly, yet subtly nestled closer.

In the darkness, Ethan's lips curled in triumph.

He had planned an elaborate confession, but the unexpected had forced his hand. Though rushed, holding her like this was more than enough.
###Chapter 356

Morning sunlight filtered through the curtains as Jenna Roland blinked awake.

The space beside her was empty.

She grabbed her phone. The 8:30 alarm had long since passed.

"Oh no!" She bolted upright, scanning the room for Ethan Roscente.

After locking the door and dressing quickly, she pushed open the bedroom door. A strange scent hit her nostrils.

Following the smell to the kitchen, she froze.

Ethan stood at the stove wearing an apron.

"You're... cooking noodles?" She rubbed her eyes in disbelief.

"Almost done," he replied without turning. "Go wash up."

Jenna lingered, watching his clumsy movements. She knew he despised noodle dishes.

While brushing her teeth, she puzzled over it—until she saw the steaming bowl of plain noodle soup on the table.

"When did you learn this?" She sniffed suspiciously.

Ethan handed her chopsticks, his gaze unusually soft. "Followed a tutorial. Try it."

She took a tentative bite and nearly spat it out. The broth tasted like pure salt.

"Well?" Ethan watched expectantly.

Jenna forced a swallow. "It's... okay."

He snatched the chopsticks and tasted it himself, immediately grimacing. "Don't eat this. It's inedible."

His first cooking attempt ended in failure.
###Chapter 357

Morning sunlight filtered through the curtains.

Jenna Roland stared at the steaming bowl of noodles before her. She hesitated before taking a bite. The overwhelming saltiness exploded on her tongue, but she forced herself not to grimace.

"How is it?" Ethan Roscente watched her expectantly.

"Not bad." Jenna managed a tight smile before gulping down water.

Ethan tasted it himself and immediately frowned. "It's inedible."

He set down his chopsticks, voice low. "Let's go out for breakfast."

Seeing his dejected expression, Jenna softened. "No need. I'll cook."

In the kitchen, Jenna boiled water with practiced ease. Ethan lingered in the doorway, watching her move.

Last night's confession still echoed between them. He'd wanted to express his feelings through this meal, but failed spectacularly.

"I'll do the dishes." Ethan took the empty bowl, his fingers accidentally brushing against Jenna's. They both flinched away.

The new batch of noodles smelled heavenly. Jenna had added homemade chili paste, crimson oil swirling on the surface.

The phone rang abruptly.

"Grandma." Jenna answered.

"Jenna, what did Ethan say about that matter?" Grandma Blanche's voice crackled through the receiver.

Jenna glanced at Ethan. "He hasn't given an answer yet."

"Ask him now!" Grandma Blanche insisted.

Jenna set down her chopsticks. "Ethan, about finding your cousin a job..."

Ethan's eyes turned glacial. "He's an ex-con. You know that, right?"

"Grandma says he's reformed."

"He raped and murdered a woman." Ethan enunciated each word. "Do you really think he belongs in my company?"

Jenna gasped. "It was that serious?"

Grandma Blanche's cough sounded through the phone. Jenna suddenly remembered the ongoing call and forced an awkward laugh.

"Give him the phone." Grandma Blanche commanded.

Ethan took it, his expression darkening. "No."

"He's paid his debt to society!" Grandma Blanche raised her voice. "Can't you do this for your grandmother?"

"If your family hadn't bribed officials, he'd be executed by now." Ethan's laugh was icy.

Silence stretched for several seconds.

"Ethan, he's still your blood relative. Just give him any position, even as charity..."

Ethan ended the call.
###Chapter 358

Ethan ended the call abruptly and tossed the phone back to Jenna.

"Next time Grandma Blanche calls you, just hang up."

Jenna caught the phone and nodded silently.

After finishing their noodles, Ethan cleared the dishes. Once done, he grabbed several bags of clothes and headed downstairs.

The hallway was eerily quiet this time—no sign of Wyatt and his crew.

Jenna swung her leg over the e-tricycle and tilted her chin at him. "Need a ride to work?"

Ethan eyed the rickety vehicle, imagining his employees spotting him on it. He shook his head decisively.

"No thanks. Be careful on the road."

Jenna didn’t press further. She twisted the throttle and sped off toward Mall of America.

She had just set up her stall when her phone buzzed. A message from Milo said he’d be staying at the hospital to look after Ryan Watson.

Jenna replied understandingly: "Take care of yourself. Don’t forget to eat."

The moment she hit send, Stella’s call came through.

"Aren’t you supposed to be napping right now?" Jenna asked, surprised.

"Can’t sleep because of my sister," Stella rasped. "By the way, why were you at Studio 54 last night?"

"It’s a long story." Jenna deflected. "What happened to Sylvia?"

"She’s missing." Stella’s voice trembled. "Her phone’s dead. The police won’t help. It’s been days."

Jenna’s fingers jerked, nearly dropping her phone. "How?"

"It’s Lucien Valois—I know it!" Stella hissed. "But last night he promised to help find her..."

A cold weight settled in Jenna’s chest. If even the police couldn’t locate Sylvia, the odds were grim.

"Did you check with her friends?"

"Every single one." Stella suddenly broke into sobs. "Jenna… she’s all I have left."

Muffled crying filled the line. Jenna gripped her phone, at a loss for words.
###Chapter 359

"Could Lucien Valois' wife have discovered your sister's affair with him and had her kidnapped?"

"I'm not sure... But his wife is ruthless. If she found out, she'd never let my sister go!"

"Then Lucien needs to confront his wife."

"What if she denies it?"

"With solid evidence, she won't have a choice. Let me help you investigate."

"Jenna... I need to ask you for a favor."

"What is it?"

"I barely know Lucien. He wouldn't question his wife for me. But he has feelings for you... Could you talk to him?"

Jenna's grip on her phone tightened.

Lucien did desire her, but Stella had warned her to stay away from that dangerous man.

Now she was supposed to walk right into his arms?

She'd barely escaped that night. Who knew what would happen if she saw him again?

That madman was capable of anything.

"Jenna... You don't want to help me, do you?" Stella's voice trembled with disappointment. "It's okay. I'll wait for the police."

"Let me make some inquiries first. If we still can't find her, I'll go to Lucien. Deal?"

"Okay. Don't force yourself. I know this is too much to ask..."

Stella choked back a sob.

She understood Lucien's danger better than anyone. She'd never risk Jenna's safety unless desperate.

"Don't say that. Your sister protected me at the club. If she hadn't stalled him, Lucien would've..."

Jenna shuddered at the memory.

"Call me immediately if you hear anything."

After hanging up, Jenna took a deep breath and dialed Ethan.

"Ethan, I need your help. It's urgent."

"Speak."

"My friend's sister is missing. The police have no leads. She used to be Lucien Valois' mistress. I suspect—"

"How is this your concern?"

Ethan's voice turned icy.

"She's my closest friend. At the club, her sister bought me time to escape..."

Jenna's voice shook. "She took a beating from Lucien to save me. Now she's vanished. I can't abandon her."

"Name."

"Sylvia Savigny."

Silence stretched for several seconds.

"I'll have someone look into it."

Ethan pressed the intercom. His assistant Lucas hurried in.

"Find a woman named Sylvia Savigny. Former mistress of Lucien Valois."

"Right away, Mr. Roscente."

As Lucas turned to leave, he caught Ethan's stormy expression and quickened his pace.
###Chapter 360

The moment Lucas left the office, Ethan's phone screen lit up.

He glanced at the caller ID—Grandpa Harrison's private number.

"Grandpa." Ethan answered the call.

A hoarse voice came through the line. "Ethan, your grandmother says you refused to give Shawn a position?"

Ethan pulled a cigarette from the pack and lit it, taking a deep drag. "You know what kind of man he is."

Shawn had been convicted of rape and murder.

His cousin was a notorious womanizer, preying on innocent women like a dog in heat.

Ethan would never allow such scum in his company.

"Your uncle can't control him." Grandpa Harrison sighed. "Only you can keep him in line."

It was true. Shawn dared to raise a hand against his own father, but he never crossed Ethan.

"He's still a Roscente." The old man's voice grew solemn. "Will you just stand by and watch him get the death penalty?"

Ethan exhaled a slow stream of smoke.

His grandfather rarely intervened like this.

"Fine." Ethan stubbed out the cigarette. "But if he lays a finger on any female employee, I won't hold back."

"Do as you see fit!"

After hanging up, Ethan pressed the intercom. "Assign Shawn to security."

"Understood." Lucas nodded and left.

......

At seven in the evening, Jenna packed up her stall and rode her e-tricycle back to the apartment complex.

Two familiar figures stood at the entrance.

"What a coincidence." Jenna hopped off the bike.

Wyatt stepped forward. "Finished for the day, Ms. Roland?"

"Business was good." She pointed to the cargo box. "Only three bags left."

Xavier crushed his cigarette underfoot. "Let us help you carry them."

Before Jenna could decline, they had already unloaded the goods with practiced efficiency.

"Last time it was four bags?" Wyatt hefted one.

Jenna's eyes curved into crescents. "Sold one today."
###Chapter 361

"Business is good today!" Wyatt Roland smiled as he eyed the merchandise on the e-tricycle. "Xavier and I can help carry these upstairs for you."

"Thanks!" Jenna Roland replied cheerfully, hopping onto the vehicle to park it.

When she returned, the two men had already disappeared from the apartment entrance.

The elevator doors opened to reveal three neatly stacked packages waiting outside her door. Jenna exhaled in relief, amused by her own paranoia.

After storing the clothes inside, she dialed Ethan Roscente. "Just got home. Are you coming back for dinner?"

Receiving a negative answer, she moved to the kitchen to prepare noodles.

The clink of cutlery had just ceased when the front door lock turned. Ethan entered holding a bouquet of sunflowers, their golden petals still glistening with water droplets.

"Sunflowers again?" Jenna arched an eyebrow.

"They looked fresh at the florist," he replied, reaching for a vase. "I'll change the water."

She leaned against the kitchen doorway as he deftly trimmed the stems. "Any luck finding Sylvia?"

"Not yet." His fingers never paused. "Don't get your hopes up."

After arranging the flowers, Ethan headed straight for the bedroom. Jenna followed after cleaning up, only to find him unbuttoning his dress shirt.

"Ah!" She spun around, hands covering her eyes. "What are you doing undressing suddenly?"

"Changing clothes." Amusement colored his voice. "What else?"

"Can't you use the bathroom?" Her ears burned crimson.

Warmth pressed against her back. Ethan had closed the distance without sound, his hands settling on her shoulders.

"Help! Pervert!" Jenna shrieked, attempting to flee, but his arms caged her effortlessly.

"Who's the pervert?" His tone turned dangerous.

"The one stripping naked!" She kept her eyes squeezed shut.

Her palm was suddenly guided against firm, heated skin. Ethan chuckled darkly. "Want to feel?"

Fingertips encountered defined ridges. Jenna peeked through one eyelid.

Pale skin stretched over eight sculpted abdominal muscles, his chest carved with perfect definition. Her hands flew to her mouth. "You actually have muscles?"

The biceps flexing as he moved explained how he'd carried her heavy packages with ease. Against her will, Jenna's gaze lingered for another appreciative sweep.
###Chapter 362

"Of course." Ethan's lips curved slightly, his gaze burning into her. "Satisfied?"

"It's...acceptable." Jenna hastily withdrew her hand, her cheeks hot enough to fry an egg.

"As long as you like it."

"......"

Her ears turned crimson.

Ethan chuckled lowly. "Shy now?"

Jenna shot him a glare and turned to flee.

This time, he didn't stop her.

Casually grabbing his shirt, he strode bare-chested toward the bathroom.

Collapsing on the couch, Jenna only exhaled when she heard the shower running.

The old Ethan would never have been this shameless. Why was he suddenly showing off his muscles today?

Unless...

He planned to share the bed tonight?

What if he tried something?

She'd never even held a man's hand before.

What would...that even feel like?

Jenna buried her burning face in her hands.

No! If Ethan really wanted to do something, she couldn't just play dumb.

Her phone vibrated.

Stella had sent a string of exclamation marks.

"You've been married this long and still haven't slept together?!"

"Separate rooms." Jenna bit her lip as she typed. "But tonight he might..."

"Wow~" came Stella's instant reply. "I've got tutorial videos."

Jenna nearly dropped her phone.

"You're insane!"

"Stop pretending to be innocent." Stella sent a link. "Study up to take control."

The shower stopped.

Like a thief, Jenna slipped onto the balcony, finger trembling over the link.

If Ethan caught her...
###Chapter 363

Jenna Roland was completely absorbed in her phone screen, oblivious to Ethan Roscente's presence outside the floor-to-ceiling window.

Ethan arched an eyebrow as he observed Jenna hiding in the corner of the balcony, surprise flickering in his eyes.

He hadn't expected to stumble upon this scene.

His slender fingers tapped lightly on the glass twice.

Jenna jerked her head up, meeting Ethan's amused gaze. Her face instantly flushed crimson. Fumbling, she locked her phone with trembling fingers.

"When...when did you get here?" Her voice was tight, her heart pounding so violently it threatened to leap from her chest.

Ethan pushed open the door and pulled her into the living room. He braced one hand against the glass beside her ear, trapping her in the small space.

Jenna's face burned even hotter, the tips of her ears turning pink.

"Let me go," she protested weakly, her eyes darting everywhere but at him.

Ethan chuckled lowly. "So this is what you like watching?"

"No!" Jenna shook her head frantically. "Stella sent it! I didn't even want to look!"

"Since when do you hide to chat with friends?" His lips curved meaningfully. "It's okay to admit it."

Jenna wished the ground would swallow her whole. She'd specifically waited until Ethan was showering to sneak onto the balcony—how had he still caught her?

This was beyond embarrassing.

Ethan released his hold, only to slide an arm around her shoulders and steer her inside. "Good things should be shared."

Jenna froze, her entire face scorching.

"I deleted it!" She glared at him indignantly. "If you want to see it, find it yourself."

Ethan pretended to reach for her phone. "Really deleted?"

Jenna tried to bolt, but Ethan yanked her back against his chest. She bit her lower lip in frustration—if she'd known this would happen, she never would've clicked that link.

This was all Stella's fault!

Ethan tilted her chin up, mischief dancing in his eyes. "Two choices: either we watch it together now, or...I'll test your learning progress tonight."

"What?" Jenna's eyes widened.

Ethan dropped a kiss on her forehead and turned toward the bedroom. "Prepare well."

Jenna stood rooted to the spot, stomping her foot in anger.

That bastard!

Fuming, she deleted the URL from her phone and decided she'd be sleeping on the couch tonight.
###Chapter 364

Jenna Roland watched the darkening sky outside her window, absently swiping her phone screen. A brilliant idea suddenly struck her.

"Hey, Milo?" She dialed her younger brother's number. "Are you coming home tonight?"

When Milo said he was staying at a friend's place, Jenna's eyes lit up. She sprang from the couch and dashed into his room in three quick strides.

The lock clicked shut behind her. Jenna exhaled in relief. Finally, she could escape that infuriating man.

She flopped onto the bed and opened her video app. A sharp knock interrupted her.

"Open the door." Ethan Roscente's deep voice penetrated the wood.

Jenna bolted upright. "What do you want?" She glared at the door.

"You think hiding here will stop me?" Amusement laced his tone. "Either open it yourself, or I'll use my key."

Jenna smacked her forehead. She'd forgotten Ethan had a spare key!

"Damn it!" She yanked the door open, teeth clenched.

Ethan hooked an arm around her shoulders and hauled her toward the master bedroom without explanation. The lock clicked again.

Jenna pressed her back against the curtains, eyes narrowed. "What are you planning?"

Ethan flexed his wrists, smirking. "Nothing illegal between husband and wife."

"Bullshit!" Her fingers twisted into the fabric. "No consent means rape!"

A vein pulsed at Ethan's temple. "You agreed to be with me last night."

"That doesn't mean sex tonight!" She jutted her chin. "I need time to warm up!"

He massaged his temples. The woman's imagination ran wild—he hadn't even considered that.

Stretching across the bed, he crooked a finger. "Come rub my shoulders."

"No!" Jenna burrowed deeper into the curtains.

Ethan's eyes slitted. "Do it, or I'll claim my husbandly rights tonight."

Jenna gasped. When had he become so shameless?

She inched toward the bed with obvious reluctance. "My own shoulders ache..."

"I'm your husband." He closed his eyes, savoring her touch. "I'll return the favor later."

"Like hell!" She scoffed. "You'll just cop a feel."

Ethan's eyes flew open. "Afraid I'll touch you?"

Jenna choked on her own saliva, face burning crimson.
###Chapter 365

Ethan propped himself up on one elbow, brows furrowing slightly. "What's wrong?"

Jenna stood barefoot on the floor, bent over as violent coughs wracked her body, turning her face crimson.

Her throat burned with raw pain.

She hurried to the living room and gulped down a glass of lukewarm water before finding relief.

When she returned to the bedroom, Ethan was already sitting up. She grabbed her sleepwear. "I'll shower first."

"Mhm."

After her shower, she found Ethan spreading out bedding on the floor.

Jenna couldn't suppress a laugh.

He turned to look at her.

"Addicted to sleeping on the floor now?" She walked over to him.

"Wasn't it you who refused the bed?" He continued smoothing the sheets. "I'm keeping you company."

"Then enjoy the floor." Jenna arched a brow. "Tonight, I'm taking the bed."

Who in their right mind would choose hard flooring over a plush mattress?

Ethan paused mid-motion. "No more floor sleeping?"

Jenna sat at the vanity and began her skincare routine. "I'm not an idiot."

Silently, Ethan gathered the bedding and stuffed it into the closet.

"Guess we won't need this anymore," he murmured.

Jenna pressed her lips together, amused.

After finishing her routine, she slipped under the covers.

When Ethan returned from washing up, his arm naturally draped over her shoulders. "This okay?"

"Mhm." Blushing, she turned toward him.

As the lights went out, he pulled her closer. "Do you dislike it when I touch you?"

Moonlight filtered through the curtains as Jenna answered, "I'm slow to warm up. Too much too soon makes me nervous—afraid you'll leave once you get what you want."

Ethan's arm stiffened.

"I won't let go." His voice was low and firm. "Jenna, I know you don't believe me, but when Ethan Roscente gives his word, he keeps it."

"Time will tell." She closed her eyes. "Goodnight."

"Goodnight."

Ethan understood her wariness. He'd prove through actions that he wasn't like Lucien Valois.

......

Jenna awoke at dawn's first light.

Beside her, Ethan breathed steadily in sleep. She carefully lifted his arm away.

Turning off the AC, she tucked the blanket snugly around him.

Assured he still slept, she crept from the bedroom on silent feet.

After freshening up, she tied on an apron and began breakfast preparations.

Remembering how long it'd been since she cooked for Ethan, she prepared extra dishes.

By the time morning rays brightened the sheer curtains, four stir-fried dishes adorned the table. Steam rose from bamboo baskets of flower buns and stuffed buns.

Wiping her hands, Jenna went to wake Ethan.
###Chapter 366

Morning sunlight streamed through the gap in the curtains. Ethan Roscente stood before the bathroom mirror, brushing his teeth.

A gentle knock sounded at the door. "Breakfast is ready," Jenna Roland's soft voice called.

The water stopped running. Ethan responded with a quiet acknowledgment. Jenna turned and walked toward the dining area, pouring steaming soy milk into a cup.

Ethan soon appeared in the doorway. His gaze softened at the sight of four delicate side dishes and a bamboo steamer releasing wisps of heat on the table.

He approached Jenna and pressed a light kiss to her cheek.

"What time did you wake up?" Ethan pulled out a chair, his eyes never leaving her face.

Jenna handed him chopsticks. "Five. I thought you've been too busy lately—takeout isn't good for you."

Ethan picked up a translucent shrimp dumpling. "Thank you."

Jenna bit her lower lip. "I haven't been taking proper care of you these days..."

Ethan ruffled her hair. "Don't say that." His thumb brushed the corner of her eye. "Let's eat."

They enjoyed breakfast in comfortable silence. Jenna suddenly asked, "Would you like braised pork ribs or sweet and sour fish tomorrow?"

"Anything you make is good." Ethan stood to clear the dishes with efficient movements.

Water rushed in the kitchen sink. Jenna stood beside Ethan drying plates, their arms occasionally brushing.

"I'll go change." Jenna wiped her hands and hurried upstairs.

Ethan carried several packed bags of clothes downstairs. Wyatt Roland waited below, hesitating as he accepted the bundles.

"No need to follow today," Ethan said briefly before returning upstairs for the remaining items.

When he came back down, Jenna was already waiting at the gate on her e-tricycle. She wore a light blue shirt, her hair fluttering in the morning breeze.

Ethan loaded the last two bags and swung into the passenger seat.

Jenna turned in surprise. "You're not going to work today?"

"It's the weekend." He fastened his seatbelt, his gaze lingering on her hands gripping the steering wheel.

Jenna blinked. She remembered how Ethan used to spend weekends buried in his office.

The e-tricycle merged onto Sunset Boulevard. At a red light, Jenna checked her phone messages.

A black Audi Q7 pulled up beside them. The window rolled down, revealing Julian Cardenas' shocked expression.

"Mr. Roscente?" His voice trembled with disbelief.

Ethan turned. His eyes instantly turned frosty.

The light changed. Jenna smoothly accelerated. Julian remained frozen until impatient car horns startled him back to reality.

He slammed the gas pedal, his eyes locked on the e-tricycle carrying the CEO of HM Group.
###Chapter 367

Julian Cardenas's gaze locked onto the familiar figure on the sidewalk outside Mall of America.

The black Maybach pulled over slowly. The window rolled down as Julian narrowed his eyes.

Ethan Roscente was bending over to help a girl arrange clothes on a street vendor's rack, his movements practiced like a seasoned pro.

Julian rubbed his eyes to make sure he wasn't hallucinating.

The CEO of HM Group—a titan of the business world—was running a street stall?

What shocked him even more was the way Ethan looked at the girl.

Uncharacteristically tender.

Julian pulled out his phone and dialed Ethan's number.

When the call connected, he saw Ethan frown and retrieve his phone.

"Speak." Ethan's voice was icy.

"Mr. Roscente... why are you selling clothes on the street?" Julian asked cautiously.

"Buying." The reply was curt.

Julian nearly choked on his own saliva.

"But sir—"

"Hurry up."

The call ended abruptly.

Julian took a deep breath and stepped out of the car toward the stall.

He picked up a pink T-shirt at random. "How much for this?"

The girl turned around, and Julian finally got a clear look at her.

Delicate features. Bright eyes. A smile like a fresh daisy.

No wonder the CEO had broken precedent to help.

"Sixty-five. Opening price for you." Her voice was crisp.

Julian grabbed three more items.

"That'll be two-sixty." As the girl started calculating, Ethan suddenly spoke. "Good quality. Shouldn't you buy more?"

Julian's eye twitched.

He was forced to take three additional pieces.

"Get two skirts too." Ethan crossed his arms.

Julian almost turned to stone on the spot.

A bachelor buying this many women's clothes?

But under Ethan's unyielding stare, he could only grit his teeth and nod.
###Chapter 368

Jenna Roland picked two dresses from the rack—one pure white as snow, the other soft pink like cherry blossoms.

"These would suit your girlfriend perfectly," she said, handing them to Julian Cardenas.

Ethan Roscente spotted some short skirts hanging nearby. He casually yanked two off the rack and tossed them in front of Julian. "These match your girlfriend's vibe better."

Julian's face darkened instantly. It was clear now—Ethan wasn't just trying to rip him off, but also mocking him!

Jenna quickly grabbed Ethan's sleeve. "He's a customer. Be polite."

"Hmm?" Ethan raised an eyebrow.

"Customer comes first," Jenna whispered. "Throwing clothes like that is rude."

The fact that Julian had followed them here without causing a scene was already the height of courtesy!

"Oh." Ethan responded indifferently.

Julian cleared his throat awkwardly and handed the clothes to Jenna. "Just wrap them all up."

"Great!" Jenna's eyes lit up. "Would you like to check out our new lace lingerie? Your girlfriend will love it."

Julian's lips twitched. What girlfriend?

If Ethan hadn't threatened him, he wouldn't even glance at this cheap merchandise!

He glared at Ethan, then forced a fake smile at Jenna. "Sure."

He'd only meant to track Ethan's movements—never expected to get fleeced instead!

Ethan took the clothes. "I'll handle checkout. You go organize the racks."

Jenna hesitated, glancing at Julian before turning to hang up clothes.

"Shorts—ninety-nine. Skirt—one-thirty. T-shirt—one-sixty..." Ethan drawled the prices.

Julian's eyes widened. The girl had just said the T-shirt was only sixty-five!

Jenna spun around and hissed in Ethan's ear. "Are you insane? Doubling the prices will scare him off!"

"Audi-driving cash cow," Ethan smirked. "Relax. He won't run."

"Total's thirteen hundred," Ethan pushed the bag toward Julian. "Cash or scan?"

Julian nearly choked. Items worth five or six hundred had more than doubled!

"Scan!" He gritted his teeth and pulled out his phone. From now on, he'd cross the street to avoid Ethan!

Ethan waved the payment QR code.

Julian paid and turned to leave.

"Your clothes," Ethan reminded.

Julian stormed back, snatched the bag, and vanished into the crowd without a backward glance.

Jenna looked worried. "He'll never come back."

Ethan slung an arm around her shoulders. "Regular customers wouldn't spend this much in a lifetime."

"But—"

"Rich people's money? Easy come, easy go." He pinched her cheek playfully. "Come on, back to work."
###Chapter 369

Jenna Roland's stall was swarmed with customers. Ethan Roscente stood there like a living advertisement.

Women lined up to buy clothes, but their eyes remained glued to Ethan.

Cash fluttered into the money box like snowflakes.

Three stalls away, Lily Evans gripped her clothing rack tightly. Her nails dug into her palms as she glared at Jenna's back.

Ever since Jenna arrived on this street, Lily's business had collapsed. The prime spot at the intersection now belonged to that little vixen. Worst of all, that man's presence had lured away her last few customers.

"Homewrecker!" Lily spat viciously.

Tanya Hill had noticed Lily's venomous stare. During a lull, she tugged Jenna's sleeve.

"Be careful, dear," Tanya whispered. "That dress seller looks ready to murder you."

Jenna glanced at Lily and shrugged. "Let her stare."

"You stubborn girl!" Tanya clapped her thighs in frustration. "Jealousy drives people mad!"

Jenna flashed her a sweet smile before bouncing over to Ethan. "What do you want for lunch? My treat!"

Sunlight filtered through the trees, casting golden flecks on Ethan's lashes as his eyes crinkled with amusement.

"Whatever you make," he said tenderly. "Street food isn't hygienic."

Jenna checked her phone. "Should I go buy groceries now?"

"Mhm." Ethan stood to help pack up the stall. "I'll watch things here."

As the e-tricycle puttered away, Tanya teased, "Little Jenna can cook?"

Ethan's lips curved unconsciously. "She's full of surprises."

Remembering his initial misconceptions about Jenna, he now found them laughable. The image of her bustling in the kitchen, ponytail swaying, had gradually etched itself into his heart.

Grandma Blanche was right—this girl was an uncut gem.
###Chapter 370

Tanya Hill watched Ethan Roscente effortlessly greet customers, his slender fingers dancing across the calculator keys. Sunlight illuminated his chiseled profile, and even the slight furrow of his brow as he tallied numbers exuded an air of elite sophistication.

She sighed. Her own son could never measure up to a man like this.

......

Aromatic scents wafted from the kitchen. Jenna Roland swiftly packed braised pork ribs into an insulated container and ladled steaming clam soup with winter melon. The wall clock showed 1:20 PM.

Grabbing the lunchbox, she dashed outside.

Her e-bike screeched to a halt outside Mall of America. Jenna weaved through the crowd, the thermos swaying in her grip. "Ethan!" She skidded to a breathless stop at his stall. "Eat first."

His fingers brushed hers as he took the container. "You haven't eaten either?"

"Waiting for you." Jenna turned toward the neighboring stall. "Aunt Tanya, mind if we borrow your table?"

The moment the folding table clicked open, the sweet-sour aroma of sweet and sour pork filled the air. Nearby vendors instinctively sniffed.

Tanya approached as the sizzling beef with peppers glistened with oil. "You've got real talent, Jenna," she marveled, eyeing the glistening steamed egg with shrimp.

"I'll make extra tomorrow. Want to join us?" Jenna offered chopsticks.

Tanya stole a glance at Ethan's expression. The man was intently ladling soup for Jenna without even looking up.

"He doesn't mind these things." Jenna placed a rib in Ethan's bowl.

After the crowd dispersed, Jenna suddenly gasped. "Tomorrow's Monday?" She noticed Ethan's hands pause while packing the containers. "Then... I'll wake up early to cook."

Two girls in JK uniforms stopped at the stall. Blushing, they stole glances at Ethan before purchasing three pairs of earrings.

Jenna chuckled while counting the bills. With this man around, their stall might as well have a human lucky cat statue.
###Chapter 371

10:00 AM sharp.

Jenna Roland had just finished packing up her street stall when her phone rang abruptly.

The name "Ethan Roscente" flashing on the screen made her eyebrows lift.

"Ethan?" She propped her chin on one hand, scanning the empty stall before her.

"We found her." His voice came through the receiver. "Under a bridge. Barely alive."

Her fingers twitched.

The words "barely alive" stabbed into her heart like a knife.

Almost too late.

"Who did this?" Her voice tightened.

"Yvonne Valois." A pause. "Lucien Valois's woman."

A chill crawled up Jenna's spine.

Broad daylight, and they dared to commit murder?

"Isn't she afraid of prison?" She clenched the phone.

"Mayor Valois is her shield." Ethan's冷笑 was icy. "That woman has powerful connections."

Cold sweat beaded on Jenna's forehead.

Thank God she'd listened to the Savigny sisters' warning.

"Sylvia needs to leave Los Angeles immediately." She lowered her voice.

"Agreed."

"Which hospital is your friend at? I want to thank them in person."

"Unnecessary." He rattled off the hospital address and hung up without ceremony.

Jenna immediately dialed Stella Laurent.

A sleepy mumble answered.

"We found your sister!" Jenna's voice was urgent. "At Los Angeles General Hospital!"

Stella's breathing hitched.

The call disconnected. Within seconds, Jenna heard frantic rustling—clothes being thrown on in panic.

One hour later.

Stella burst into the hospital room to find Sylvia Savigny asleep beneath an oxygen mask.

Her legs gave out. Only a hand clamped over her mouth stifled the scream.

Her sister's face was swollen beyond recognition.

Bandages wrapped her head. Bruises mottled her lips purple.

A cast suspended her left leg midair. An IV tube snaked into her right hand.

Tears splattered the linoleum.

The choked sobs woke the patient.

Sylvia pried open swollen eyelids with visible effort.
###Chapter 372

Sylvia's lashes fluttered at the sound of approaching footsteps. She didn't need to open her eyes to know who it was.

Stella stood by the hospital bed, silent tears streaming down her face. She bit her lip hard, afraid to disturb the fragile figure beneath the white sheets.

"Big sis..." Stella finally choked out, her voice breaking.

Sylvia turned her face away, brows furrowed. She couldn't bear for her sister to see her like this.

Stella grabbed her hand, hot tears splashing onto the sterile bedding. "Do you have any idea how terrified I was? If you'd died, I wouldn't want to live either!"

Sylvia's shoulders trembled slightly. Memories flooded back—the cruel words she'd hurled at her sister, the shameful entanglement with Lucien Valois for money.

How ironic. What right did she have to lecture anyone?

"Does it hurt?" Stella asked softly.

Sylvia shook her head. She looked too wretched to even speak. The oxygen mask fogged with each shallow breath.

"I'm sorry..." Sylvia's whisper was feather-light.

Stella wiped her tears. "Jenna helped so much. If she hadn't pulled strings to find you..."

"Jenna?" Sylvia's eyes flickered with recognition.

"Her friend has connections at the police station," Stella explained. "When you recover, we must thank her properly."

Sylvia closed her eyes. She remembered the biting cold under the bridge, the terrifying sensation of blood leaving her body. Jenna had given her a second chance at life.

A phone rang abruptly.

"How is she?" Jenna's voice came through the receiver.

Stella glanced at the bed. "Badly injured, but stable."

"Yvonne won't let this go," Jenna said gravely. "Once she's discharged, you both should leave town."

Hanging up, Stella squeezed her sister's hand. "Let's go back home, sis."

Sylvia stared at the ceiling. She knew there was no choice. For Stella's sake, she had to survive.
###Chapter 373

"Alright." Sylvia replied softly, forcing a faint smile. "When we return to our hometown, we'll build a new house. We'll raise some chickens and ducks, plant vegetables. Then I'll find you a good matchmaker."

"Let's talk about that later." Stella stood up. "You should rest now. I'll go ask the doctor about your condition."

Sylvia closed her eyes as Stella turned and left the hospital room.

The moment she stepped into the hallway, two men in black suits approached.

Stella paid them no mind and walked straight to the doctor's office.

Inside, several physicians were busy at work. A female doctor looked up. "Can I help you?"

"I'm Sylvia Savigny's family member."

The doctor set down the medical chart. "I'm her attending physician."

"Doctor, my sister's injuries..." Stella's voice tightened.

"Left leg fracture required surgery. Three broken ribs were stabilized. Mild concussion that needs monitoring. The external injuries aren't severe."

Stella's pupils constricted. Her fingers trembled uncontrollably.

"Will...will she need the metal plates removed later?"

"Of course." The doctor nodded. "At least two weeks hospitalization. No heavy labor after discharge."

"Thank you, Doctor." Stella bowed deeply.

The doctor waved a hand. "Just doing my job."

As Stella turned to leave, she froze in the doorway.

"Let go of my sister!" She grabbed a chair and swung it at the man choking Sylvia. "Help! Murder!"

The man backhanded her across the face. Stella's vision went dark.

She sank her teeth into the attacker's arm. His companion punched her squarely in the face.

Stella collapsed limply to the floor.

"You animals!" Sylvia's eyes bulged with rage. Every wound screamed in agony.

"Move!" The accomplice yanked the man's arm. "She shouted too loud—people are coming!"

The two fled in panic.

Footsteps pounded down the hallway. Sylvia mustered her last strength to scream: "Help..."
###Chapter 374

A searing pain shot through Sylvia Savigny's left leg as she tried to get out of bed. Cold sweat soaked through her hospital gown.

Hurried footsteps echoed in the hallway.

"Doctor!" Sylvia's voice trembled. "My sister was attacked. Please help her!"

Three white-coated physicians rushed in. Nurses restrained Sylvia as she struggled to rise. "Don't move! You'll reopen your wounds."

Clutching the sheets, Sylvia watched them examine Stella Laurent.

"Just temporary unconsciousness." The doctor removed his stethoscope. "No life-threatening injuries."

Stella's eyes flew open. She grabbed the doctor's sleeve. "Someone's trying to kill my sister! I need to call the police!"

The doctor frowned. "Who?"

"Yvonne Valois!" Blood trickled from Stella's split lip. "She must have sent them!"

Twenty minutes later, police sirens pierced the hospital corridor.

Whispers spread through the gathered crowd. Stella pointed at her swollen cheek. "Those men in black almost strangled my sister!"

Inspector Cole Macmillan flipped open his notepad. "Any personal enemies?"

"Lucien Valois's wife!" Stella rasped. "She kidnapped my sister, beat her half to death, and dumped her under an overpass!"

A murmur rippled through the ward.

The inspector's pen paused. "Evidence?"

"My sister is the witness!" Stella turned toward the bed.

Sylvia gave a weak nod. "They said I touched someone I shouldn't have..."

Another officer lowered his voice. "Lucien Valois is the mayor's son."

Inspector Macmillan snapped his notebook shut. "We'll need your formal statement."

"But who'll protect my sister if I leave?" Stella stamped her foot in frustration.

Suddenly she pulled out her phone. "Jenna, please come to the hospital now!"

At her clothing stall, Jenna Roland's hanger clattered to the ground. "Yvonne's trying to wipe them out!"

She swiftly packed up her merchandise. Her e-tricycle sped toward the hospital through the night.
###Chapter 375

Jenna Roland pushed open the hospital room door to find Sylvia Savigny alone inside.

Sylvia's eyes flew open, filled with terror. Only when she recognized the visitor did her tense shoulders relax.

"It's you." Sylvia exhaled sharply.

Jenna hurried to the bedside. "Did those men in black come back?"

Sylvia shook her head, fingers absently twisting the blanket edge. "I keep fearing they'll appear suddenly."

Jenna pulled up a chair, her gaze lingering on Sylvia's bandaged arms. "Can you tell me exactly what happened?"

Sylvia recounted the kidnapping ordeal in a trembling voice. By the end, her words had faded to a whisper.

"Yvonne Valois won't let me go." Sylvia gave a bitter smile. "Not even if I flee to the ends of the earth."

Jenna clenched her fists. "Just because she has power and influence?"

"We can't fight her." Sylvia's eyes dimmed. "I just want Stella to be safe."

Jenna suddenly stood. "I have a friend at the police station. Maybe he can help."

"It's useless." Sylvia shook her head. "Even Lucien Valois couldn't protect me, let alone..."

"Then we'll use public opinion!" Jenna's eyes lit up. "Expose her crimes online."

Sylvia froze. "That..."

"I'll make a call." Jenna strode toward the door. "Rest for now."

In the hallway, Jenna dialed Liam Hill's number. Before the call connected, she glanced back at the closed door.

Through the glass window, Sylvia lay staring blankly at the ceiling.
###Chapter 376

Jenna's fingers twisted the hem of her shirt when the call connected.

"Officer Hill, it's Jenna Roland." Her voice was deliberately hushed. "We met at the police station."

Liam's steady baritone came through the receiver. "I remember. What's wrong?"

She drew a sharp breath. "My friend used to be Lucien Valois's mistress. After Yvonne found out, she sent men to kidnap her. They nearly killed her."

Her nails dug into her palms as she stared at the sterile hospital walls.

"Now she's in the hospital, and someone tried to murder her again." Jenna's voice trembled. "The perpetrator has powerful connections. Are we really out of options?"

A faint clink of glass being set down sounded through the phone.

"Evidence?" Liam's tone turned grave. "Kidnapping, attempted murder—we need solid proof."

Jenna bit her lower lip. "Everyone knows it's Yvonne. Only hospital staff had this room number, yet the assassin found her instantly."

The rustle of flipping papers carried through the line.

"The law only cares about evidence." A lighter clicked as Liam lit a cigarette. "Audio recordings, video footage, eyewitnesses—we need it all."

"But she has the mayor backing her!" Jenna's voice cracked.

Smoke laced Liam's quiet chuckle. "The higher they climb, the harder they fall. Find me proof, and I'll handle this personally."

Jenna's head snapped up, fire igniting in her eyes.

"Deal." Each word was deliberate. "We'll get you the evidence."

After hanging up, she pushed open the hospital room door.

Sylvia sat motionless, staring at the IV drip.

"The police need proof." Jenna took her icy hand.

Sylvia gave a bitter smile. "We're prisoners in this room. Where would we even look?"

Jenna leaned close, whispering in her ear.

"What?" Sylvia's eyes widened. "That's too dangerous!"

"It's our only shot." Jenna's gaze burned with determination. "We have to force her to show her hand."

Sylvia watched the darkening sky outside the window before nodding slowly.

Two shadows melted into the blackness of the hospital corridor as night descended.
###Chapter 377

Sylvia Savigny stared at the ceiling, fingers tapping lightly on the bedsheet. Better to take action than wait helplessly. At least this way, there was a sliver of hope.

She nodded slowly, agreeing to Jenna Roland's plan.

"In my current condition, I'll have to wait until I'm discharged," Sylvia said, her voice weak but resolute.

The hospital door swung open as Stella Laurent hurried in, looking exhausted.

"Did they file the case?" Jenna asked urgently.

Stella sank into a chair. "The police said there's insufficient evidence. They'll only pursue the two men in black for now." She gave a bitter smile. "Masks and hats—like finding a needle in a haystack."

All three knew the case would go nowhere.

"I have a new plan," Jenna lowered her voice. "We'll execute it after your sister is discharged."

Stella frowned. "What plan?"

As Jenna explained, Stella paled. "It's too dangerous! What if—"

"That's why we need Officer Liam Hill as a witness," Jenna's eyes gleamed. "Video and photos—irrefutable evidence."

"But the Valois family's influence—"

"Prepare two copies," Jenna cut in. "If the police ignore it, we'll go public. Let public opinion crush her."

After a moment's thought, Stella finally nodded.

Jenna pulled two pepper sprays from her bag. "Take these for protection."

"Where did you get these?" Stella gasped, accepting one.

"Prepared them when I worked at the club," Jenna shrugged. "Essential for self-defense."

Stella tucked the other under her sister's pillow.

"I should go," Jenna checked her watch.

Stella walked her to the elevator and hugged her tightly. "Thank you."

"Don't mention it," Jenna patted her back.

As the elevator doors closed, Jenna exhaled deeply. She decided to take a break—the street vending had worn her out.

Just outside the hospital entrance, Jenna froze mid-step.

Lucien Valois was approaching, flanked by two bodyguards in black.

Her pulse spiked. If that madwoman knew Lucien's true intentions...

Lucien's gaze lingered on her face for a second before coolly shifting away. He passed by without expression, as if she were a stranger.

Jenna clenched her fists, nails digging into her palms.
###Chapter 378

Jenna Roland froze in place.

She stood right in front of Lucien Valois, yet he walked past her as if she were invisible.

After searching for her for so long, wouldn’t he even spare her a glance?

Her heart clenched as if gripped by an invisible hand.

Unable to resist, she turned back—only to meet Lucien’s deep, penetrating gaze. He had been watching her all along.

Flustered, Jenna quickly faced forward again, her nails digging into her palms.

Lucien stared at her retreating figure, a flicker of sorrow in his eyes. Without a word, he turned and entered the hospital doors.

Jenna mounted her e-bike and rode aimlessly for a while before remembering she needed groceries.

Back in the Beverly Hills kitchen, she chopped vegetables while calling Ethan Roscente.

"Will you be home for dinner?"

After his confirmation, she dialed Milo Roland.

"Sorry, sis. I’m taking care of Ryan Watson tonight."

Hanging up, Jenna surveyed the dusty living room and grabbed a rag to clean.
