The washing machine hummed as she stuffed in sheets and pillowcases.

By the time she finished chores, dusk had settled outside.

A hot shower washed away her exhaustion. Tying on an apron, she started dinner.

At 6:30 sharp, the lock clicked.

Ethan tiptoed into the bedroom, placing a bouquet of red roses on the nightstand.

"You're back?" Jenna emerged from the kitchen with dishes. "Wash up for dinner."

Four dishes and a soup steamed on the table—all Ethan’s favorites.

"Why only my preferred foods?" He frowned.

She handed him chopsticks with a smile. "Because you love them."

"You should think of yourself more." He placed a chicken wing in her bowl. "You’ve lost weight."

"Nonsense." But she obediently took a bite.

They exchanged servings across the table, the meal filled with warmth.

Midway, Jenna suddenly set down her utensils. "Ethan… do powerful people really face no consequences?"

He paused. "Ordinary people struggle against them."

"So we just endure injustice?" Her voice dropped to a whisper.
###Chapter 379

Ethan Roscente's slender fingers tapped the table, his gaze sharp as a blade. "Only the weak complain about fate. The strong rewrite the rules. The Yangs and the Lu family? Mere ants. If you're powerful enough, even the elite circles will bow before you."

Jenna Roland clenched the hem of her shirt, her knuckles turning white. "Easy for you to say. For ordinary people, climbing the social ladder is harder than reaching the heavens!"

"Old Man Savigny started with a street stall," Ethan sneered. "Now everyone calls him 'Sir Savigny.' Opportunity favors the prepared."

Jenna jerked her head up, defiance flashing in her eyes. "That's one in a million! If Sylvia hadn't met her benefactor, Yvonne would've destroyed her long ago!"

Their shadows stretched starkly under the light, two worlds colliding.

Ethan stood atop the clouds, born the heir of HM Group. Jenna fought through the mud, scraping together every penny for her brother's medical bills.

"You could've walked away," Ethan narrowed his eyes.

"That day at Studio 54..." Jenna's voice trembled. "When Lucien slapped Sylvia in public, I should've stepped in."

Her nails dug into her palms. "I'm the reason she lost her protector and became Yvonne's target."

Ethan suddenly closed the distance between them, his breath hot. "What if Yvonne turns on you next?"

"Bring it on!" Jenna grabbed a fruit knife and slammed it into the table. "I'll trade my life for hers!"

The blade vibrated with a metallic hum.

Ethan studied her flushed face and suddenly chuckled. "What a stubborn one." He flicked the knife handle. "Who'll take care of your brother if you die?"

"The surgery was successful." Jenna lifted her chin. "He'll—"

"Eat." Ethan shoved a shrimp dumpling into her mouth. "It's getting cold."

An eerie silence fell over the dining table.

While washing dishes, Jenna kicked the sink. "The drain's clogged."

Ethan rolled up his tailored shirt sleeves, revealing toned forearms. Crouching down, he sent a voice message to his assistant: "Sign me up for a crash course in plumbing. Now."

Water droplets splashed onto his Patek Philippe watch.
###Chapter 380

Lucas Roscente was buried in quarterly reports when his phone vibrated. He glanced at the screen and froze at the caller ID - "Ethan Roscente."

"Mr. Roscente?" Lucas answered, confusion lacing his voice.

"Do you know how to fix a clogged drain?" Ethan's deep voice came through the receiver.

Lucas nearly dropped his phone. He double-checked the caller ID - it was indeed the titan of Wall Street.

"May I ask...why?" He treaded carefully.

"Just answer the question." Impatience sharpened Ethan's tone.

Lucas swallowed hard. "Basic knowledge. First, you'll need to detach the pipe and check for blockages..."

The line went dead.

Ethan crouched beneath the kitchen sink. As he unscrewed the pipe joint, a putrid stench assaulted him.

Rotting vegetable scraps clung to the interior. Gritting his teeth, Ethan picked out the sludge with gloved fingers.

When he turned the faucet back on, water gushed from the loose connection. He shut it off immediately, brows furrowed.

"Still not fixed?" Jenna's voice carried from the living room.

Ethan stood, water stains blooming on his shirt cuffs. "Requires specialized tools."

Jenna pointed to the doorframe. "The building posted a plumber's number."

The advertised plumber informed him they were closed. Ethan hung up and dialed Lucas again.

"Purchase drain-cleaning tools. Deliver to Beverly Hills."

Lucas abandoned his paperwork and raced to the hardware store. One hour later, he handed the tool bag to Ethan outside the luxury condominium.

Watching his boss march upstairs with plumbing gear, Lucas rubbed his eyes. Moonlight illuminated the absurd sight - the impeccably tailored CEO now wrestling with a clogged drain.

"Only in a million years." Lucas shook his head and disappeared into the night.
###Chapter 381

The first rays of sunlight barely touched the market stalls when Jenna Roland finished setting up her booth. She adjusted the T-shirts on the display rack with practiced ease before settling onto the small stool behind her counter.

The first customers arrived quickly—three young women browsing through her selection. Jenna stood to greet them, enthusiastically pointing out different designs.

Then a woman in her fifties shoved through the group. Her faded floral blouse was wrinkled, dirt still caked under her fingernails. Lydia Lombardi grabbed a white T-shirt without looking. "How much for this rag?" she barked.

"That's premium cotton, ma'am. Fifty-five dollars," Jenna replied with a professional smile.

"Fifty-five?" Lydia screeched. "You think I'm stupid? This flea market junk isn't worth half that!"

Jenna's smile froze. In six months of street vending, she'd never encountered such rudeness.

"The fabric won't pill or stretch. My wholesale cost was thirty. Fifty-five is very reasonable," she explained through gritted teeth.

Lydia threw the shirt on the ground. "Pah! I could buy three pounds of pork for that!"

The two browsing customers hastily put down their selections and hurried away. Jenna's hands trembled with anger at the lost sale.

Tanya Hill from the adjacent shoe stall waddled over, her plump frame radiating indignation. "Hey lady, either buy something or stop harassing her!"

"None of your damn business!" Lydia planted her hands on her hips. "These crooks need to be exposed!"

Tanya's temper ignited. "Cheapskate! Can't afford fifty-five? Maybe you should walk around naked!"

Their shouting match erupted instantly. Every time Lydia tried to retort, Tanya drowned her out with louder insults. Nearby vendors began gathering, adding their own commentary.

Jenna watched the spectacle coldly. "Calling you 'ma'am' was too generous. Save some decency unless you want karma biting your kids."

Just then, the woman minding Tanya's stall came rushing over.
###Chapter 382

"Can't we criticize her outrageous pricing? Ganging up on one person—have you no shame?" a woman shrieked in support.

Tanya Hill sneered. "Oh, defending her like she's your mother or ancestor? No wonder your stall's deserted!"

Hannah Kalmien, the sock vendor, chimed in. "Fifty-five for a T-shirt isn't expensive. If you can't afford it, scram. All this whining—she deserves a lesson!"

Other vendors, disgusted by Lydia Lombardi's attitude, rallied behind Jenna Roland.

Lydia turned to leave, cursing under her breath.

Jenna suddenly exploded. "You old hag! May your son die heirless, get run over by a car, and leave your daughter-in-law a miserable widow!"

She hadn't meant to go this far, but the vile woman had insulted her parents—her ultimate red line.

Lydia spun around, jabbing a finger inches from Jenna's face. "You poisonous little bitch! You'll die in the gutter!"

"Say that again," Jenna stepped closer.

"I said your whole family deserves to rot! Worthless trash!" Lydia spat.

Tanya egged her on. "Jenna, slap her already!"

Without hesitation, Jenna backhanded Lydia across the face. "You asked for it, you old witch."

Lydia clutched her cheek, eyes bulging.

"One wasn't enough?" Jenna delivered another stinging slap, then yanked her hair, slamming her to the ground.

When the clothing vendor tried to intervene, Tanya and others blocked her.

Jenna pulled out her phone to call the police.

"Enjoy jail," she said coldly, staring at Lydia sprawled on the pavement.

Tanya added, "That's disorderly conduct—we'll all testify."

Panicked, Lydia tugged her companion's sleeve. "Help me up! Let's go!"

Sophia Valrose, her daughter-in-law, hissed, "Mom, we can't just leave! Let the cops handle this!"

Tanya raised an eyebrow. "You're her daughter?"

Supporting her mother-in-law, Sophia glared. "I'm her daughter-in-law!"
###Chapter 383

Tanya Hill curled her lips in a cold smirk. "So that's how it is. You're jealous because Jenna's business is better than yours, so you sent your mother-in-law to cause trouble? Birds of a feather!"

Jenna Roland's pupils constricted sharply.
She never imagined this Lydia Lombardi was actually Sophia Valrose's mother-in-law.

Just days ago, Tanya had warned her that Sophia was envious of her success.
And now she'd already sent someone for revenge?

Sophia helped Lydia to her feet, her face dark with fury. "Why should she get ahead so fast? Why did she have to set up right in front of me? She ruined my business!"

Jenna almost laughed at the absurdity.
"I can set up wherever I want. If you can't compete, that's your problem."

Tanya crossed her arms, sneering. "Sophia, you're pathetic. Can't handle competition, so you send your mother-in-law to do your dirty work? No shame at all?"

Sophia's face flushed crimson.
Knowing she was in the wrong, she tried dragging Lydia away.

Jenna blocked their path in one swift move. "I've already called the police. They'll be here any minute."
Tanya also barred their escape. "Think you can just run? Not happening."

Sophia ground her teeth. "The street doesn't belong to you! Get out of our way!"
Lydia spat venomously, "Good dogs don't block the road!"

"You scared off my customers and think you can walk away?" Jenna stood her ground.

Hannah Kalmien suddenly interjected, "Sophia, you sabotaged her business first, and your mother-in-law cursed Jenna's parents. Now you won't even apologize?"

She gave Jenna a meaningful look. "Jenna isn't someone you can bully."
That much was true.

Jenna had once chased her uncle around the yard with a cleaver.
She wouldn't let this slide.

Sophia kept deflecting. "She insulted us too! Why should we apologize?"
Hannah frowned deeply. "Are you serious? You started this!"

Just then, the wail of sirens approached.
A police car pulled up smoothly before the stalls.

Three officers stepped out, led by Inspector Liam Hill whom Jenna recognized.

Lydia and Sophia panicked, but Jenna and Tanya held them firmly in place.

Liam's sharp gaze swept over them. "Who called this in?"
His crisp uniform and chiseled features radiated authority.

Though puzzled by his question, Jenna raised her hand. "I did, Officer."
###Chapter 384

By the time Officer Liam Hill arrived, the crowd had formed an impenetrable wall.

Jenna Roland stepped forward and recounted every detail of Lydia Lombardi's deliberate provocation. She emphasized the venomous insults hurled at her family and revealed Sophia Valrose's instigation behind the scenes.

Lydia shrieked in protest, "Her clothes are outrageously priced! What's wrong with speaking my mind? Those customers left on their own—how is that my fault?"

Tanya Hill stood as a witness. "Fifty-five for a T-shirt is expensive? If you can't afford it, walk away. But you had to call them rags and spew profanities."

Hannah Kalmien chimed in, "She came here looking for trouble. We all saw it."

The onlookers murmured in agreement.

After hearing the accounts, Officer Hill turned to Lydia and Sophia. "You're causing a public disturbance. You’ll need to come with us."

Lydia paled and shoved Sophia aside. "Why arrest me? That bitch hit me! She pushed me! Officer, why aren’t you arresting her?"

Officer Hill scanned the crowd. "Did anyone see Jenna lay a hand on her?"

Tanya shook her head. "She's lying."

Hannah added, "Officer, people like her deserve punishment."

No one claimed to have witnessed any physical altercation.

Lydia trembled with rage. "You all saw it! Why are you protecting her? You’re in this together!"

Tanya smirked. "We side with justice, not favoritism. Unlike you two, who can’t stand seeing her business thrive."

Jenna felt a surge of gratitude for maintaining good relationships with her neighbors. She resolved to thank them properly later.

In the end, Lydia was taken away for disrupting public order. Sophia slunk off to pack up her stall.

Jenna bought ten bottles of soda and ten packs of cigarettes from the corner store, distributing them to the vendors who had stood up for her.

"Don’t be afraid if this happens again. We’ve got your back," they assured her warmly.

Her heart swelled. Setting up shop here had been the right decision.

Business quickly rebounded after the commotion died down.

During a brief lull, Tanya returned the cigarettes. "No one in my household smokes. You should take these back."

"Tanya, why don’t you open them and share with everyone?" Jenna suggested.

With a cheerful nod, Tanya broke open the packs and passed them around to the nearby stall owners.
###Chapter 385

At ten in the morning, Jenna Roland waved off her last customer and rubbed her sore shoulders.

She pulled out her phone and dialed Officer Liam Hill.

"Officer Hill, how's the Lydia Lombardi situation?"

His steady voice came through. "Seven-day detention and a five-hundred-dollar fine."

Jenna burst out laughing.

This outcome was even more satisfying than she'd expected.

"Did she throw a fit?"

"Doesn't matter how mad she is. The penalty stands." He paused. "By the way, how's your friend Sylvia?"

Jenna's expression darkened. "Pretty badly hurt. Any leads on those two attackers?"

"Security cameras only caught their backs. Masks and hats. No solid clues yet."

"Sounds like professionals."

"Not necessarily." His tone was firm. "We'll keep investigating."

Jenna changed the subject. "Free for lunch? My treat."

"On duty today. Rain check."

As she hung up and slipped her phone back into her pocket, the door chime jingled.

Milo Roland barged in, full of energy.

"Sis! Business looks good!"

Jenna eyed him up and down. "Ryan's out of the hospital?"

"He can walk on his own now." Milo's smile faltered. "But..."

"What's wrong?"

"His parents divorced. Neither wants him. They're making him drop out and get a job."

The cloth in Jenna's hand fell to the floor.

"He's only a sophomore!"

"So I was thinking..." Milo rubbed his hands together. "Sis, maybe we could help him?"

Jenna narrowed her eyes. "That's why you're here?"

Milo crouched in front of her with an ingratiating grin. "He's got such good grades. It'd be a waste if he quit school."

"A year's tuition plus living expenses would run at least five or six grand." Jenna sighed. "With your expenses too, that's a lot of pressure."

"Think of it as an investment!" His eyes sparkled. "Once he gets into college, he'll pay you back for sure!"

Jenna met her brother's hopeful gaze and felt her resolve soften.
###Chapter 386

"So you agree?" Milo's eyes lit up.

Jenna crossed her arms. "I'll sponsor him, but he has to pay me back."

With her current financial stability, funding Ryan's education wasn't an issue.

In the past, she would never have made such an offer.

Milo pouted. "Sponsorship means free money. Who asks for repayment?"

Jenna flicked his forehead. "Do I look like a money printer? Tell him I'll only cover his senior year if he agrees to repay me."

"What about living expenses?"

She rubbed her temples. Ryan was still hospitalized and couldn't work summer jobs. Winter break was his only option.

"After discharge, he can work at my stall—$100 per day. He'll earn $1,500 before school starts. Weekends at $100 for two days. You chip in occasionally, and he'll make it to graduation."

Milo gave a thumbs-up. "You're the best, sis!"

Jenna scoffed. "Only because he helped you and deserves pity..."

"Once he gains experience, he could start a small business after college. With luck, he might even become a boss."

"If he strikes it rich, he'll repay you tenfold!"

"Enough chatter!" She poked his forehead. "Watch the stall. I need the restroom."

"Got it!" Milo grinned.

——

At 3 PM Wednesday, Ethan stopped by the stall.

Coincidentally, urban management officers were conducting inspections.

They frantically loaded garments onto the e-tricycle.

After outrunning the officers, Jenna grinned ear to ear. "Thrilling, huh?"

Ethan sighed. "Being chased by authorities is an achievement?"

"Adrenaline rush! They'd have confiscated everything."

"Why not open a proper store?"

"Street vending earns more." She shook her head.

Returning later, they found the officers gone and reset their remaining merchandise.

"Join me for wholesale shopping tomorrow?" Jenna asked abruptly.

Ethan frowned. He had an important international conference in the morning.

"We leave at 6:30 AM," she added.

"That early?"

"Latecomers get leftovers." She winked.

Rubbing his temples, he relented. "Fine."
###Chapter 387

Ethan Roscente's slender fingers tapped rhythmically on his desk in the HM Group CEO office.

"Lucas, reschedule tomorrow's international conference to 2 PM."

The tablet nearly slipped from Lucas Roscente's grasp.

"Sir, our overseas branches have confirmed three times already. A last-minute change might—"

"I have arrangements." Ethan didn't look up, his tone brooking no argument.

Lucas swallowed hard. The workaholic CEO had never postponed meetings for personal reasons, let alone the crucial weekly global strategy session.

"May I... provide our international partners with an explanation?"

"Tell them I have urgent matters." Ethan flipped open a file. "Dismissed."

Lucas exited in a daze.

Last week's memory flashed before him—Ethan standing motionless by a street food stall, gaze fixed on a bustling young woman.

"Oh no..." Lucas muttered. "Is the CEO really falling for her?"

His mind conjured apocalyptic visions: an empty executive office, paperwork piling to the ceiling, while their illustrious CEO wore an apron making change at a night market...

———

Dawn barely tinted the sky at 6 AM.

Jenna Roland shoved the last jacket into her trunk and grinned at Ethan. "Perfect timing! We got the newest collection."

Ethan frowned at her wind-chapped nose.

"You could establish supplier contracts."

"New designers don't get those privileges." She rubbed her hands together. "Come on, let's check accessories."

Silently noting the wholesale market's name, Ethan hefted two garment bags and followed.

Inside the bustling marketplace, Jenna navigated stalls with practiced ease.

"Hold fifty of these hair clips for me!" She stretched toward the top shelf.

Ethan stood sentry, the ghost of a smile touching his lips as he watched excitement spark in her eyes.

"Guard the goods." She vanished into another vendor's booth.

He nodded, his towering frame drawing covert glances from passing shoppers. Yet his attention never wavered from that one busy figure weaving through the crowd.
###Chapter 388

Jenna Roland emerged from the wholesale market dragging two enormous bags of clothes. Sweat dampened the stray hairs clinging to her forehead.

She panted as she dropped the bundles at Ethan Roscente's feet, her cheeks flushed from exertion.

"There's one more bag upstairs." Wiping her brow, her eyes sparkled. "Wait here."

Ethan reached to help, but she dodged with surprising agility.

"I've got this!" She turned and sprinted upstairs, her ponytail bouncing behind her.

Within ten minutes, Jenna descended with a third oversized bundle obscuring her view. Yet her steps remained steady despite the obstructed vision.

"We should carry them together." Jenna scanned their surroundings warily. "What if someone steals the clothes?"

Ethan chuckled but obediently lifted two bags. Jenna clutched the remaining bundle protectively, like a mother bear guarding her cub.

Their e-tricycle waited by the market entrance. Jenna dashed over in quick strides, only relaxing after verifying the garments' safety.

"You need a proper vehicle." Ethan eyed the overloaded trike.

At the red light, Jenna hit the brakes.

"A minivan?" She scoffed. "Too expensive."

Ethan turned with focused intensity. "Used ones are affordable. More practical too."

Jenna nibbled her lip in thought. When the light turned green, she revved the engine.

"You're right." She sighed. "Should've asked around earlier."

At Mall of America, Jenna stretched as her stomach growled audibly.

"Come on, I'll buy you baozi." She winked at Ethan. "Their soy milk is amazing."

Tanya Hill was organizing merchandise at her stall. After entrusting her with the trike, Jenna tugged Ethan toward the breakfast shop.

Morning sunlight draped over them, casting elongated shadows. Jenna's steps turned light and lively, as if the earlier exhaustion had never existed.
###Chapter 389

Morning sunlight spilled across the street corner. After breakfast with Ethan Roscente, Jenna Roland watched as he helped set up her stall before leaving. He didn't call for his driver, opting to hail a cab to the office instead.

Her stall was draped with new clothing designs. Customers streamed in from the moment she opened, keeping her so busy she barely had time to sip water. Only by noon did she finally catch her breath.

Just as she sat down to rest, Milo Roland arrived with Ryan Watson in tow.

"Sis," Ryan said hesitantly, standing before the stall.

Jenna nodded in understanding and launched into a detailed explanation of street vending tips and pricing strategies. By the time she finished, it was nearly 11:30.

She headed to a nearby restaurant to order several dishes. When the food was ready, the staff delivered it directly to her stall.

Borrowing a folding table from Tanya Hill next door, Jenna set out the meal. "Aunt Tanya, would you like to join us?"

"No thanks, my husband's bringing lunch soon," Tanya replied with a wave.

After politely declining invitations from other nearby vendors, Jenna sat down to eat with Milo and Ryan.

"Ryan, the stall's profits aren't high, so I can only pay you $100 a day," Jenna said, placing a piece of meat in his bowl. "With two weeks until school starts, you'll earn about $1,500."

Ryan's eyes reddened. "Sis, you've already covered my medical bills and tuition. I'd work for free."

"You need income right now," Jenna insisted, adding more food to his bowl. "If you call me sis, then don't stand on ceremony."

Ryan ducked his head over his rice, blinking back tears. In all his life, only his grandparents had shown him such kindness. He silently vowed to repay Jenna someday.

After lunch, Jenna noticed Ryan's faded clothes and cracked shoes. Leaving the boys in charge of the stall, she hurried to a nearby mall.

She bought Ryan four outfits and selected two pairs of shoes plus socks in Milo's size.

As she returned with armfuls of shopping bags, she spotted a crowd gathered around her stall, angry shouts carrying through the air.

Her heart lurched. Jenna broke into a run.

Pushing through the crowd, she saw a hulking man raising his hand to strike Milo!

"Stop!" Jenna shouted.

Tanya and other vendors struggled to restrain the brute, but his massive frame overpowered them.

Jenna threw herself in front of Milo, glaring at the man. "Let him go!"
###Chapter 390

The man gripped Milo Roland's collar with bone-white knuckles.

Jenna Roland lunged forward, but his grip didn't loosen.

A feral glint flashed in Jenna's eyes as she sank her teeth into the man's wrist.

"Ah!" He howled in pain, shoving Milo away before backhanding Jenna across the face.

"You bitch!" Spittle flew from his twisted mouth as he raised his foot to kick her stomach.

Tanya Hill and her crew surged forward, forming a protective wall around Jenna.

"Cops are on their way!" Tanya barked. The burly men behind her took a synchronized step forward.

The man spat on the ground, unleashing a torrent of obscenities.

A fist cut through the air with a whoosh.

Someone's punch connected with the man's nose, sending blood gushing down his face.

A brutal kick to the back of his knees sent him crashing to the pavement.

Blows rained down like hail as he curled into a fetal position.

Jenna shook her head, trying to clear the ringing in her ears.

"Give me your shoe." She held out her hand to Milo.

The crowd parted like the Red Sea.

Jenna swung the sneaker, its rubber sole smacking against the man's face with dull thuds.

"I've hacked my own uncle with a cleaver!" Each swing carried the weight of her fury.

His screams mingled with cheers from the onlookers.

Sirens wailed in the distance.

Jenna crouched to tie Milo's shoelaces, her fingers trembling slightly.

"Ryan!" Milo suddenly cried out.

The teenager lay curled on the ground, his T-shirt soaked with sweat.

Jenna pulled out her phone, blood from the attacker still smeared on her fingertips.

"Stay with me." She pressed down on Ryan's twitching arm.

Police uniforms pushed through the crowd.

Officer Liam Hill surveyed the chaotic scene with a frown.

"He threw the first punch." Milo pointed at the bloodied man. "Check the surveillance footage."

Tanya and the others nodded vigorously, all talking over each other to corroborate.

An ambulance siren pierced the night.

Jenna wiped her face, leaving a streak of blood across her hand.
###Chapter 391

The street vendors all testified, unanimously identifying the man as the instigator.

Officer Cole Macmillan glanced at the man curled up on the ground before turning to Jenna Roland. "What happened here?"

Jenna straightened her posture. "I hit him. He grabbed my brother by the collar—Milo just had surgery. I bit him, and he slapped me." She pointed to the blood at the corner of her mouth. "See? My ears are still ringing."

Officer Cole frowned. "But his injuries are severe. For a young woman like you—"

"I kicked the back of his knee," Jenna said bluntly. "When he dropped, I kicked him a few more times."

Milo immediately chimed in. "Officer, look at his size. We stood no chance. My friend just had an appendectomy and can't even stand straight now. This was clearly assault!"

The man on the ground groaned, his swollen lips unable to form coherent words.

Officer Liam Hill crouched beside him. "Name? Why did you attack the stall?"

"I... was..." The man slurred.

Jenna clenched her fists. "Officer, punish this bastard properly!"

Liam's gaze lingered on Jenna's face—her left cheek swollen, her ear flushed red, blood trickling from her lip. He averted his eyes calmly. "Call an ambulance."

Soon, sirens wailed as paramedics arrived.

The medical team loaded the man and Ryan Watson into the ambulance. Jenna accompanied them while Milo stayed to pack up their stall. Liam and Cole followed to the hospital.

In the examination room, the doctor frowned. "What's your relation to Ryan?"

"My brother's classmate. He was helping at our stall." Jenna asked urgently, "How is he?"

"Post-op wound rupture with internal bleeding," the doctor admonished. "He needs immediate debridement surgery."

Jenna dug her nails into her palms. She never should've let Ryan help.

"Operate as soon as possible," she said, voice trembling.

The doctor turned to Liam. "The other patient's condition is worse. Three fractured ribs, a broken leg, perforated eardrum, and internal bleeding."

Liam glanced at Jenna. He knew full well she couldn't have inflicted such damage alone. But for now, he remained silent.

"Treat the injuries first," Liam told the doctor.

The doctor shook his head helplessly. "We need family consent for surgery."
###Chapter 392 

Liam Hill flashed his police badge. "The family can't be reached right now. I'll sign the surgical consent form."

The doctor glanced at the credentials and immediately went to assemble the surgical team.

As the red light above the operating room lit up, Jenna Roland's phone rang. It was Milo calling to check on Ryan Watson's condition.

"The wound reopened, causing internal bleeding. He needs another surgery." Jenna's voice trembled slightly as she gripped her phone.

Relief was palpable on the other end of the line.

Liam crossed his arms, his dark eyes narrowing. "Your friend seems very concerned about you."

Jenna's fingers tightened around her phone. "What?"

"I said," Liam's lips curved slightly, "you're quite popular."

She forced a dry chuckle. "I guess."

Something in his tone made her wary.

His gaze dropped to the side of her face. "Shouldn't you get that ear checked?"

Jenna touched her swollen earlobe. "I can hear fine. It's probably nothing."

"If you don't examine it now, who will you blame if problems arise later?" His voice turned stern. "Come with me."

The words snapped her to attention. She followed silently.

At the registration desk, Liam efficiently handled everything on his phone. An ENT examination was quickly arranged.

He leaned against the wall outside the examination room, waiting. Thirty minutes later, Jenna emerged with a report.

"Tympanic congestion." She handed him the paper. "The doctor said it's minor."

Liam skimmed the results. "Get the prescribed medication and use it as directed."

They returned to the operating wing just as Ryan was wheeled out. Pale and groggy from anesthesia, he looked fragile.

When Ryan finally awoke in his hospital room, his first words were an apology. "Jenna, I'm so sorry..."

She gently squeezed his hand. "Don't be reckless next time."

The boy's eyes brimmed with guilt as he nodded.
###Chapter 393

Two hours later, Liam Hill called.

"The surgery is done. He's in the room next to Ryan's," Liam's steady voice came through the phone.

Jenna hung up and checked that Ryan was asleep before quietly stepping out.

The sharp scent of disinfectant hit her as she pushed open the neighboring door.

Liam stood by the bed. "How's Ryan?" he asked in a low voice.

"Fine." Jenna's gaze shifted to the patient. "And him?"

The man on the bed was awake, his face dark with fury.

When he saw Jenna, he thrashed violently, hatred burning in his eyes.

"You bitch! This isn't over!" he snarled through gritted teeth.

Jenna took two calm steps forward.

"Threatening someone in front of an officer?" She turned to Liam. "Officer Hill, what's the penalty for intimidation?"

"Detention," Liam replied coldly.

Jenna smirked. "Had to ruin your own life by trashing my stall. Got a death wish?"

Liam pulled out his notepad. "Name. Why did you vandalize the stall?"

The man turned his head away defiantly.

Only when Liam flashed his badge and warned him about obstructing justice did the man reluctantly speak.

"Leo Lombardi." He glared at Jenna. "She got my mom arrested and ruined my wife's business!"

Jenna's pupils contracted.

Lydia Lombardi's son.

No wonder he came after her.

Leo kept shouting, "These injuries are from those vendors! Arrest them!"

Liam shut his notepad. "Evidence?"

Leo froze, then exploded. "What evidence? You think she did this to me?"

"Evidence is required for charges," Liam said flatly. "No evidence, no case."

Leo tried to sit up but was pinned by his leg cast.

"Why won't you believe me?" he screamed hysterically.

Liam remained unmoved. "The law requires proof. Without it, anyone could accuse anyone."

Jenna cut in smoothly, "You're paying Ryan's medical bills."

"Never!" Leo's face twisted. "If he hadn't interfered—"

Jenna ignored him, turning to Liam. "Officer Hill, I'll leave the compensation matter to you."

Back in Ryan's room, she called Milo.

After a brief update, she hurried back to the night market.

Tanya and the others immediately surrounded her.

"Fractures and internal bleeding," Jenna said calmly. "But he brought it on himself."

The fruit vendor exhaled in relief. "You didn't mention us, right?"

"Don't worry." Jenna smiled slightly. "This stays between us."

The vendors finally relaxed.
###Chapter 394

Jenna Roland stared at the pile of dirty clothes Milo had sorted out, her brow furrowed. The garments were covered in dust and stains—unsellable now. She'd have to wash them for personal use.

That bastard Leo Lombardi had cost her hundreds again.

With her folding table broken under Leo's stomping feet, Jenna had to pack up early. She crouched down, methodically folding each item into the woven bag while calculating tomorrow's expenses—a new wooden board for her stall was essential.

Her steps slowed outside a used car dealership.

"How much for the minivan?"

"Not bad—just over thirty grand. Only a year old." The owner answered around his cigarette, disinterested.

A new one wouldn't cost much more. Jenna scoffed, adjusting her heavy bags before trudging home.

The moment she crossed the threshold, she dropped the bundles and collapsed onto the couch, gasping. Sweat trickled down her temples, her back drenched.

After thirty minutes, she suddenly stood and left again.

She didn't head for the market. Instead, she went straight to the auto dealership.

By dusk, a gleaming silver minivan sat parked below their apartment building.

Jenna ran her fingers over the steering wheel, lips curling upward. Though unregistered, this vehicle would revolutionize her vending business.

On the way back, she picked up a replacement board and stopped by the fishmonger for a live carp and fresh greens.

Golden sunset rays gilded their kitchen when she returned.

......

The aroma of home cooking greeted Ethan Roscente as he opened the door.

The tangy sweetness of sweet-and-sour fish mingled with sautéed vegetables, making his mouth water involuntarily.

"You're back?" Jenna emerged with two rice bowls. "Wash up for dinner."

When Ethan returned from washing his hands, she was ladling soup. Her damp hair, tied in a high ponytail, indicated a recent shower.

"Closed shop early today?" He accepted the chopsticks she offered.

"Bought a car." She deposited a piece of fish in his bowl. "Took your advice—didn't go used."

Ethan's eyebrow arched. "You can drive?"

"Who do you think you're looking down on?" Jenna tilted her chin up. "My license predates yours."

"Really?" Ethan suddenly leaned in, warm breath grazing her ear. "Then why don't you... show me what you've got?"

Heat flooded Jenna's ears. She rapped his knuckles with her chopsticks. "Can't even eat without running your mouth!"

Ethan's low laughter sparkled in his eyes like scattered starlight.
###Chapter 395

A cold smile curled at the corners of Liu Ruyan's lips. "Third Sister, you swear? Many people in this world make deadly oaths. How many actually suffer the consequences?"

Her gaze locked onto Liu Hongxing's eyes, her voice soft yet carrying undeniable authority. "After all these years, I can guess your schemes with my eyes closed."

Liu Hongxing's pupils gradually lost focus.

"Who exactly is that old woman?" Liu Ruyan pressed.

"My father's birth mother," Liu Hongxing answered mechanically. "She's been coming to our house since I can remember. After Grandma passed, she moved in permanently. Dad said she was just a hired caretaker."

Liu Ruyan's eyes glinted. "What's your father's real name? Where is the old woman from? Does she have other family?"

"She calls him Liu Ergou. No idea about her hometown—never been there."

"On the seventh night after Grandma's funeral, who pushed me down the stairs?" Liu Ruyan finally voiced the question buried deep within her.

"It was Dad's plan," Liu Hongxing said tonelessly. "He told you about the ghost visitation ritual on purpose. He had Second Brother and me tie ropes across the stairs and scatter marbles and banana peels."

Liu Ruyan's heart clenched. "I'd already agreed to go to the countryside. Why try to kill me?"

"The villa was in your name. Grandma's will stated it would only pass to us if you died."

"Was Gao Hongxia part of your scheme too?"

"Dad paid her five hundred yuan to replace someone else and get assigned to your work team."

Liu Ruyan smirked. Gao Hongxia had ruined her life for five hundred yuan—she must be drowning in regret now.

After extracting every answer, Liu Ruyan guided Liu Hongxing back to bed. Watching the peacefully sleeping Liu Hongying, she sighed softly. Sometimes ignorance truly was bliss. Liu Hongying's simple-mindedness had spared her from this web of filth.

Leaving the Liu residence, Liu Ruyan headed straight for People's Hospital. Tian Gui'e lay stiff as a mummy in her deserted hospital room.

After administering a sedative, Liu Ruyan transported the unconscious woman into her secret space. The white wolf curiously tapped its paw against Tian's chest—

"YOWCH!"

Tian jolted upright, only to faint again at the sight of a giant wolf muzzle inches from her face.

"Silver Moon, was that on purpose?" Liu Ruyan stifled a laugh.

The wolf pouted. I was just inspecting this strange creature.

"You're a wolf. Of course people faint when they see you."

Says the girl who trembled like a leaf when we first met, Silver Moon thought smugly, though aloud it praised, "Few possess your courage."

Amused, Liu Ruyan admitted, "I was terrified too at first."

Her gaze shifted to the unconscious Tian Gui'e. Now to pry more secrets from this woman's lips.
###Chapter 396

Jenna grabbed a towel and rushed into the kitchen, her trembling fingers wrapping around Ethan's bloodied hand. Warm crimson seeped through the fabric, staining her palm with a vivid red.

"You need the hospital!" Her voice shook with urgency.

Ethan glanced at his bandaged left hand, oddly pleased by the timing of this injury. The glistening tears in Jenna's eyes sent warmth through his chest, turning pain into sweet torment.

"It's really nothing—"

"Shut up!" She yanked him toward the door with surprising strength.

A rusty minivan waited at the alley's entrance, its door screeching in protest. Ethan hesitated—the battered vehicle stood in stark contrast to his usual Maybach.

"Get in!" Jenna revved the engine, black smoke puffing from the exhaust.

The moment his seatbelt clicked, the van lurched forward. Through the rearview mirror, he saw her biting her lower lip hard enough to draw blood. At that moment, he wouldn't mind dying in a crash.

Fluorescent lights glared in the ER. When the nurse peeled back the blood-soaked towel, Jenna gasped—a jagged wound spanned his entire palm, tiny porcelain shards embedded in the torn flesh.

"A bowl did this?" The doctor adjusted his glasses skeptically.

Antiseptic fumes filled the air, but Ethan only watched Jenna's white-knuckled grip on the chair. She trembled as if the injury were her own.

"Will it scar?" Her whisper barely carried over the suturing sounds.

The doctor didn't look up. "Depends on aftercare. But..." His gaze flicked to Ethan's elegant fingers. "Such beautiful hands. What a shame."

Suddenly Ethan clasped Jenna's hand with his bloody right one. "That painter you like—exhibition next month at the gallery." A pause. "Come with me?"

Her tears finally fell, mingling with drying blood on his skin.
###Chapter 397

Dr. Nathan Watson carefully stitched up Ethan Roscente's wound and wrapped it in pristine white bandages.

"Keep the wound dry. Change the dressing every three days." He adjusted his glasses. "Drink plenty of water and rest."

Ethan gave a noncommittal grunt, grabbing Jenna Roland's hand to leave.

The hospital lobby buzzed with activity.

Jenna suddenly stopped walking.

Officer Liam Hill approached in his police uniform, accompanied by his colleague Dr. Cole Macmillan.

"Officer Hill." Jenna smiled in greeting. "Still at the hospital?"

Liam's gaze lingered on Ethan before shifting to Jenna. "And this is?"

"Her husband." Ethan spoke first, tightening his grip on Jenna's hand. "Officer Hill, I presume? Heard a lot about you."

Jenna shot Ethan a glare.

Liam's expression darkened. "So Ms. Roland is already married."

"Yes." Jenna forced an awkward laugh. "Here on a case, Officer?"

"Brought in an injured suspect for treatment." Liam's tone remained neutral.

After brief pleasantries, Jenna quickly pulled Ethan away.

Cole nudged Liam with his elbow. "Smitten?"

Liam averted his gaze. "Any man would admire a beautiful, sensible woman."

"Too bad you're late." Cole teased. "Her husband doesn't seem like someone to trifle with."

Liam didn't respond.

The man was undeniably striking. Standing beside Jenna, they looked like a painting.

"Let's go pay the bill." He turned toward the counter.

Inside the car.

Ethan stared at the passing scenery. "How do you know that Officer Hill?"

"When Milo got into that fight at the police station." Jenna focused on driving. "He also handled the incident when Leo Lombardi vandalized our stall."

Ethan tapped his fingers against his knee. "What a coincidence."

"I called the police the first time." Jenna explained. "Aunt Tanya reported the second incident. He's been helpful."

Ethan let out a cold laugh.

"When I pushed Lydia Lombardi, all the vendors testified for me." Jenna continued. "This time with Leo's injury, if not for Officer Hill—"

"No one helps without reason." Ethan cut her off sharply. "There's always an ulterior motive."

Jenna's grip on the steering wheel tightened.

The air in the car turned icy.
###Chapter 398

Jenna kept her eyes on the road, her tone calm. "He probably likes me, but I'm not sure. Now that you've made our relationship clear, he should back off."

She sighed inwardly. If Liam truly gave up, she wouldn't be able to ask for his help when in trouble again.

Oh well. She couldn't keep taking advantage of his feelings.

That would be unfair.

From now on, she'd keep things strictly professional.

Ethan gazed out the window at the blur of pedestrians rushing past.

Suddenly, he spoke. "If you meet a better man than me someday, would you leave?"

Jenna burst out laughing. "Don't be ridiculous! We've known each other so long that I've memorized all your quirks. Starting over with someone new would be exhausting!"

"Besides, what man could possibly outshine you? I'm not some naive girl who falls for sweet talk. I prefer substance—someone strong, reliable, responsible, financially stable, and actually helpful when it counts."

"Hmm?" Ethan arched a brow, the tension in his face easing into a smirk. "Substance? So I'm just a tool to you?"

Jenna shot him a glare. "Don't twist my words! Marriage is about mutual support. Good looks alone are useless. Kindness needs to translate into action."

"I'm both kind and committed to this family," Ethan stated bluntly.

"So you've got nothing to worry about. I'd never leave."

Jenna maintained steady control of the wheel. When another driver cut her off, she rolled down the window and cursed. The offender swallowed his anger upon seeing a woman behind the wheel.

Back home, Jenna said, "Rest up. I'll do the dishes."

"Okay." Ethan obediently settled on the sofa.

After cleaning the kitchen, she found him watching TV. "I'm going to shower."

"Okay." His tone remained gentle.

Fresh from her bath and skincare routine, Jenna approached him. "Your turn."

Ethan raised his bandaged right hand with a roguish grin. "Doctor's orders—no water contact."

"Oh." Jenna deadpanned. "Then wait till it heals."

He frowned. "We share a bed. Won't you mind the stink?"

She blinked innocently. "I like your natural musk."

Ethan was rendered speechless.

He tried again. "I shower daily. Can't sleep otherwise. Get my drift?"

Jenna dropped the act and nodded sweetly. "Got it. You want me to take you to a public bathhouse, right?"
###Chapter 399

Jenna saw right through Ethan's little game.

His intentions were practically written across his face.

He just wanted her to help him bathe.

She decided to play dumb instead.

"I really don't know what you're talking about." Jenna blinked her innocent doe eyes, fluttering her lashes.

Ethan narrowed his gaze and grabbed her collar.

"Playing dumb?"

He leaned in close, his warm breath brushing against her neck.

"My hand is injured. You're helping me shower tonight."

Jenna shrank back.

"No!"

She refused firmly. "Men and women shouldn't be so intimate."

Ethan chuckled lowly.

"We share the same bed. What boundaries are left?"

Jenna pried his hand off and tried to bolt.

The next second, the world spun.

She landed in his lap, her cheeks instantly burning.

"You—"

"I'm injured." Ethan gave her a pitiful look.

Jenna turned her face away.

"Missing one shower won't kill you."

His gaze dropped to her flushed lips.

His thumb grazed them lightly.

"So soft..."

Jenna shuddered.

"Pervert!"

She shoved him away and darted off like a startled rabbit.

Ethan watched her retreating figure, his chest shaking with laughter.

This girl—her flustered reactions were adorable.

His phone suddenly rang.

"Speak."

"Mr. Roscente, the East Glory Group proposed a marriage alliance..."

Ethan lit a cigarette and exhaled a slow stream of smoke.

"Felix Savigny's daughter?"

He smirked. "She's not even worthy."

On the other end, Lucas nearly fell out of his chair.

"Y-You're married?"

"None of your business."

Ethan stubbed out the cigarette, his gaze softening as it drifted toward the bedroom.
###Chapter 400

Lucas's Adam's apple bobbed visibly.

He collapsed into his office chair like a puppet with its strings cut.

Ethan Roscente was married?

As the CEO's personal assistant of five years, how could he have been completely unaware?

The secrecy was beyond impressive.

His phone suddenly vibrated in his palm.

Lucas nearly jumped out of his skin.

"Felix Savigny" flashed across the screen.

"Good afternoon, Chairman Savigny."

"Lucas, any updates on our lunchtime discussion?"

Lucas forced a professional smile. "My apologies, but Mr. Roscente is already married."

"What?!" Felix's voice spiked through the receiver. "Since when?"

A titan like Ethan getting married should have sent shockwaves through the business world.

Especially since the Savignys and Roscentes were old family friends.

"I don't have details. Mr. Roscente just confirmed it himself."

Lucas hastily ended the call and exhaled sharply.

In the Savigny mansion, Felix's hand trembled around his phone.

"What's wrong?" His wife Audrey looked up in concern.

Their daughter Cecilia set down her scrolling device.

"Ethan Roscente is married!" Felix slammed his palm on the sofa armrest.

Audrey gasped. "That's impossible!"

Cecilia bit her lip. "Dad, is he just brushing us off?"

Felix immediately dialed Grandpa Harrison Roscente.

With the Savigny Group's cash flow crisis, this marriage alliance was supposed to be their lifeline.

"Harrison, I heard Ethan got married?"

"Yes, the registration was finalized a while back. Just waiting on the wedding ceremony."

Felix shot to his feet. "Which family's daughter?"

He needed to know who had stolen this opportunity right from under the Savignys' noses.
###Chapter 401

"She's not from a prestigious family, just an ordinary girl." Grandpa Harrison Roscente's hearty laughter came through the phone. "Though her background is modest, this girl has remarkable resilience. Quite endearing."

Felix Savigny's brow furrowed. "An ordinary family?"

"Yes. Her parents passed away early, and now she lives with her younger brother." Grandpa Harrison's tone remained cheerful. "We'll invite you to the wedding celebration. I must go now—another meeting awaits."

After hanging up, Felix turned to Audrey and Cecilia Savigny with a grim expression. "Ethan Roscente has indeed registered his marriage. To a girl with no connections whatsoever. How could the Roscentes allow this? They've lost their minds!"

Audrey gasped, covering her mouth. "Ethan married a commoner? Impossible!"

"If only I knew the reason!" Felix massaged his temples in frustration.

Cecilia bit her lip, her voice trembling. "Dad, if I can't marry Ethan, the Roscentes won't help us. With the company's broken capital chain, we're finished without their support!"

A cold glint flashed in Audrey's eyes. "Did the old man mention the girl's name?"

"No." Felix shook his head.

"Then we'll find out." Audrey's voice turned icy. "Once we locate that woman, we'll make her leave Ethan willingly."

The Savigny Group teetered on the brink of collapse. Only the wealthy Roscentes could save them now. This was the legacy of generations—if it crumbled under Felix's watch, he'd never face his ancestors in the afterlife.

Cecilia fretted. "Mom, they're already married. If Ethan truly loves her, even if she agrees to divorce, he won't."

"We won't know until we try." Audrey squeezed her daughter's hand. "Cecilia, don't you remember your childhood promise to Ethan? You vowed to be his bride. This is your chance. Your father and I will make it happen."

No one knew Cecilia's heart belonged to another—her boyfriend, a graphic designer at an ad agency. Though his salary barely covered rent, he'd shown her real love. The arranged marriage had filled her with resistance.

Now Ethan's sudden wedding brought unexpected relief. She could only hope his love for that girl was genuine—so she wouldn't be forced into the Roscente family.

......

"Achoo—"

In the living room, Ethan sneezed three times in succession.

Jenna Roland had just ended a client call when she heard the commotion. Peeking around the doorframe, she asked, "Catching a cold?"

Ethan gave her a pitiful look. "I'm heartbroken."

"What nonsense?" Jenna frowned.

"You won't bathe me." He stepped closer, eyes brimming with accusation.

"...Drop dead!" Jenna rolled her eyes and slammed the door shut.
###Chapter 402

Jenna leaned against the headboard, her fingers swiping rapidly across her phone screen.

Ethan stood by the bed and sighed deeply. "Someone's being rather heartless."

Jenna didn't look up, continuing to scroll through short videos.

Seeing her indifference, Ethan grabbed his pajamas and headed for the bathroom.

Suddenly remembering the doctor's warning, Jenna bolted upright. She glared at the bathroom door, her brow furrowed.

"Ethan!" She rushed to the bathroom entrance. "The doctor said your wound can't get wet! Are you insane?"

The door swung open.

Ethan stood there wearing only black boxer briefs, water droplets trailing down his defined abs. He braced one arm against the doorframe, smirking at her.

Jenna's gaze involuntarily dropped.

Eight perfectly sculpted abdominal muscles, with the hint of a V-line leading downward. Her ears burned instantly.

"Running away?" Ethan yanked her into the bathroom and locked the door behind them.

Pinned against the tiled wall, Jenna was engulfed by his masculine scent.

"Since you're here," Ethan murmured against her ear, his breath warm, "why not help me wash my back?"

Jenna covered her flushed face. "Y-you're going too far!"

"Too far?" His low chuckle vibrated against her skin. "Who was the one who came knocking?"

The cramped space filled with steam. Jenna could hear her own heartbeat pounding in her ears.

"I just..." Her voice trembled. "I didn't want your wound to get infected..."

Ethan suddenly released her, his expression softening. "Go to bed."

Jenna hesitated.

"If you don't leave now," Ethan narrowed his eyes, "I'll make you stay."

Jenna fled.

Even lying in bed, the image of his sculpted, dripping-wet torso refused to leave her mind.
###Chapter 403

Ethan stood wearing only black boxer briefs, his sculpted physique on full display.

The defined ridges of his abs gleamed like honey under the light, utterly mesmerizing.

Jenna stared at his torso, her mind drifting to forbidden places.

She remembered those late-night movies she'd secretly watched under the covers.

Despite watching several, her lack of real-world experience left her imagination wanting.

Her gaze involuntarily traveled lower, and her cheeks suddenly burned.

With a body like that, the experience must be incredible.

Ethan emerged from the closet in pajamas to find Jenna grinning at the ceiling.

Her flushed face and dazed eyes betrayed her scandalous thoughts.

"What's on your mind?" He snapped his fingers before her eyes.

Jenna startled, meeting his knowing smirk. Panic set in.

"N-nothing!"

Ethan crossed his arms, looking down at her. "That blush says otherwise."

She nearly choked on her own saliva.

How did he read her so easily?

Rolling away, she faced the wall. "I'm going to sleep!"

His low chuckle followed him out. When he returned from a phone call, Jenna was still scrolling on her phone.

The moment he lay down, she flinched away like a startled rabbit.

"Running?" His long arm hooked around her waist, pulling her flush against him.

Her back pressed to his chest, every contour unmistakable through the thin fabric.

"Let me go!" Her voice trembled.

Ethan's breath tickled her ear. "Why so jumpy?"

"I'll sleep on the couch!" She squirmed.

His arm tightened. "Keep wriggling. See what happens."

Jenna froze instantly.

Then the world spun as he pinned her beneath him.
###Chapter 404

Jenna's pupils constricted like a startled fawn. She writhed violently beneath Ethan, her legs kicking wildly as if he were a predator about to devour her.

Ethan clamped down on her slender wrists. Jenna went completely still, reduced to futile struggles like a beached fish.

"We may be legally married, but I was forced into this!" Her voice trembled. "I'll call the police if you don't stop!"

Ethan chuckled darkly, his smoldering gaze pinning her. "You're always overthinking things. Don't you want to experience it for yourself?"

"No!" Jenna's cheeks burned crimson like ripe cherries. "I'm warning you—don't you dare!"

"Women always say the opposite of what they mean." His breath scorched her neck as he whispered against her ear.

Jenna shuddered. "Milo is right next door! What if he hears—"

"Then stay quiet." Ethan traced her fevered cheek. "Unless...you want him to hear?"

"You—" Her eyes welled up, voice breaking. "I'm scared..."

"Don't be." He kissed her trembling lashes. "I'll be gentle."

Months of marriage without even a kiss. Jenna recalled her friend's warning: men who abstain too long stray easily. Since they were already wed, perhaps she shouldn't refuse anymore.

"Then...be gentle." The concession came in a whisper.

Ethan's gaze darkened, zeroing in on her bitten lips. His Adam's apple bobbed before he claimed that rosy mouth.

Jenna stiffened at first, but his skilled kiss soon melted her resistance. Her clumsy response accidentally nipped his tongue.

"Ah—" He hissed in pain but laughed low. "Little fool."

The endearment burned her ears. Before she could protest, another searing kiss silenced her.

......

When the storm passed, Ethan reluctantly broke the kiss. Cradling her close, his voice turned gravelly. "I'll cherish only you in this lifetime."

Jenna's flushed face abruptly cooled. "Cheat on me, and I'll castrate you."

Ethan blinked before chuckling into her hair. "That brutal?"

"Do you know how important a woman's first time is?" She fisted his collar, eyes blazing. "Betray me, and you'll lose everything down there."
###Chapter 405

Ethan Roscente immediately sobered when he saw Jenna Roland's suddenly serious expression.

He met her gaze directly and solemnly raised his right hand. "I, Ethan Roscente, swear that if I ever fail you, may heaven strike me down."

Jenna snorted and pulled his hand down. "Enough already. I'm going to shower."

"What about me?" Ethan asked seriously. "Want to shower together?"

"Dream on!" Jenna's ears turned pink. "I'll get a wet towel. You can clean yourself."

She quickly slipped into her nightgown and fled the room.

Ethan threw back the covers. The stark red stain on the sheets made his breath catch.

So she really had been a virgin.

No wonder she'd resisted so fiercely, so terrified, crying from the pain.

The memory of that night at the hotel flashed through his mind—how close Oliver Macmillan had come to taking her.

His fists clenched involuntarily, knuckles turning white.

That bastard had almost ruined her.

And he would pay for it. Soon.

Ethan pulled on his pajama pants and walked bare-chested into the living room.

As he lit a cigarette, Milo Roland peeked out from his room.

"Mr. Roscente..." The teenager hesitated. "Can we talk?"

Ethan exhaled a smoke ring. "Come here."

Milo adjusted his collar and approached.

"There's a class gathering this Saturday. Ryan Watson and I are both going." Milo rubbed his hands together. "I'm worried about Jenna working the stall alone—"

"I'll go." Ethan stubbed out the cigarette. "And call me brother-in-law from now on."

Milo's eyes widened.

He knew exactly what that title meant.

"Brother-in-law." The boy's voice was clear.

"Did she get hit?" Ethan asked abruptly.

Milo nodded. "A slap."

Ethan's gaze turned icy. Milo wisely retreated to his room.

Jenna emerged drying her hair, frowning at the cigarette butt in the ashtray. "Post-sex smoke? How indulgent."

"You know a lot." Ethan pulled her into his arms.

"Let go!" Jenna struggled free and hurried into the bedroom, her face flushing when she saw the sheets.

She turned and shoved Ethan. "Out. I need to change these."
###Chapter 406

Ethan Roscente stood at the bedroom doorway, his gaze fixed on the glaring red stain on the sheets. His Adam's apple bobbed, dark currents swirling in his eyes.

Jenna Roland frantically tugged at the blanket to cover it.

"Don't move." He strode forward, grasping her slender wrist. "I'll handle it."

The tips of Jenna's ears burned as her fingers unconsciously twisted the hem of her nightgown.

Ethan deftly stripped the bloodied sheets, his movements gentle as though handling something precious. He turned to retrieve fresh linens from the closet, fingertips brushing over the crisp cotton fabric.

"I can do it myself..." Jenna reached out.

"Stay put." His tone brooked no argument, yet his hands remained tender.

After replacing the sheets, Ethan leaned down to tuck the blanket around her. Moonlight filtered through the sheer curtains, casting delicate patterns across her face.

"Ethan..." Her voice was barely a whisper.

He suddenly bent closer, his lips grazing her burning earlobe. "Thank you for becoming mine."

Jenna burrowed deeper under the covers, only her flushed cheeks visible.

"If you dare betray me..." She glared fiercely, though her eyes shimmered with unshed tears.

Ethan chuckled, pulling her—blanket and all—into his arms. "As you command, Mrs. Roscente."

Three days later, at a night market stall.

Ryan Watson's forehead bandage had been removed, leaving only a faint scar. He stood awkwardly beside Milo Roland, nervously twisting the hem of his shirt.

"Sis." Milo yanked Ryan forward. "This idiot insisted on helping out before finishing his meds."

Jenna handed over a thermos. "Take your medicine first."

Ryan cradled the cup, steam fogging his glasses. He suddenly looked up. "Will those people...come back?"

"Who cares!" Milo punched his shoulder. "Brother-in-law's coming tomorrow. Let's see who dares cause trouble!"

Jenna's hand jerked, nearly knocking over the sugar jar. Ever since that night, the title "brother-in-law" sent her pulse racing.

"Leo Lombardi got fifteen days in detention." She changed the subject. "Next time they cause trouble, we'll call the police directly."

Ryan nodded, but his eyes darkened behind his glasses.

Top floor of HM Group headquarters, Ethan shattered his third coffee cup.

"Mr. Roscente?" Assistant Lucas peeked through the door.

Ethan grabbed his suit jacket, frost crystallizing in his gaze. "Get the car ready."

The hallway lights elongated his cold, imposing silhouette, the temperature plunging in his wake. Lucas shrank back, not daring to ask another question.
###Chapter 407

The derelict chemical plant on the outskirts of Los Angeles stood silent, its crumbling walls veined with moss. Faint light seeped through shattered windows, painting the concrete floor in jagged stripes.

A thick layer of dust coated the ground. In the corner, a man writhed inside a burlap sack. His Armani suit was soiled, nylon ropes biting into his wrists. The once-glossy leather shoes had dulled to a lifeless sheen.

Four black-clad bodyguards stood like statues, the air thick with tension.

The iron door screeched open.

Ethan Roscente stepped inside, his Oxford shoes gleaming. The black dress shirt clung to his broad shoulders and tapered waist. Platinum cufflinks caught the dim light, mirroring the ice in his gaze.

"Mr. Roscente." The bodyguards bowed in unison.

He stopped before Howard Wen. Slowly, he peeled off his gloves. The sack was yanked away, revealing Howard's ashen face.

"Wake him."

Ice water cascaded over Howard's head. He gasped awake, coughing violently—only to meet Ethan's abyssal stare. His entire body trembled, dark stains spreading down his trousers.

"You promised to spare me!"

Ethan's lips curved. The cigar between his fingers glowed crimson. "I did." Smoke curled around his sharp jawline. "But I never said there wouldn't be consequences."

Howard's pupils contracted.

The first punch landed with a sickening crack. His scream echoed through the empty factory, sending crows scattering from the windows.

"Do you know what Jenna Roland's virginity was worth?" Ethan ground his heel into Howard's twisted fingers. Bones crunched. "Ten of your family fortunes couldn't cover it."

Howard spat blood, begging through split lips. His swollen eyelids fluttered as Ethan accepted a baseball bat from a bodyguard.

The last thing he saw was cold metal flashing in the dim light.
###Chapter 408

"Mr. Roscente, I swear I've learned my lesson!" Howard Ho sobbed uncontrollably, his voice trembling. "I'll stay far away from Miss Roland from now on!"

Ethan Roscente looked down at him with icy disdain.

"Did you buy Jenna from Victor Roland?"

Howard froze for a second before nodding frantically like a dog. "Yes! But later I had Victor and his men tied up and beaten!"

The ember of Ethan's cigarette glowed faintly in the dim light.

"Here's your chance at redemption." He exhaled a slow stream of smoke. "Get Victor's orchard transferred to Jenna."

Howard shuddered violently.

"Can you do it?" Ethan's voice was feather-light yet suffocating.

"Yes!" Howard answered without hesitation.

Ethan crushed the cigarette, sparks flying.

"Succeed, and all is forgiven." He turned to leave. "Fail, and you're a dead man."

Howard collapsed to the ground, only daring to breathe after Ethan disappeared from view.

He glared viciously at Xavier Valdemar. "Untie me now, you idiot!"

Xavier clenched his fists, but remembering Howard's brother was the deputy mayor, swallowed his anger.

Once freed, Howard groaned in pain. He pulled out his phone and dialed.

"Brother! Ethan Roscente's men kidnapped me!" he wailed. "Send help immediately!"

His brother, Howard Ho Sr., sounded shocked on the other end.

After hearing the details, Howard Sr. let out a long exhale.

"Do as he says." His voice was grim. "Send your location. I'm dispatching a team now."

......

Seven days later.

Jenna Roland was busy at her street stall when her phone rang.

"Jenna! You scheming bitch!" Victor's voice exploded through the receiver. "Did you send someone to sabotage my orchard?"

Jenna's grip tightened until her knuckles turned white.

"Bad reception at the crematorium?" she sneered. "Got a new number?"

"That orchard is mine!" Victor shrieked hysterically. "You'll never take it!"

Jenna's eyes narrowed.

Something happened to the orchard?

"It belonged to my father first." She enunciated each word. "A thief like you doesn't deserve to call anything 'mine'."

"It's under my name now!" Victor roared. "No matter who you send, I'll die before handing it over!"
###Chapter 409

Jenna Roland's knuckles turned white as she gripped her phone. Victor Roland's curses screeched through the receiver.

"That orchard was never meant to be yours!"

"You bitch! Your whole family should die!"

Jenna smirked. "I'll return those words to you. Victor, you're the one who deserves an early grave."

She ended the call with a sharp swipe of her finger.

Milo Roland looked up from his phone. "What's Victor ranting about now?"

"Trouble at the orchard." Jenna tossed her phone onto the market stall. "He thinks I'm behind it."

Ryan Watson leaned closer. "What kind of trouble?"

Jenna checked the time. Lunch hour approached. She stood. "Hungry? I'll grab us some food."

Ryan's eyes lit up. "Starving." He scratched his head sheepishly. "Only had water this morning."

Jenna understood. Since his parents' divorce, the boy often skipped breakfast.

"Wait here." She grabbed her wallet and left.

The aroma of cooked food wafted from nearby restaurants. Jenna ordered three dishes and soup, paid, and returned.

Soon, steaming containers arrived. Jenna unfolded a new collapsible table and waved the boys over.

"Tanya, join us?" She called to the neighboring stall.

Tanya Hill shook her head. "You go ahead."

Jenna picked up her chopsticks when her phone rang again. Ethan Roscente's name flashed on screen. Her lips curved unconsciously.

"Eating now," she said brightly. "You?"

Ethan's deep voice rumbled through the line. "Was hoping to take you to lunch."

"Next time." She speared a piece of braised pork. "I'll cook for you tonight."

"Don't just make my favorites." He paused. "Cook something you like too."

After hanging up, Jenna took two bites before another unknown number called.

She frowned at the screen. Not Victor. Who then?

"Hello, who's this?"
###Chapter 410

"Miss Roland, this is Howard Wen." The voice on the phone was both familiar and strange.

Jenna's fingers tightened instantly, her nails digging into her palms. She'd recognize that voice anywhere—even in death.

"You dare call me?" Her tone could freeze hell.

"Please don't be angry." Howard's voice oozed appeasement. "I've reclaimed your parents' orchard from your uncle. When would be convenient to transfer the deed?"

Jenna froze.

"What did you say?" She couldn't believe her ears.

"I knew your uncle seized the property, so I retrieved it for you." Howard explained. "Consider it... an apology for past wrongs."

A cold laugh escaped her. "Since when did you grow a conscience?"

"I genuinely want to make amends." Sincerity dripped from his words. "Three o'clock this afternoon at the Land Resources Bureau?"

"Fine." She hung up without ceremony.

Turning to Milo, her eyes blazed with intensity. "We're getting the orchard back!"

"Who helped?" Milo frowned.

"An... acquaintance." She evaded. "We're finalizing the paperwork this afternoon."

As Milo opened his mouth to press further, Jenna was already mapping out plans. "Once we have the orchard, I'm quitting the clothing business!"

"What about all this inventory?" He gestured at the mountain of garments.

"Sell what we can." Her smile reached her eyes. "I'll wear the rest myself!"

She discreetly texted Ethan. Joy aside, she hadn't forgotten Howard's true nature.

Ethan replied instantly: 【I'll go with you.】

At 2:30 PM, Jenna arrived early outside the government building. The early spring wind carried a chill, yet her skin burned with anticipation.

"Waiting long?" Ethan's voice brushed her ear.

Before she could turn, strong arms pulled her into a warm embrace. His lips grazed the corner of her mouth.

"People are watching!" Flustered, she pushed him away, cheeks flaming.

Ethan chuckled, tightening his grip on her shoulder. "Let them."

Sheltered against his chest, her heartbeat thundered. Eyes fixed on the intersection, she awaited the man who held her future in his hands—equal parts hope and trepidation coursing through her veins.
###Chapter 411 

Jenna Roland had always prided herself on being fearless. But today, under the watchful eyes of the crowd, Ethan Roscente kissed her until her cheeks burned crimson.

"Have you lost your mind?" she hissed through gritted teeth, fingers clutching the hem of her blouse.

Ethan chuckled, his warm breath brushing her earlobe. "What's wrong? Feeling shy?"

"There are people everywhere!" Jenna glared at him, the tips of her ears turning scarlet.

"Alright, alright. I'll be more careful next time." He pinched her cheek affectionately.

Before Jenna could retort, a black Audi pulled up beside them.

Wilson Parvis stepped out, his smile freezing when he spotted Ethan.

He swallowed hard and forced himself forward. "Miss Roland, Mr. Roscente. Sorry to keep you waiting."

Jenna noticed the bruise on his face and raised an eyebrow. "What happened to you?"

"Just... tripped and fell." Wilson stole a nervous glance at Ethan, beads of sweat forming on his forehead.

Jenna nodded thoughtfully. "Let's go get the paperwork done."

Wilson trailed behind them like a frightened mouse, not daring to lift his head the entire time.

The process went smoothly. Outside the Land Resources Bureau, Jenna turned to Wilson. "Thanks for handling the orchard matter."

"My pleasure, truly." He waved his hands frantically.

Jenna's expression darkened. "But if I hear you're harassing women again—"

"I swear I won't!" Wilson backed away, hands raised in surrender.

As he scurried off, Jenna finally smiled. "My parents' orchard is finally back where it belongs."

Ethan watched her joyful expression with amusement. "What's next?"

"First, I'll clear out the remaining stock at the boutique. Then I'll visit the orchard." She rubbed her hands together. "This time, I'm keeping it safe."

"Call me if you need anything." He ruffled her hair. "Come on, I'll drive you home."

A mischievous glint appeared in Jenna's eyes. "What do you think about getting guard dogs for the orchard?"

Ethan laughed. "Whatever makes you happy."

Their shadows stretched long in the sunset. Jenna secretly slipped her hand into Ethan's, her heart full of contentment.
###Chapter 412

Jenna pointed at the white minivan parked by the roadside. "I drove here myself. Come home early this afternoon. I'll cook something delicious for you."

"Alright." Ethan's lips curved slightly, his deep eyes shimmering with warmth. His striking features glowed under the sunlight, drawing admiring glances from passersby.

Jenna's heart swelled with pride. A husband this handsome must have countless admirers. But she wasn't lacking either—she matched him perfectly.

"I'll head out now."

"Drive safely."

She slid into the driver's seat and fastened her seatbelt. Through the rearview mirror, she saw Ethan standing motionless, watching her leave. His tall figure only disappeared from view when her car turned the corner.

Ethan's smile faded as his usual composed demeanor returned. He drove straight to the office.

...

At 5 p.m., Jenna closed her stall early. Passing by the market, she invited Milo and Ryan to join her grocery shopping.

Their cart overflowed with ingredients—spare ribs for Ethan, braised fish for Milo, spicy chicken for Ryan. Only her own favorite dish was missing.

Back at Beverly Hills, the trio immediately got to work in the kitchen. Milo washed vegetables, Ryan prepped ingredients, while Jenna took charge of cooking. The sizzling wok filled the air with mouthwatering aromas.

Ethan arrived home promptly at six. Shrugging off his suit jacket and rolling up his sleeves, he helped arrange the dishes.

By 6:30, eight exquisite dishes covered the dining table. Milo and Ryan served rice, ushering everyone to their seats.

"Sis, why don't you head to the orchard tomorrow? We'll handle the clothing stall," Ryan suggested between bites.

"You two selling women's clothing?" Jenna paused her chopsticks, eyes twinkling.

"It's not lingerie." Ryan grinned. "Don't worry, we've got this."

Jenna burst out laughing. "Fine. Starting tomorrow, I'll deliver the goods and go straight to the orchard."

After dinner, when Jenna moved to clear the table, Ethan stopped her. "You've worked hard enough cooking." He glanced meaningfully at Milo.

Taking the hint, Milo practically pushed Jenna out of the kitchen before dragging Ryan in to wash dishes.

"Impressive!" Jenna gave Ethan a thumbs-up.

Amusement danced in Ethan's eyes as he guided her to the sofa. "Hire some help at the orchard. I don't like you working there alone."

The evening news played softly on TV. Jenna turned down the volume. "It's too early to hire workers when we're not making profits yet."
###Chapter 413

Ethan gripped Jenna's hand tightly, his brow furrowed. "Your uncle's family is trouble. Guard dogs won't cut it. I'll hire professional bodyguards—ex-military. They could handle Victor Roland's goons or even a whole gang without breaking a sweat."

Jenna fell silent.

Dogs could deter thieves, but if the Rolands came armed, a few canines would be useless.

Sometimes, the only language people like Victor understood was brute force.

"How much would bodyguards cost per month?"

"Friendship discount—two grand each."

"That cheap?" Jenna's eyes widened in disbelief.

Even food delivery drivers earned more than that, let alone skilled security personnel.

"They're not in it for the money. Just want something to do."

"But that's ridiculously low!"

"Leave it to me." Ethan pinched her cheek. "I'll cover their salaries."

"No!" She swatted his hand away. "I can't let you pay my employees!"

"I'm your husband."

"Still no!"

She refused to take advantage of him, especially when it involved multiple salaries.

"My monthly salary is fifty grand. This is nothing." He lowered his voice. "Keep arguing, and you won't sleep tonight."

"..."

Jenna's ears burned. "Are you threatening me?"

Ethan leaned in, his breath hot against her neck. "What do you think?"

She pushed him away in a fluster. "Milo and Ryan are right here!"

"So? Yes or no?"

Always cornered by him, Jenna stomped her foot. "Fine! Have it your way!"

Why was he so eager to throw money around?

Still, she tucked this gesture of care deep into her heart.

......

At dawn the next day, Jenna took Milo and Ryan to set up their street stall.

After settling them in, she drove alone to the orchard.

At the foot of the hill, she found the iron gate secured with a new lock.

Without a key, she simply picked up a rock and smashed it open.

Inside, the orchard sprawled before her—rows upon rows of fruit trees.

Apples, oranges, and pomegranates weighed down the branches, their bounty bending the limbs low.
###Chapter 414

The orchard gleamed with meticulous care under Victor Roland's stewardship. Each tree stood nourished by rich fertilizer, every inch of soil bearing witness to devoted cultivation.

Jenna Roland paused at the orchard's entrance, a cold smirk playing on her lips. Victor's prized orchard now belonged to her. She could almost picture him fuming with rage.

Villagers soon arrived for their daily work, confused by the locked gates they'd encountered earlier.

"Jenna, why was the orchard locked this morning?" An elderly woman with silver-streaked hair spoke first.

Jenna surveyed the crowd, her voice clear. "From today onward, I'm the owner of this orchard. Those who wish to stay are welcome. Those who leave won't be stopped."

A wave of murmurs erupted.

"This orchard was my parents' legacy. Victor stole it for years. Now justice is served." Jenna's tone left no room for debate.

Chester Kalmien stepped forward. "I've worked here since your parents' time. This orchard means everything to me. I'll stay if you'll have me."

"Taking back what's rightfully yours is only fair!" Fiona Garten declared, thumping her chest.

Darren Savigny raised his hand. "Count me in too."

To Jenna's surprise, every worker chose to remain. She immediately raised their daily wages from $100 to $150, sparking cheers.

"What needs doing today?" Jenna asked.

"Four western plots need weeding, and rotten fruit must be collected for compost," Darren replied.

Jenna nodded. "Get to work then." As the group dispersed, she trailed her fingers along the gnarled tree trunks during her solitary inspection.

Her phone rang. Ethan Roscente's name flashed on screen.

"I've arranged the men. Send the address." His baritone voice crackled through the receiver.

Within an hour of sharing her location, four broad-shouldered men in black shirts appeared at the orchard gates.

"Ethan sent you?" Jenna appraised them.

Vincent Roland, their leader, nodded. "You must be Ms. Roland."

"Did Ethan explain your pay and meals?"

"$2000 monthly, but you cover our food." In truth, they were Ethan's personal security, acting under orders.

"Agreed. I'll deliver meals daily," Jenna said briskly.

"And our duties?" Vincent inquired.

"Remove trespassers immediately. Not a single branch gets damaged." Her gaze hardened. "Night shifts required."

"We've brought gear for 24/7 rotations," Vincent assured.

Jenna checked her watch. "Start today. Exchange numbers for emergencies."

After swapping contacts, Jenna strode homeward, her silhouette cutting a defiant figure against the afternoon sun.
###Chapter 415

Jenna Roland carried a woven basket into the bustling farmers' market, expertly selecting fresh ingredients.

As she picked vegetables, she texted Ethan Roscente: "Coming home for lunch?"

His reply came quickly: "Client meeting. Eat without me."

A faint smile curved her lips as she read the message. She bought just enough for herself and smoothly checked out.

The aroma of cooking soon filled her kitchen. Four dishes and a soup were arranged on the dining table. Jenna savored her meal unhurriedly.

She pulled out newly purchased plastic containers, efficiently portioning the leftovers. These disposable utensils were specifically bought for meal deliveries.

"Sis, business was crazy today!" Milo Roland accepted the thermal lunchbox, face glowing with pride.

Jenna arched an eyebrow. "How much?"

"Over six hundred!" He flashed a thumbs-up. "Impressive, right?"

"Not bad." She pinched his cheek affectionately. "Eat up. I need to make a delivery."

Milo leaned in curiously. "Taking lunch to Ethan?"

"No." She shook her head. "The new security guards at the orchard. I promised them meals."

Grabbing the takeout bags, she turned to leave. Milo's voice followed her: "Be careful out there!"

Her car had just left the city limits when Vincent Roland called: "Miss Jenna, Victor Roland brought people here."

Her eyes turned icy. "Just as expected."

She pressed the accelerator, the vehicle speeding down the country road. In the distance, two groups faced off on the hillside.

Vincent gripped something in his hand that made the opposing group hesitate.

"Victor Roland!" Jenna strode forward, voice frosty. "This orchard belongs to me now. Dare to cause trouble again?"

Victor's face darkened with rage. Since losing the orchard to Ethan's schemes, sleepless nights had left him gaunt and haggard.

He hadn't wanted to come today, but the memory of being outmaneuvered ignited his fury, compelling him to drag relatives along for confrontation.
###Chapter 416

Victor Roland stood at the orchard gate, his face dark with rage. His burning glare locked onto Jenna Roland, fury radiating from his entire being.

"How did this orchard end up in your hands when it was clearly taken by Ethan Roscente?" he demanded through gritted teeth.

Jenna smirked dismissively, handing her lunchbox to her bodyguard Zachary Macmillan.

"Victor Roland, you dare ask me that?" Her voice was ice. "This was my parents' legacy. You stole it for years, and now it's rightfully returned. What gives you the right to question me?"

Veins bulged on Victor's forehead. His fists clenched until his knuckles cracked.

"Bullshit!" he roared. "You conspired with Ethan Roscente to scheme against me!"

Jason Roland and Sean Roland immediately chimed in.
