The door opened again as Stella entered with aromatic paper bags. Spicy broth, fried chicken wings, and boba tea covered the coffee table, the scent of chili oil permeating the room.

"Dig in!" Jenna reached eagerly.
###Chapter 489

Stella's snacks covered every inch of the hospital coffee table. Jenna couldn't resist indulging, devouring most of them until her stomach bulged uncomfortably.

She reluctantly set down the last bite, leaving several untouched treats. Stella turned to Blanche and Grace, offering them the leftovers.

All three declined with polite gestures.

Unable to bear wasting food, Stella settled in to finish them herself.

Jenna shifted restlessly, too full to sit or lie down. She paced the room with Ethan hovering protectively beside her—one hand steadying her lower back, the other cradling her swollen belly.

Five grueling hours passed before her cervix dilated to four centimeters.

The epidural brought sweet relief. Jenna resumed her slow walks down the hallway, now only wincing slightly during contractions.

Another eight hours crawled by. Seven centimeters.

Frustration gnawed at Jenna. The doctor had estimated an eight-to-nine-hour labor. Why was this taking so much longer?

"Wasn't the epidural supposed to eliminate the pain?" she gritted out between breaths.

Three excruciating hours later—nine centimeters. Her water broke in a sudden gush, and nurses rushed her to delivery.

Outside, Ethan wore a path in the floor. Blanche and Harrison fidgeted in their seats. Milo, who'd arrived that evening, stood sentry by the doors.

One hour later, a nurse emerged with a swaddled bundle.

"Congratulations, Mr. Roscente. A healthy baby boy."

"Really?" Blanche's voice quivered with emotion.

Harrison's eyes glistened. "Our family line continues!"

Milo pumped his fist. "I'm an uncle!"

Ethan barely glanced at the infant. "How's my wife?"

"Second-degree tearing. The doctor's suturing now. She's exhausted—we'll take her straight to recovery."

Grace pressed a hand to her chest. "How severe is the tear?"

"The baby's head circumference was above average," the nurse explained gently.

Tears spilled down Grace's cheeks.

"We need to run newborn screenings. Which family members will accompany us?"

Grace and Benjamin followed immediately.

Ethan, Stella, Milo and Blanche remained outside.

When Jenna was wheeled out thirty minutes later, she looked ghostly pale—drenched in sweat, too spent to speak.

Ethan cradled her icy hand, his own eyes suspiciously bright. "Rest now, love. You were incredible."

Jenna managed a faint nod before surrendering to oblivion.

After settling her, the nurse reviewed post-delivery instructions and departed.

Blanche produced bottles and formula. "The little one will be hungry soon."

Stella blinked. "No breastfeeding?"

Blanche cast a protective glance at Jenna's unconscious form. "Formula. Let her body heal first."

Watching the Roscentes fuss over their new arrival, Stella felt an unexpected pang. Jenna had everything—a doting husband, devoted in-laws, now a male heir to secure her position.

Her future couldn't be brighter.
###Chapter 490 

Ethan took out the formula and baby bottle from his bag. The bottle had been sterilized at home, and the water in the thermos was at the perfect temperature, ready to prepare the baby's meal.

He turned to look at Jenna on the hospital bed. She was fast asleep, exhausted from the physical toll of childbirth, finally able to rest properly.

Half an hour later, Grace returned to the room with the crying baby and Benjamin. Worried the noise would wake Jenna, Ethan gestured for them to step outside. He quickly prepared the formula and handed the bottle to Grace.

"The little one is starving," Grace murmured soothingly, carefully guiding the nipple to the baby's mouth.

Grandma Blanche leaned in, her eyes filled with tenderness. "Look how eagerly he's drinking. All that crying earlier—he was just hungry."

Benjamin chuckled and asked Grandpa Harrison, "Dad, who do you think he takes after?"

"He looks just like Ethan," Grandpa Harrison observed, studying his grandson. "The shape of his head is identical to Ethan's when he was a baby."

Ethan frowned. "My head was that big?"

Grandma Blanche immediately chimed in, "You were always our big-headed boy."

Skeptical, Ethan turned to Milo. "Be honest."

Milo awkwardly rubbed his nose. "Well... it was kind of large."

What truly left Ethan speechless was when Grace nodded in agreement. "The doctor said Jenna's severe perineal tearing was because the baby's head circumference exceeded the norm. The genetics are undeniable."

Even his own mother had to say it—Ethan was utterly defeated.

The baby soon fell asleep in Grace's arms, but most of the formula remained in the bottle. A nurse came in to check and reminded them, "A newborn's stomach is very small. Thirty milliliters per feeding is enough."

Ethan realized he'd prepared too much. He'd been worried the baby would go hungry, but he might have overburdened him instead.

The nurse moved to Jenna's bedside. "We need to massage the uterus to help expel the lochia."

Stella hesitated. "But she just fell asleep..."

"This is essential postpartum care," the nurse said, pulling back the blanket and applying firm pressure to Jenna's abdomen.

The sudden, sharp pain jolted Jenna awake. The combination of uterine contractions and external pressure made her break out in a cold sweat.

"Why does it still hurt after giving birth?" Jenna asked weakly.

The nurse continued her work as she explained, "The uterus needs to shrink back to its original size. This is normal."

Jenna finally understood—the pain of childbirth wasn't over yet. After the nurse left, she said to Stella, who was staying overnight, "You should get some rest. Grandma and the others can take care of things here."

Stella shook her head. "I'll just nap on the empty bed next door. You're the one who needs proper rest right now."

Grateful, Jenna nodded and closed her eyes again. The room finally settled into quiet, the only sound the steady beeping of the monitor.
###Chapter 491

Morning sunlight streamed through the gap in the hospital room curtains.

Grandma Blanche and Grandpa Harrison Roscente had stayed up all night and were finally persuaded by Grace and Benjamin Roscente to go home and rest.

Milo Roland rushed in with his backpack to say goodbye, not wanting to be late for his 8 AM class.

Stella Laurent returned from the water dispenser with a basin of warm water, wringing out a towel to gently clean Jenna Roland's face.

Ethan Roscente carefully prepared formula, feeding their newborn with practiced ease.

"Stella, your nursing skills put the professionals to shame," Jenna teased, her complexion much healthier than the night before.

Stella rolled her eyes as she wiped Jenna's fingers. "Only for you. No amount of money could make me do this for anyone else."

"Why are you so good to me?" Jenna tilted her head curiously.

"The paycheck helps," Stella admitted, pausing. "But mostly because without you, my sister and I would've died at Yvonne Valois' hands."

She hadn't even gone home, staying solely to care for Jenna.

"Ethan deserves most of the credit for that," Jenna said, glancing at her husband.

Stella chuckled, wringing the towel again. "Without his beloved wife involved, do you think the mighty Mr. Roscente would've lifted a finger?"

"Don't feel obligated," Jenna murmured.

Stella picked up the basin. "Enough talk. I'll get fresh water."

Once the door closed, Jenna turned to Ethan. "Have you decided on a name?"

"You choose." He didn't look up from the baby.

"I'm not exactly literary," Jenna demurred. "How about Shawn? For a bright future."

Ethan raised an eyebrow. "No culture, huh? That's actually quite good."

"Uneducated doesn't mean illiterate!" Jenna glared.

"Then what about Shawn Roscente?" Ethan suggested. "More complete symbolism."

Jenna's eyes lit up. "The extra syllable does sound better."

"Done." Ethan nodded. "But we should still consult our parents."

"They'll agree with whatever you say," Jenna laughed.

The door swung open. Sophie Roscente entered with Vanessa Galatea trailing behind.

Ethan's expression darkened instantly. "Who invited her?"

Vanessa twisted her fingers nervously, addressing Jenna. "Ms. Roland, I came to apologize. I was wrong to sow discord between you two."

"Actually, I should thank you." Jenna's smile didn't reach her eyes. "Otherwise, I wouldn't have learned about Yvonne Sherwood."

Vanessa bit her lip, turning to Ethan. "Ethan, I promise never to upset Ms. Roland again."
###Chapter 492

Sophie Roscente wore an ingratiating smile. "Sis, Ethan, don't blame Vanessa. She didn't mean it. Let me see my little nephew."

Ethan Roscente stood guard beside the bassinet, his wary gaze sweeping over Vanessa Galatea. Jenna Roland needed rest after childbirth—he wouldn't let petty disturbances trouble her.

"He just fell asleep. Keep your voice down," Ethan murmured in warning.

Sophie tiptoed to the bassinet and lifted a corner of the blanket. A pink, cherubic face greeted her. She clapped a hand over her mouth, eyes sparkling.

"Oh my God! He's absolutely precious!" Sophie bounced on her toes. "Ethan, look! He's blowing bubbles!"

Vanessa seized the moment to edge closer, her painted smile brittle. As the infant's features came into focus, her nails dug crescent moons into her palms.

This should have been her child. If not for Jenna's interference, she—Vanessa Galatea—would be standing beside Ethan now.

"You came together?" Jenna's weak voice floated from the hospital bed.

Sophie turned. "I ran into Vanessa at the entrance. Her grandfather's hospitalized here. Since we were heading the same way..."

Jenna gave a faint nod and asked no further.

"Ethan, have you named him yet?" Sophie whispered.

"Shawn Roscente." Ethan's tone was flat, but his eyes never left the bassinet.

"Beautiful name!" Sophie rubbed her hands. "Can I hold him?"

"No." The refusal was absolute.

Sophie pouted. "You're being ridiculous!"

Jenna chuckled. "Your brother barely dares to breathe when holding him. He stayed up all night watching over the baby. Newborns are fragile—he's just being cautious."

"Then...can I at least touch him?" Sophie wheedled.

With permission granted, she extended a single finger and brushed the infant's cheek.

"Wow! Like touching jelly!" Sophie's face flushed with delight.

Jenna's eyes crinkled. "Newborn skin is the softest."

Reluctantly withdrawing her hand, Sophie felt a sudden curiosity about motherhood—until the thought of labor pains made her reconsider instantly.

The door swung open as Stella Laurent entered with a water basin, eyeing the unfamiliar girls.

"This is Ethan's sister Sophie Roscente, and her friend Vanessa Galatea," Jenna introduced.

Stella nodded and went straight to the bedside. "The doctor said no greasy broth. Should I get pigeon soup instead?"

"Yes, please." Jenna smiled gratefully.
###Chapter 493

The fluorescent lights in the hospital corridor were harsh. Sophie Roscente gently pushed open the door to the VIP ward. Inside, Jenna Roland cradled the baby, humming a soft lullaby. The infant slept soundly, cheeks flushed pink.

"I should head home now, sis," Sophie whispered.

Jenna looked up with a tired smile. "Be careful on the road."

Outside the hospital, Sophie pulled out her phone and dialed Vanessa Galatea.

A red sports car soon pulled up at the entrance.

"Need a ride home?" Vanessa rolled down the window.

Sophie slid into the passenger seat. "Thanks."

As they merged onto the main road, Vanessa suddenly spoke. "You actually call her 'sister-in-law' now?"

Sophie's fingers paused on the seatbelt buckle. "She is my brother's wife."

"She's not good enough for Ethan." Vanessa's knuckles whitened around the steering wheel.

Sophie turned to face her. "Vanessa, my brother is happy. Jenna takes great care of the family. Even Grandpa Harrison and Grandma Blanche adore her."

"Such an act!" Vanessa slammed the brakes. "She's just a gold digger!"

Sophie frowned. "She didn't know about the Roscente family's status when they got married."

"What does that matter?" Vanessa sneered. "I've loved Ethan since we were kids. How dare she steal him from me?"

"You can't force feelings." Sophie sighed. "With your looks and background—"

"Help me." Vanessa cut her off. "Make them divorce."

Sophie's eyes widened. "Are you insane? They have a child together!"

Vanessa's expression darkened. "Fine. Forget I asked."

Without warning, she signaled and pulled over. "Change of plans. You'll need to find your own ride."

Sophie blinked. "But taxis never come to this area—"

"Not my problem." The door locks clicked open.

Sophie inhaled sharply and shoved the door open. Cold wind rushed in as she stepped onto the curb without looking back.

The sports car roared away, exhaust fumes hitting Sophie's face.

She took out her phone and blocked Vanessa's number across all platforms.

Three days later, the VIP ward was unusually quiet. Ethan had left to handle an urgent corporate project. Grandpa Harrison had spiked a fever, keeping Grandma Blanche at home. Grace and Benjamin Roscente were attending a relative's birthday celebration, leaving only Jenna and the baby.

When the nurse came for rounds, Jenna sat staring out the window. Sunlight filtered through the glass, casting fractured patterns across her pale face.
###Chapter 494

Sunlight filtered through the curtains as Stella Laurent tucked the blanket around the baby. She turned to Jenna Roland propped against the headboard. "I'll get lunch. What would you like?"

Jenna closed the parenting book in her hands. "Steamed turbot, stir-fried green beans, shredded pork with lettuce, and tomato egg soup." She paused. "Order something you like too."

"That restaurant's abalone soup is famous. I'll bring some back for you." Stella reached for her jacket.

"Alright." Jenna smiled in agreement.

Before leaving, Stella reminded her, "Call me immediately if you need anything."

As the door clicked shut, Jenna considered checking her phone but remembered Stella's warning. She picked up the book instead. Two pages in, the door burst open.

Vanessa Galatea stood silhouetted in black, locking the door behind her.

Jenna straightened instinctively. "Ms. Galatea?"

Vanessa's gaze fixed on the bassinet, her lips curling into a sneer. "The spitting image of Ethan." Her nails dug into her palms.

"Is that why you're here?" Jenna shielded the baby.

Vanessa's head snapped up, eyes glinting dangerously. "Ethan should've been mine! What right does a country bumpkin like you have to steal him?"

Jenna scoffed. "Love isn't about seniority. He never loved you."

"Shut up!" Vanessa shrieked. "I've known him twenty years! Who do you think you are?"

The baby stirred uneasily. Jenna kept her voice low. "Leave. You're frightening him."

"Leave?" Vanessa lunged at the bed. "How long do you think that pretty face will keep Ethan interested? When he tires of you, you won't even have a place to cry!"

Jenna met her gaze squarely. "Still better than you. At least he chose me once."

The words ignited Vanessa's fury. Madness flashed in her eyes. "Then I'll destroy you first!" Her hands slammed onto Jenna's freshly stitched wound.

White-hot pain blinded Jenna as sweat drenched her hospital gown. She clawed at Vanessa's wrists. "Get off! Help—"
###Chapter 495

Jenna Roland's abdomen erupted in searing pain, as if thousands of steel needles were twisting inside her.

She dug her nails into Vanessa Galatea's wrist with bone-crushing force.

Vanessa cried out and violently shook her off.

Four deep gashes oozed blood on the pale skin, the flesh grotesquely torn.

"You bitch!" Vanessa's eyes flashed with venom before her palm cracked across Jenna's face.

Jenna's cheek bloomed crimson, a trickle of blood escaping her split lip.

As Vanessa turned to leave, her gaze caught on the scarlet stain spreading across the white hospital sheets.

Her pupils contracted in panic before she fled the room.

......

Stella Laurent pushed open the hospital door, takeout bag in hand. The metallic tang of blood assaulted her senses.

The bed stood empty, its sheets drenched in shocking red.

The food container hit the floor with a splatter of spilled broth.

Staggering to the nurses' station, her voice trembled. "Where's Jenna? What happened?"

A nurse looked up urgently. "She hemorrhaged suddenly. They're operating on the third floor!"

Stella's knees buckled.

Fumbling for her phone, she dialed Ethan Roscente.

"Mr. Roscente... Jenna's hemorrhaging—"

A deafening crash came through the receiver.

Ethan overturned his coffee cup as he bolted from the conference table, dark liquid ruining documents.

He ran four red lights, tires screeching against asphalt.

His pounding footsteps echoed through hospital stairwells.

When he reached the OR doors, his dress shirt clung to him, soaked with sweat.

"What happened?" He gripped Stella's shoulders. "She was fine this morning!"

Stella shook her head, tears hitting the linoleum. "I only left to get food..."

Ethan staggered back, slamming against the wall.

The glowing surgery sign burned his retinas.

He remembered Jenna's pallid face, her weak request for wonton soup.

Now that soup lay abandoned on the hospital floor.
###Chapter 496

Ethan Roscente clutched his head, knuckles turning white.

His bloodshot eyes remained fixed on the glowing red light above the operating room.

"Jenna will be fine..." His whisper was hoarse, barely audible.

The operating room doors swung open abruptly.

A masked doctor strode out. "Family of Jenna Roland?"

Ethan shot to his feet and rushed forward. "I'm her husband. How is she?"

The doctor removed his mask, expression grave. "She's suffering from postpartum hemorrhage. We need Type B blood immediately, but our blood bank is running low. Is anyone here Type B?"

Ethan's face drained of color.

"I'm not..." His voice shook. "Can you transfer blood from another hospital?"

The doctor shook his head. "There's no time."

Stella Laurent wrung her hands. "I'm not Type B either!"

Then a familiar voice cut through the tension.

"What happened to Jenna?"

Lucien Valois approached swiftly, his suit jacket draped over one arm, forehead glistening with sweat.

Ethan's gaze turned icy as he blocked his path. "What are you doing here?"

Stella quickly intervened. "Mr. Valois, Jenna's hemorrhaging after childbirth. She needs Type B blood!"

Without hesitation, Lucien rolled up his sleeve. "I'm Type B. Take mine."

Ethan grabbed his collar. "Don't think this will—"

"Enough!" Lucien shoved him away. "Saving her comes first!"

The doctor made a swift decision. "Follow me."

Lucien hastily handed his documents and phone to Stella before following the doctor into the operating room.

The sharp scent of antiseptic assaulted his senses.

A nurse handed him sterile scrubs. "Change into these first."

Fumbling with the garments, Lucien shuddered as the cold alcohol swab touched his skin.

When the final door opened, the sight on the operating table froze his blood.

Jenna lay motionless, her face paper-white. The sheets beneath her were soaked crimson.

His legs nearly gave out.

"Will she..." Lucien's voice trembled. "...make it?"

A gurney was wheeled over. "We need that transfusion now!"

As the needle pierced his vein, Lucien stared fixedly at the ceiling.

"Take more," he rasped. "However much you need."

The nurse frowned. "Regulations limit donations to 400 milliliters."

"That won't be enough!" He tried to sit up.

"Don't worry," she pressed him back down. "Additional blood is en route from other hospitals."

Only then did Lucien relax against the bed, closing his eyes.

He remembered coming only to collect his medical report, only to encounter a frantic Ethan in the hallway.

How cruelly ironic fate could be.
###Chapter 497

The operating room lights glared harshly in the sterile hallway. Stella Laurent's fingers trembled as they clutched the hem of her blouse.

Tears slid silently down her cheeks while she stared at the closed doors.

If anything happened to Jenna Roland, she would never forgive herself.

The sudden ringtone made her jump. The caller ID showed "Dad."

"Uncle Vincent, this is Stella..."

Lucien Valois's urgent voice came through the line. "Lucien, we found your sister!"

She ended the call abruptly after a few vague responses, afraid to say too much.

Her gaze flickered toward Ethan Roscente.

The man stood motionless before the operating room doors, his tall frame rigid as a statue.

Thirty minutes later, a nurse rushed past with blood bags.

Lucien emerged, his face ashen and steps unsteady.

"Mr. Valois!" Stella hurried to support him.

Ethan turned, his dark eyes locking onto his rival with unreadable intensity.

"Thank you." His voice was gravelly.

Lucien gave a weak smirk. "Don't mention it. I saved her because I love her."

Their gazes clashed like drawn swords.

"She's my wife." Ethan's pupils darkened.

Leaning against the bench, Lucien laughed bitterly. "So what?"

He stared at the ceiling, his Adam's apple bobbing.

"I know I don't deserve her." The whisper barely reached their ears.

The corridor plunged into tomblike silence.

Only the crimson glow above the operating doors continued its wordless pulse.
###Chapter 498

"She will never be yours." Ethan Roscente's gaze was razor-sharp, his entire being radiating an aura of unyielding dominance.

Lucien Valois let out a bitter laugh. "I know I'm not worthy of her. Ethan, I love Jenna Roland deeply. If you ever dare to hurt her, I'll stake my life to make you pay."

"My woman is none of your concern," Ethan replied coldly.

Stella Laurent intervened tactfully. "Mr. Valois, your father is on the phone. He says it's urgent."

Lucien shot Ethan one last resentful glare before answering. "Dad, what is it?"

"Who was that Stella woman just now?" Vincent Valois demanded, his tone sharp.

"Jenna's friend," Lucien murmured, lowering his voice. "Ethan is here too. I just came to donate blood."

Vincent's anger subsided slightly. "Go to Boys Town orphanage. Secretary Zhang found a lead about your sister."

"Understood."

"And remember—stay away from Jenna!"

Ethan massaged his temples irritably. "Got it."

After hanging up, Lucien turned to Ethan. "Don't tell Jenna I was the blood donor."

"Why?" Ethan frowned.

"She hates me. Knowing the truth would only upset her." Lucien's smile was pained. "I don't want to add to her burdens."

Ethan fell silent for a moment before striding toward the operating room.

Three hours later, the surgical lights finally dimmed.

"The patient is out of danger," the doctor announced, wheeling out the hospital bed. "She'll need two days in the ICU for observation."

Ethan exhaled deeply, the tension in his body finally easing.

Suddenly, his expression darkened. "Where's the baby?"

Stella gasped, realizing they'd forgotten about the newborn. She rushed back to the ward in panic.

The empty bassinet made her legs buckle.

"Over here," a nurse said, appearing with the bottle-fed infant. "I brought him over since no one was attending to him."

Stella nearly burst into tears. "Thank you so much!"

Her hands trembled as she updated Ethan, then carefully cradled the contented baby.
###Chapter 499

Ethan Roscente hadn't slept for two full days outside the ICU. He couldn't bring himself to tell Grandma Blanche the truth, insisting over the phone that Jenna Roland was recovering well.

When Jenna was wheeled out of intensive care, she looked gaunt, her face as pale as parchment. Weakly lying on the hospital bed, she felt Ethan immediately grasp her hand, pressing a trembling kiss to her knuckles.

"Darling..." His voice cracked, eyes bloodshot. "If anything happened to you, I wouldn't want to live either."

Jenna forced a weak smile, her voice hoarse. "Our parents are watching over me from heaven. How's the baby?"

She should've been discharged long ago, but nearly died from postpartum hemorrhage. The memory of Vanessa Galatea's twisted face flashed in her mind, igniting fury in Jenna's eyes.

"It was Vanessa." She gritted her teeth. "When Stella went to get food, she barged in and pressed down on my stomach—"

Ethan's pupils constricted, a murderous aura radiating from him. He suppressed his rage, not wanting to frighten their child.

Stella gasped, covering her mouth. "It was her?!"

"I truly thought..." Jenna's tears spilled over. "I'd never see any of you again."

"Don't be afraid." Stella clasped her icy hand. "Once you recover, we'll make her pay!"

Ethan's gaze turned glacial. "No need to wait." He pulled out his phone and dialed. "Bring Vanessa to me."

Hanging up, he gently caressed Jenna's cheek. "No one who hurts you will escape justice."

His phone rang again. Grandma Blanche's caller ID made him frown. "She's called over a dozen times these past two days. I kept saying you were asleep."

Jenna nodded understandingly. Answering the call, she heard Grandma Blanche's anxious voice: "Jenna dear, are you alright?"

"Grandma, I just woke up." Jenna summoned her strength. "Just feeling extra sleepy. Sorry for worrying you."

"Thank goodness! Rest well then."

After hanging up, Ethan scoffed. "She didn't even ask about me once."

Jenna chuckled weakly. "I just had a baby. Cut me some slack."

He playfully pinched her nose. "Fair enough."
###Chapter 500

Stella asked cautiously, "Mr. Roscente, how do you plan to deal with Vanessa?"

A ruthless glint flashed in Ethan's eyes. "She dared to lay a finger on Jenna. I'll make sure she begs for death."

Stella shivered under his icy gaze.

Vanessa must have a death wish, targeting Jenna like that.

Didn't she know how terrifying Ethan could be?

Even Lucien's father avoided crossing Ethan, let alone the entire Valois family.

This time, Vanessa had truly messed with the wrong person.

As evening fell, Ethan's phone rang.

It was Xavier.

After a brief call, Ethan hung up.

He turned to Jenna. "We've got her. I'll be back soon."

"Go ahead." Jenna nodded obediently. "If anyone else shows up, I'll have Stella smash them with a vase."

Ethan ruffled her hair before leaving.

The black Rolls-Royce sped toward Villa Ephrussi de Rothschild.

This was one of Ethan's properties, usually guarded by Xavier and his team.

Within half an hour, the car stopped in front of Villa 88.

Xavier had been waiting in the courtyard.

"Where is she?" Ethan's voice was glacial.

"In the basement." Xavier led the way respectfully. "This way, sir."

The basement was dimly lit, with only a single swaying bulb.

A woman in black was tied to a chair in the center.

Her eyes were blindfolded, her mouth sealed tightly with duct tape.

Hearing footsteps, she struggled violently, muffled whimpers escaping.

Ethan raised a hand.

Xavier immediately removed the blindfold and tape.

Vanessa's eyes widened in terror. "E-Ethan?!"

"Surprised?" Ethan looked down at her coldly. "Didn't think about consequences when you attacked Jenna?"

Vanessa's face turned deathly pale.

All she'd wanted was Jenna dead!

How could that bitch survive after losing so much blood?

"Ethan, let me explain—" Her voice trembled.

Ethan waved impatiently. "Do it."

Xavier and the bodyguards stepped forward, fists raining down.
